Venusaur.overview: Venusaur is a phenomenal sun sweeper in UU. Venusaur's defensive typing lets it set up on many common Pokemon like Tangrowth, Swampert, and Rotom-W, allowing it to clean teams with its Growth boots. With moves like Giga Drain for reliable recovery, a powerful 100-Base Power and sun-boosted Weather Ball, and Sludge Bomb or Earth Power, Venusaur is able to punch holes in many teams, as with a boost it 2HKOes nearly every Pokemon in the tier barring Chansey. With a Modest nature, it outspeeds every relevant Pokemon in the tier under sun. However, Venusaur is severely limited if sun is no longer active, being outsped and KOed by plenty of Pokemon like Salamence and Azelf or used as setup bait for Pokemon like Scizor. Without a boost, Venusaur can sometimes be too weak to sweep, as common Pokemon like Rotom-H and Moltres are able to survive an unboosted hit and OHKO it back. Lastly, priority users such as Zygarde-10%, Scizor, and Mamoswine can pick off a weakened Venusaur. The inconsistency of sun teams because of Hippowdon limits the prominence of Venusaur in the metagame.
Venusaur.comments:
Other Options

Knock Off can be used to remove Chansey's Eviolite while also nailing Nihilego and Chandelure, but generally Venusaur benefits much more from its other moves; it can OHKO Nihilego and Chandelure with Earth Power, and after enough boosts from Growth it can damage Chansey with Giga Drain and outheal the damage done by Seismic Toss. Venusaur can run a defensive set with Leech Seed to blank Amoonguss and check Primarina, but generally Amoonguss is the better option thanks to Spore and Regenerator.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types and Fire-type Coverage: If Venusaur chooses to not run Earth Power, Chandelure can stomach any of Venusaur's hits at +2 and take it out with a Fire-type attack. Rotom-H and Moltres are can take an unboosted Sludge Bomb from Venusaur and KO it back with their Fire-type attacks. Threats who commonly carry Fire-type coverage like Salamence, Hydreigon, and Nidoqueen can take an unboosted hit and KO Venusaur in return.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Special walls such as Chansey, Umbreon, and Mandibuzz can take any of Venusaur's hits and stall out sun turns with their recovery moves, with the former wearing it down with Seismic Toss and the latter two being able to hit Venusaur hard with Foul Play due to Growth's attack boosts. However, Venusaur can outdamage Seismic Toss's damage with Giga Drain if it manages to accumulate enough boosts. Nihilego can take on an unboosted Venusaur but loses if it boosts on the switch-in. Assault Vest Galarian Slowbro can take a +2 hit and KO it back.

Priority Users: Zygarde-10%, Lycanroc-D, Scizor, and Mamoswine can revenge kill Venusaur using their priority moves if Venusaur is worn down, which can happen due to Venusaur sometimes having to take a hit to set up Growth while also dealing with Life Orb recoil.

sets.name: Chlorophyll Sweeper
sets.description:
Growth is a powerful setup move under sun, boosting Venusaur's Special Attack by 2 stages and allowing it to 2HKO nearly all the Pokemon in the tier. It can set up on popular Pokemon such as Tangrowth, Swampert, and Amoonguss due to its typing, and then sweep through opposing teams. Giga Drain hits Water-, Ground-, and Rock-types like Primarina, Hippowdon, and Lycanroc-D super effectively. Weather Ball is Venusaur's main attacking move under sun, as its Base Power becomes 100 and is boosted by the sun, KOing Steel-types that resist Giga Drain like Celesteela, Scizor, Skarmory, and Jirachi. Sludge Bomb hits Pokemon that resist Giga Drain and Weather Ball like Salamence, Hydreigon, and Rotom-H while also hitting Fairy-types like Hatterene super effectively, though it will need a boost to OHKO the former two. Earth Power is an alternative option to hit Tentacruel, Chandelure, and Nihilego harder, but this leaves Venusaur susceptible to Salamence, as Giga Drain and Weather Ball are mandatory moves. Maximum investment in Special Attack and Speed ensures Venusaur is as strong and fast as possible. A Modest nature is used to maximize damage output while still nearly outspeeding everything under the sun. Life Orb is used to boost Venusaur's damage output, letting it OHKO Pokemon such as Rotom-H, Salamence, and Moltres after a boost, while a boost to Giga Drain gives Venusaur insane damage output and reliable recovery, making it a powerful force.

Venusaur only fits on sun teams, so Torkoal is a mandatory partner, as it is the most reliable sun setter in the tier. It provides the team with entry hazard support and entry hazard control with Stealth Rock and Rapid Spin, respectively. Other Pokemon that take advantage of sun like Chandelure, Darmanitan, and Hatterene break holes in enemy teams thanks to their powerful wallbreaking capabilities amplified by sun, allowing Venusaur to sweep much more easily. Hatterene in particular checks Hydreigon and discourages entry hazards from being set so Torkoal can come in more, allowing Venusaur to sweep more easily. Venusaur also appreciates momentum such as Teleport from Chansey and Flip Turn from Swampert to help it get in safely as well as give it more opportunities to set up; for example Chansey can bring Venusaur in on physical attackers like Scizor and Azumarill, which are forced out by it under sun.

Nidoqueen.overview: Nidoqueen is a capable entry hazard setter in UU thanks to its offensive potency with Sheer Force and Life Orb, being able to threaten a multitude of UU staples including Hippowdon, Tangrowth, Primarina, and Scizor. Its solid defensive typing also lets it check Pokemon such as Nihilego and Cobalion lacking Iron Head and discourage common Electric-types such as Rotom-H from using Volt Switch. However, Nidoqueen can struggle to pivot into Electric-types like Raikou and Thundurus-T that commonly carry super-effective coverage to break through it. Unfortunately, Nidoqueen's overreliance on its Life Orb leaves it susceptible to Knock Off from Pokemon it would pivot into like Nihilego. A low Speed stat gives Nidoqueen an undesirable matchup versus faster-paced teams, and although Nidoqueen sports a quality defensive typing, it is still weak to common Pokemon in the tier such as Mamoswine and Keldeo. These struggles sting a bit more because Nidoqueen has no form of reliable recovery, meaning it is worn down pretty quickly throughout a match. Nidoqueen typically faces competition from Hippowdon and Nihilego as Stealth Rock setters thanks to the former's greater bulk and reliable recovery and the latter's greater Speed.
Nidoqueen.comments:
Other Options

Nidoqueen can utilize Toxic Spikes over Stealth Rock to cripple foes like Hippowdon and Slowking, but Toxic Spikes struggle with the presence of Pokemon who can absorb them like Amoonguss and Nihilego as well as Pokemon immune to them like Salamence, Scizor, and Celesteela. Nidoqueen can run a bulkier set holding Black Sludge, as it can somewhat take advantage of its bulk and defensive typing to better check Cobalion and Rotom-H and do a better job setting up entry hazards, but this set struggles because it is somewhat weak.

Checks and Counters

Chansey: Chansey is the single best answer to Nidoqueen, as it can consistently switch into its attacks without worry, recover any damage away, and chip Nidoqueen with Seismic Toss.

Psychic-types and Psychic-type Coverage: Psychic-types such as Azelf, Necrozma, and Starmie all can outspeed and KO Nidoqueen, with Necrozma being able to live a hit and use it as set up fodder thanks to its high natural bulk. Threats Nidoqueen would normally check like Thundurus-T commonly carry Psychic-type coverage, keeping Nidoqueen from reliably checking them.

Water-types: The majority of Water-types in UU can outspeed and OHKO Nidoqueen with ease. Keldeo can outspeed Nidoqueen and OHKO it with Hydro Pump, Rotom-W nearly OHKOes it with Hydro Pump, and Choice Band Crawdaunt and Azumarill OHKO it with Aqua Jet. Slowking and Swampert easily take hits from Nidoqueen and deal heavy damage to it in return.

Ground-types: Hippowdon tanks Earth Power well and does massive damage with Earthquake. Faster Ground-types like Mamoswine, Diggersby, and Zygarde-10% outspeed and OHKO Nidoqueen.

sets.name: Offensive Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Nidoqueen is a reliable setter of entry hazards because of its above average bulk, ability to force switches, and good matchup versus hazard removers such as Salamence and Rotom-H. Earth Power and Sludge Wave are mandatory, powerful STAB moves that OHKO bulkier Pokemon such as Primarina, Cobalion, and Tangrowth. Fire Blast is an excellent coverage move and the best pick for the last slot, as it wipes out Scizor, almost OHKOes Amoonguss, and cleanly 2HKOes Celesteela. The given Speed EVs lets Nidoqueen outspeed and heavily damage Autotomize Celesteela, with the remaining EVs towards HP to better take on Cobalion and Scizor.

Nidoqueen best fits on offensive builds that appreciate an additional wallbreaker on top of a Stealth Rock setter. Tangrowth pairs very well with Nidoqueen, taking on dangerous Water-types like Keldeo and Starmie. It also heavily threatens Hippowdon. Physical cleaners like Swords Dance Scizor and Cobalion appreciate Nidoqueen's good matchup versus Amoonguss and Tangrowth and can wipe out specially defensive walls like Chansey and Mandibuzz in exchange. They both can also overwhelm Slowking for Nidoqueen. Pivots like Slowking, Thundurus-T, Rotom-H, and Noivern can bring Nidoqueen in against foes like Tangrowth, Nihilego, and Primarina. Slowking can also check faster threats to Nidoqueen like Keldeo and Azelf and let it enter the field safely with Teleport. Entry hazard removal from the likes of Salamence and Rotom-W can keep Nidoqueen from being worn down by Spikes.

Nidoking.overview: Thanks to its excellent offensive typing, ability in Sheer Force, powerful STAB moves like Sludge Wave and Earth Power, and excellent coverage moves like Fire Blast, Ice Beam, and Thunderbolt, Nidoking is a very powerful wallbreaker. It can hit a large portion of the tier for super effective damage, pressuring plenty of Pokemon like Skarmory, Primarina, and Amoonguss. Even though Nidoking is one of the most dangerous threats in the tier, its mediocre Speed tier and bulk mean it can't find many opportunities to wallbreak, mandating pivot support to get it onto the field safely. Nidoking also relies on its Life Orb to do massive damage, so it despises Knock Off from the likes of Nihilego and Thundurus-T. Its typing also doesn't benefit it much defensively, leaving it weak to common attacking types like Ground, Water, and Psychic from Pokemon like Excadrill, Azumarill, and Azelf. Furthermore, despite being a Ground-type, Nidoking doesn't provide a functional Electric immunity for its team, being outsped by Rotom-W, Rotom-H, and Thundurus-T and getting hit hard by their other moves. This lack of defensive utility makes it hard to justify over other Pokemon that share its Ground or Poison typing like Hippowdon, Excadrill, and Nihilego. Nidoqueen, while weaker, has more bulk than Nidoking, allowing it to fit Stealth Rock for role compression, and its lower Speed isn't a hinderance in UU.
Nidoking.comments:
Other Options

Stealth Rock can be run for role compression thanks to Nidoking preventing common entry hazard removers like Excadrill and Tentacruel from switching into it. While Nidoking's higher Attack might make a physical set worthwhile, it lacks the proper movepool, and most of its Sheer Force-boosted moves are special. Sucker Punch is an option to pick off the likes of Jirachi and Azelf as well as other revenge killers like Lycanroc-D, but forgoing coverage or added utility isn't great for Nidoking. While you forgo the additional power from Life Orb, a Choice Scarf set is a solid revenge killer while still being an effective wallbreaker.

Checks and Counters

Chansey: Thanks to Chansey's tremendously high special bulk, it is able to switch into any of Nidoking's attacks and can proceed to whittle it down with Seismic Toss, set up Stealth Rock, or recover its HP with Soft-Boiled.

Water-types: Keldeo and Rotom-W outspeed and threaten Nidoking. Crawdaunt and Azumarill can both effectively revenge kill Nidoking thanks to Aqua Jet. Slowking can tank a Thunderbolt and deal heavy damage with Scald or pivot out into a revenge killer.

Ground-types: Pokemon like Diggersby, Excadrill, and Zygarde-10% can comfortably revenge kill Nidoking. Swampert and Hippowdon can switch into most attacks, but must be wary of switching into Earth Power as it can 2HKO. Gastrodon can switch in relatively easily and threaten it.

Psychic-types and Psychic-type Coverage: Psychic-types such as Necrozma, Azelf, and Starmie can hit Nidoking super effectively with their STAB moves. Psychic-type Coverage like Psychic on Thundurus-T and Psychic Fangs on Lycanroc-D keep Nidoking from switching into them.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Sludge Wave is Nidoking's strongest STAB move, hitting Pokemon like Hatterene, Tangrowth, and Primarina super effectively, as well as discouraging Rotom-W and Rotom-H from switching in freely. Earth Power slams Steel- and Poison-types such as Jirachi, Cobalion, and Nihilego. Fire Blast roasts Celesteela, Skarmory, and Scizor. It also OHKOes Amoonguss after Stealth Rock. Thunderbolt allows Nidoking to nail Water- and Flying-types like Slowking, Gyarados, and Mandibuzz. Alternatively, Substitute makes Nidoking much less prediction reliant, giving it free turns against foes that it forces out like Nihilego and Tangrowth. Ice Beam heavily pressures Hippowdon and OHKOes Salamence and Noivern, but these Pokemon get pressured by Nidoking's STAB attacks anyway. A Modest nature should be run to increase Nidoking's damage output against threats like Slowking and Mandibuzz, since it doesn't miss out on any notable Speed benchmarks. Life Orb and Sheer Force pair together to negate the health loss of Life Orb while giving an effective 70% power boost, which is a big factor behind Nidoking's power.

Nidoking fits best on offensive teams that are able to bring it in many times to wallbreak and tear through defensive Pokemon like Amoonguss and Skarmory. As a result, pivots such as Rotom-W, Zarude, and Moltres make for good partners. Zarude forces out Swampert and Hippowdon while Rotom-W lures in Tangrowth for Nidoking and OHKOes Krookodile. Chansey is also a great partner for Nidoking, providing pivot support while beating its common checks like Rotom-W and Hydreigon. Switch-ins to Psychic-, Ground-, and Water-type attacks like Jirachi, Tangrowth, and Amoonguss can be paired with Nidoking on bulkier teams. Jirachi also provides entry hazard support, allowing Nidoking to reliably KO Celesteela, and Healing Wish support to let it wallbreak even more. Tangrowth and Amoonguss are also able to handle Electric-types in the tier much better than Nidoking and can pivot into the likes of Zygarde-10% and Keldeo excellently. Late-game cleaners like Scizor and Cobalion are great teammates to break through Chansey, which Nidoking struggles against. Sticky Web support from Ribombee offsets Nidoking's average Speed tier, allowing it to outspeed and OHKO threats like Tentacruel, Excadrill, and Lycanroc-D.

Tentacruel.overview: With incredible Special Defense, an excellent defensive typing that allows it to deal with threats like Primarina, Keldeo, and Celesteela, and the distinction of being one of the only viable Rapid Spin users in the tier, Tentacruel is a solid option for many balance and bulky offense teams. Access to Knock Off alongside Scald and Sludge Bomb make Tentacruel nearly impossible to switch into, threatening foes like Amoonguss with a burn or Slowking with a Sludge Bomb poison. Additionally, it matches up well against common entry hazard setters like Cobalion and Skarmory. Its base 100 Speed lets it outrun and deal heavy damage to offensive threats like Excadrill and Mamoswine. While its Special Defense is excellent, its Defense and HP are fairly poor, making it difficult for Tentacruel to switch into strong physical attackers like Cobalion and Scizor. This is further worsened by Tentacruel's mediocre attacking stats making it difficult to acquire KOs and leaving it overly reliant on status, which worsen its matchup against foes like Azelf, Galarian Slowbro, and Salamence. These weaknesses also put Tentacruel at a disadvantage against other common entry hazard setters like Hippowdon, Nidoqueen, and Excadrill, which can handle Scald, and make it difficult to remove entry hazards. Tentacruel's lack of recovery severly hinders its ability to check foes it normally would with its typing like Cobalion, Scizor, and even Keldeo, causing other Water-types like Slowking and Primarina to be preffered over it.
Tentacruel.comments:
Other Options

Ice Beam hits Dragon-types like Salamence and Hydreigon super effectively. Haze allows Tentacruel to shut down setup sweepers like Calm Mind Primarina, Calm Mind Keldeo, and Autotomize Celesteela, which can take advantage of its passivity. Toxic Spikes can be used to give Tentacruel its own method of setting up entry hazards, but it is unreliable due to the prevalence of Heavy-Duty Boots and Amoonguss.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Electric types such as Thundurus-T, Raikou, and Rotom-W severely dent Tentacruel with their STAB attacks. They all can also easily use Volt Switch on Tentacruel to generate free momentum.

Ground-types: Hippowdon, Swampert, and Excadrill easily OHKO Tentacruel with Earthquake, although they don't like having to take a Scald in the process. Seismitoad and Gastrodon are immune to Scald and resistant to Sludge Bomb, which means Tentacruel can only force progress by fishing for poison against them. Gastrodon also has reliable recovery, which makes fishing for poison even more ineffective.

Dragon-types: Hydreigon and Zygarde-10% outspeed and nail Tentacruel hard. Salamence and Noivern can switch into Tentacruel if needed, though they hate taking Knock Off and losing their Heavy-Duty Boots or getting Poisoned by Sludge Bomb.

Psychic-types: Hatterene, Azelf, and Necrozma easily OHKO Tentacruel with Psyshock or Photon Geyser, although Hatterene doesn't like taking a Sludge Bomb. Galarian Slowbro is especially troublesome for Tentacruel, as it cannot be poisoned and can easily set up on Tentacruel with Calm Mind.

Physical Attackers: Conkeldurr, Crobat, Zarude, and Gyarados can muscle through Tentacruel due to its poor Defense. The former is especially dangerous, as it doesn't have to fear getting burned by Scald.

sets.name: Defensive Spinner
sets.description:
Scald can threaten common Pokemon like Scizor, Cobalion, and Amoonguss with a burn. Sludge Bomb prevents Tentacruel from being too passive and hits foes such as Tangrowth, Primarina, and Azumarill. It also has a chance to poison, which is useful for crippling threats like Salamence, Keldeo, and Slowking. Rapid Spin can provide a boost to Tentacruel's Speed, letting it outspeed common Pokemon like Lycanroc-D, Noivern, and Azelf. Knock Off cripples checks like Chansey, Salamence, and Swampert. Black Sludge gives Tentacruel a form of recovery, which it completely lacks otherwise. Liquid Ooze punishes draining moves such as Leech Seed, allowing it to deal passive damage to foes that rely on these moves for recovery, like Celesteela and Amoonguss. A Timid nature and 160 Speed EVs allow Tentacruel to outspeed Excadrill and Rotom-W. The rest of the EVs are put into Defense to more easily deal with Cobalion and Keldeo's Secret Sword.

Tentacruel is best used on balance and bulky offense teams that appreciate its ability to remove entry hazards. Entry hazard setters like Hippowdon and Skarmory benefit greatly from Tentacruel removing Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off and clearing entry hazards solely from its side of the field, which let them fully capitalize on their entry hazards. Hippowdon also checks threatening foes like Thundurus-T and Galarian Slowbro for Tentacruel. Grass-types like Tangrowth and Tapu Bulu provide switch-ins to some of Tentacruel's biggest checks such as Thundurus-T, Raikou, and Zygarde-10%. The latter can also set up Grassy Terrain, which provides Tentacruel with another source of recovery and weakens Earthquake. Jirachi provides Wish support for Tentacruel. Other Steel-types like Scizor and Celesteela can take on Psychic- and Dragon-types like Azelf and Hydreigon for Tentacruel.

Slowbro-Galar.overview: Thanks to its amazing ability and typing, Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro can act as a great late-game cleaner. Its resistances let it stomach hits from the likes of Nihilego and Amoonguss, and its Poison STAB allows it to threaten Pokemon such as Primarina and Tangrowth. Galarian Slowbro's decent bulk and Regenerator let it come in multiple times to spam Sludge Bomb or Scald, wearing checks like Jirachi and Gastrodon down through potential poison and burns. It can similarly cripple offensive checks like Krookodile, Zarude, and Keldeo, which it can take a hit from and then switch out. Regenerator lets Galarian Slowbro easily set up even if it's been weakened or forced out early-game, and it's very difficult to take out once it gets going with Calm Mind. Its immunity to Toxic also contributes to its longevity. Being capable of using Colbur or Shuca Berry forces Pokemon like Zarude and Mamoswine to scout for its specific Berry. However, its very low Speed for a sweeper lets Pokemon like Krookodile, Diggersby, and Azumarill revenge kill it. Its special bulk is not good before setting up, leaving it weak to special attackers such as Primarina and Galarian Moltres. Galarian Slowbro can easily become setup fodder for Pokemon like Calm Mind Reuniclus and Suicune. Furthermore, it faces competition with Reuniclus as a Calm Mind sweeper because of its Magic Guard and ability to beat Pokemon like Celesteela more easily. Reuniclus is also not weak to Ground, easing matchups against Pokemon like Gastrodon and Nidoqueen.
Slowbro-Galar.comments:
Other Options

Heavy-Duty Boots preventing entry hazard damage can create more setup opportunities.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Choice Band Krookodile, Crawdaunt, and Galarian Moltres scare Galarian Slowbro with their Dark-type attacks. The former two do huge amounts of damage to Shuca Berry Galarian Slowbro, and even after consuming its Colbur Berry, Knock Off still does a good chunk. Galarian Moltres takes advantage of Galarian Slowbro's bad Special Defense before it sets up. It also doesn't fear status thanks to Rest.

Ground-types: Quagsire doesn't care about Galarian Slowbro's boosts thanks to Unaware. Rhyperior, Mamoswine, Diggersby, and Krookodile can remove Galarian Slowbro with their powerful Earthquakes, but they have to be wary of Scald and potential burns. Furthermore, they should only be brought in to revenge kill Galarian Slowbro and while knowing its item, as Shuca Berry can negate its Ground weakness.

Ghost-types: Both Aegislash and Chandelure can exploit the low Special Defense of Galarian Slowbro before setting up. They also can heavily damage Assault Vest variants, though they dislike taking a super effective hit in return if they fail to KO it.

Knock Off and Trick: All of Galarian Slowbro's sets hate Knock Off, Trick, or both even. Assault Vest Galarian Slowbro can lose its Assault Vest against Pokemon it normally checks like Nihilego, making it a weaker pivot into threats like Thundurus-T. Both Assault Vest and Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro get crippled by Trick from threats like Jirachi and Rotom-W.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
Future Sight lets Galarian Slowbro assist teammates like Zarude by preventing checks such as Buzzwole from freely switching in. Ice Beam can be used in its place to hit Salamence and Kommo-o a bit harder, especially on teams that don't benefit from the Future Sight support as much. Psyshock lets Galarian Slowbro immediately threaten Pokemon like Keldeo, Nihilego, and Amoonguss without having to rely on Future Sight. Shell Side Arm is mostly used to pressure Calm Mind Primarina. Sludge Bomb is an alternative to fish for poison more reliably on foes like Salamence when not running Ice Beam, but it's not as reliable overall due to being worse against Calm Mind users. Flamethrower targets Steel-types like Aegislash and Jirachi. It also hits Buzzwole harder than Psyshock without depending on Future Sight. Eathquake is an option to hit Nihilego, Tentacruel, and Aegislash on teams that struggle to fit Psyshock and Flamethrower. Scald is another option that nails Krookodile on the switch as well as Rhyperior. Assault Vest lets Galarian Slowbro face special attackers like Keldeo, Primarina, and Salamence with ease. A Quiet nature is used to secure an OHKO with Ice Beam on Salamence and to not lower Galarian Slowbro's damage output when using physical Shell Side Arm while still boosting its Special Attack. 16 Special Attack EVs make Galarian Slowbro less passive overall.

Mienshao, Buzzwole, and Lycanroc-D love Galarian Slowbro's Future Sight support letting them break through checks like Buzzwole and Amoonguss a lot more easily. They also appreciate Galarian Slowbro's ability to pressure checks like Salamence and Tapu Bulu with its coverage. In return, they threaten Dark-types like Zarude and Krookodile with their Fighting-type attacks. Amoonguss, Buzzwole, and Tapu Bulu make for great partners, as they take on physical attackers like Lycanroc-D and Crawdaunt, act as Knock Off absorbers, and check Dark- and Ground-types like Zarude and Rhyperior. Amoonguss notably forms a Regenerator core with Galarian Slowbro and acts as a great secondary check to Keldeo and Primarina. Secondary checks to special attackers such as Nidoking, Aegislash, and Nihilego are needed, as Galarian Slowbro is 2HKOed by STAB moves from the former two and hates losing its Assault Vest to the latter's Knock Off. Rotom-W, Zarude, and Cobalion are Pokemon that can pivot into their STAB attacks and keep offensive presence. Entry hazard removal from partners like Salamence and Starmie is appreciated to facilitate Galarian Slowbro's ability to check special attackers like Salamence.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Calm Mind allows Galarian Slowbro to muscle through checks like Jirachi and Gastrodon. Psyshock has great synergy with Flamethrower, the former hitting Nihilego and Chansey while the latter targets Steel-types like Aegislash. Sludge Bomb is an option to cripple Pokemon like Galarian Moltres and Crawdaunt, while also doing more damage to Primarina and Hatterene. Scald is aimed at Ground-types such as Rhyperior and Krookodile, and it can burn physically offensive threats like Kommo-o. However, it will have a harder time dealing with Aegislash. Slack Off helps Galarian Slowbro pose a constant threat and set up on Pokemon like Celesteela. Shuca Berry does the same against Ground-types like Nidoking and Mamoswine. Kasib Berry lets you take a Shadow Ball from Aegislash and retaliate back with a boosted Flamethrower. Colbur Berry lets it take an attack like Zarude's Darkest Lariat and KO back. Safety Goggles is an option that lets Galarian Slowbro beat Amoonguss and stay in against Spore. A Bold nature and the given EV spread help against physical attackers such as Azumarill. An EV spread of 252 HP / 152 Def / 104 SpD with a Bold nature avoids the 2HKO from Choice Specs Primarina's Moonblast, lets +1 Galarian Slowbro always take Choice Specs Chandelure's Shadow Ball, and improves its odds at beating Aegislash.

Tapu Bulu is an exceptional teammate for its Grassy Terrain, which allows Galarian Slowbro to face Ground-types like Mamoswine and Rhyperior more easily. Tapu Bulu also takes on dangerous threats like Crawdaunt, while Galarian Slowbro removes Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth. Tapu Bulu and Tangrowth can remove Krookodile and Rhyperior, some the largest Ground-type threats to Galarian Slowbro. Due to Galarian Slowbro's low Speed, pivots that can get it in safely against setup fodder are ideal teammates. Jirachi and Zarude can use U-turn in front of Pokemon like Celesteela and Buzzwole. Raikou and Rotom-W can use Volt Switch on Grass-types and offensively check Chandelure. Galarian Slowbro appreciates Mienshao and Buzzwole checking Dark-types such as Krookodile and Crawdaunt. Entry hazard removal from the likes of Salamence and Rotom-W is needed. Strong wallbreakers like Choice Band Krookodile and Buzzwole can remove Calm Mind sweepers that beat Galarian Slowbro one-on-one like Suicune.

sets.name: QCQD
sets.description:
Galarian Slowbro is able to maximize its power with Nasty Plot and destroy would-be checks like Kommo-o and Aegislash. The chance to activate either Quick Draw or Quick Claw is 44%, which makes a fortunate Galarian Slowbro difficult to check. Galarian Slowbro can be tailored to what it needs to break. Psyshock is useful for dealing with Keldeo and Chansey. Fire Blast is essential for hitting Steel-types like Celesteela and Aegislash. Ice Beam hits common Pokemon such as Salamence, Krookodile, and Thundurus-T, but Grass Knot is an alternative to have a better matchup against bulkier teams, as it can OHKO Quagsire and Rhyperior. Other combinations of these moves like Sludge Wave / Psyshock / Fire Blast or Weather Ball with rain support are also acceptable, depending on the rest of the team.

Quick Claw Quick Draw Galarian Slowbro is best on hyper offense structures, especially with team support from Pokemon such as Alolan Ninetales, which helps it set up much easier. Galarian Slowbro is also useful on Sticky Web teams, where it can be slightly less reliant on Quick Claw + Quick Draw to outspeed Amoonguss and Aegislash and provide some defensive utility with its resistances and ability to absorb Toxic Spikes. Entry hazard support from Pokemon such as Krookodile can facilitate an easier sweep. Galarian Slowbro is vulnerable to Pokemon like Krookodile and Kommo-o, so other setup sweepers such as Galarian Moltres and Salamence are good partners. Rotom-W and Zarude can draw in passive Pokemon such as Chansey and Tangrowth for Galarian Slowbro. In return, Galarian Slowbro can lure Kommo-o and Tangrowth.

Cloyster.overview: Cloyster is a unique, solid setup sweeper with Shell Smash + Skill Link on hyper offense teams. Its naturally high Defense lets it set up on physical attackers such as Zygarde-10%, Mamoswine, and Excadrill. After a Shell Smash boost, Cloyster can threaten many top UU threats such as Hippowdon, Salamence, and Amoonguss, with only a select few Pokemon able to revenge kill it at +2. However, Cloyster's lackluster Special Defense stat and initial speed prevent it from setting up against offensive teams with powerful special attackers such as Azelf, Nihilego, and Thundurus-T. Even at +2 Speed, Cloyster is outsped by common Choice Scarf users such as Zarude and Hydreigon. Cloyster cannot fit coverage for both Slowking and Primarina, and it just cannot get past checks such as Keldeo, Rotom-W, and Tentacruel. It is vulnerable to priority moves such as Lycranroc-D's Accelerock and Conkeldurr's Mach Punch, and can have its sweep cut short by status, Life Orb recoil, and entry hazards.
Cloyster.comments:
Other Options

Focus Sash could be used in place of Life Orb or White Herb to get off a Shell Smash reliably, but this item necessitates using a Taunt lead or Rapid Spin Excadrill to block or clear entry hazards. Heavy-Duty Boots can be run to mitigate Cloyster's entry hazard weakness, but, like with any item bar Life Orb, Cloyster will fail to get past Skarmory and Cobalion.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: Fighting-types such as Conkeldurr, Cobalion, and Keldeo offensively pressure and KO Cloyster. Conkeldurr can also pick off Cloyster using Mach Punch. However, Cobalion is cleanly OHKOed by a +2 Hydro Pump.

Bulky Water-types: Bulky Water-types such as Rotom-W and Tentacruel can tank Cloyster's hits and KO it with Volt Switch or Sludge Bomb, respectively. Additionally, Slowking or Primarina can wall Poison Jab sets and Pin Missile sets, respectively.

Faster Threats and Priority Moves: Faster threats such as Nihilego, Azelf, Thundurus-T, and Salamence can take advantage of Cloyster's poor Special Defense and KO it before it boosts. Common Choice Scarf users like Zarude and Hydreigon can outspeed Cloyster at +2 and KO it with their STAB moves. Common priority move users such as Scizor, Zygarde-10%, and Lycanroc-D can also KO Cloyster after it boosts.

sets.name: Shell Smash Sweeper
sets.description:
With Skill Link, Icicle Spear, and a Shell Smash Boost, Cloyster can defeat many top threats, such as Diggersby, Celesteela, Tangrowth, and Thundurus-T. Pin Missile hits Ice-resistant Pokemon such as Slowking and, somewhat less importantly, Starmie, for super effective damage. However, Poison Jab is an option to KO certain Water-types such as Primarina and Azumarill. It also hits Keldeo and Rotom-W for greater damage. Hydro Pump is run to OHKO physically defensive Pokemon such as Cobalion and Skarmory after a boost. Life Orb secures these OHKOs, but it can severely cut into Cloyster's longevity. White Herb is an alternative that restores Cloyster's defenses back to normal after Shell Smash, limiting its vulnerability to Scizor's Bullet Punch and potentially letting it boost again. A Naughty nature gives Cloyster maximum Attack without weakening Hydro Pump, as it does not care about decreasing its already low Special Defense.

Cloyster is primarily a late-game cleaner on hyper offense teams, which are great at weakening its checks. Cloyster appreciates a dedicated suicide lead, such as Excadrill or Scolipede, to set up entry hazards and rack up chip damage on threats such as Celesteela and Swampert. Excadrill's Stealth Rock also disables Skarmory's Sturdy, and it can remove hazards with Rapid Spin, alleviating Cloyster's weakness to them. Celesteela and Azelf can take on Fighting-types such as Conkeldurr and Cobalion, with the former beating Scizor and the latter able to revenge kill Keldeo as well. Gyarados and Thundurus-T can remove Water-types like Keldeo, Tentacruel, and Rotom-W for Cloyster. They also can wear down checks such as Slowking and Primarina. Scizor and Meteor Beam Nihilego pressure faster threats such as Zarude, Azelf, Salamence, and Hydreigon. Scizor can revenge kill Azelf with Bullet Punch and take a hit from Zarude, while Nihilego uses both Salamence and Hydreigon to fire off Meteor Beam.

Chansey.overview: Chansey's sky-high, Eviolite-boosted special bulk allows it to wall nearly every special attacker in UU, including nearly unwallable threats such as Nidoking, Choice Specs Hydreigon, and Choice Specs Primarina. In addition, Chansey can withstand certain physical attacks from threats like Zygarde-10% and cripple them with Toxic. Chansey is hard to wear down, since it has Soft-Boiled for HP recovery and Natural Cure to remove status ailments, allowing it to be a status sponge into the likes of Amoonguss, Slowking, and Swampert. Chansey possesses a trove of valuable utility moves such as Teleport, Thunder Wave, Aromatherapy, and Stealth Rock to support its team. However, Chansey is rather passive, as it relies on Seismic Toss and Toxic to deal damage. As a result, many Pokemon such as Scizor, Excadrill, Skarmory, and Cobalion easily take advantage of Chansey. Without Teleport, Chansey is a huge momentum drain for non-stall teams. Chansey's typing provides few useful resistances, and Chansey by itself must rely on its bulk to keep threats in check. Chansey is vulnerable to every entry hazard, meaning it gets overwhelmed by them quickly. Chansey is also susceptible to Knock Off from Pokemon it would normally check like Azelf and Thundurus-T, as without Eviolite, it is harder for Chansey to keep threats like Zygarde-10% and Choice Specs Hydreigon in check.
Chansey.comments:
Other Options

Chansey can run Counter to surprise physical attackers. However, it's hard to fit over another move, works only once as a lure, and depends on prediction.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types and Fighting-type Coverage: Fighting-types such as Cobalion, Conkeldurr, and Keldeo can easily break through Chansey with their powerful STAB moves. Fighting-type coverage from Skarmory, Lycanroc-D, and Tapu Bulu lets them break through Chansey easily. However, all but Conkeldurr dislike being crippled by Toxic or Thunder Wave.

Strong Physical Attackers: Strong physical attackers such as Diggersby, Mamoswine, Azumarill, and Swords Dance Excadrill can break through Chansey despite its Defense investment with their powerful moves or weaken it by removing its Eviolite with Knock Off. However, most fear Toxic or Thunder Wave.

Bulky Setup Sweepers: Bulky setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Scizor and Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro are immune to Toxic and take advantage of Chansey's passive nature.

Knock Off and Trick: Every Knock Off user is a huge threat to Chansey, as once it loses its Eviolite, it is harder for it to switch into attacks. It must even watch out for Knock Off from Pokemon it normally checks like Azelf, Nihilego, and Thundurus-T. Trick users like Jirachi and Rotom-W limit Chansey's effectiveness by crippling it with a Choice item.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Seismic Toss makes Chansey less passive, since it deals reliable damage to all but Ghost-types. Toxic helps Chansey wear down the enemy team, especially against bulky foes like Salamence, Hippowdon, and Tangrowth. Teleport is a great support move to bring other teammates safely onto the battlefield and to keep up momentum on more offensive teams. Since Chansey has little to fear from many special attackers, it can force switches and get many opportunities to set up Stealth Rock. Chansey can use Aromatherapy to act as a cleric; however, this is usually only considered on balance and stall teams. Thunder Wave can be used instead of Toxic to support slow teammates like Conkeldurr and cripple Scizor and Cobalion, but it makes Chansey weaker against bulky Pokemon and has less use overall. Wish is a helpful option to heal teammates, especially those without a reliable recovery move like Mamoswine. Maximum investment in Defense and HP alongside a Bold nature allows Chansey to check Azelf and Hatterene as well as weaker physical attackers such Hippowdon more effectively.

Chansey can fit on bulky offense, balance, and stall teams as a sturdy wall for special attackers. Sturdy physical walls such as Tangrowth and Skarmory can check threatening wallbreakers such as Lycanroc-D, Diggersby, and Mamoswine for Chansey. In return, Chansey checks strong special attackers such as Nidoking, Moltres, and Primarina. Wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Hydreigon and Zygarde-10% appreciate Teleport Chansey's ability to bring them safely onto the battlefield. Since entry hazards limit Chansey's ability to switch into attacks and force it to recover more, entry hazard control from Salamence, Skarmory, and Excadrill is crucial. Umbreon and Quagsire can check threatening setup sweepers like Gyarados, Scizor, and Galarian Slowbro, with Umbreon also offering Wish support to Chansey's teammates and a check to physical threats such as Zygarde-10%, Mamoswine, and Jirachi. Ditto is also an option to keep offensive setup sweepers like Azumarill and Gyarados in check. A good Knock Off absorber such as Tangrowth, Amoonguss, or Cobalion is helpful, as Chansey needs Eviolite to better switch into attacks. Amoonguss is also able to check Keldeo and Azumarill. The common presence of Scizor means Chansey needs counters to it in order to function; Defensive Salamence, Iron Defense Skarmory, and Iron Defense Registeel are all helpful in handling it.

Starmie.overview: With a variety of coverage moves like Ice Beam and Thunderbolt alongside a great Speed tier to outrun top UU Pokemon like Keldeo, Nihilego, and Salamence, Starmie is a solid offensive threat in the UU metagame, being able to threaten nearly the entire tier for super effective damage and 2HKO most of it. Starmie's wide coverage allows it to force many switches, and its ability Analytic severely punishes nearly all of them. Starmie's access to Recover also allows it to use its typing to check common foes like Celesteela and Keldeo throughout a game. However, while Starmie's Analytic-boosted attacks can hit exceptionally hard, Starmie's unboosted attacks are not too powerful and can be strugged off by many Pokemon like Scizor, Rotom-W, Chansey, and Assault Vest Tangrowth. Furthermore, Starmie is prone to being worn down by entry hazards and Life Orb recoil, forcing it to use Recover more than it would like and limiting its effectiveness as a wallbreaker. Starmie's vulnerable typing and frailty causes it to be easily revenge killed by common Choice Scarf users like Diggersby and Hydreigon. While slower, Keldeo is stronger and doesn't rely on Life Orb to do damage, making it the preffered option on more teams. Still, Starmie's Speed lends it a valuable place on teams that need it.
Starmie.comments:
Other Options

Starmie can run a bulky utility set with Rapid Spin to remove entry hazards against common setters like Cobalion, Skarmory, and Hippowdon. It also utilizes Natural Cure to absorb Toxic from foes like the aformentioned Hippowdon. However, this set is very passive and gives free entry for common threats like Hydreigon. On the offensive set, Scald can be run to cripple physical attackers with a burn, but the power drop is noticeable.

Checks and Counters

Faster Threats and Priority: Choice Scarf users like Diggersby, Hydreigon, and Zarude outspeed Starmie and KO it due to its frailty. Both Crobat and Noivern naturally outspeeds Starmie and heavily damages it with their STAB attacks. Priority move users like Zygarde-10% and Lycanroc-D can also pick off a weakened Starmie.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Common specially defensive Pokemon like Chansey, Gastrodon, and Assault Vest Tangrowth can all take Starmie's attacks and limit it in their own ways. The former two can status it, hampering Starmie's longevity, while the latter can KO Starmie with Power Whip.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Hydro Pump deals devastating damage to common Pokemon like Hippowdon, Scizor, and Cobalion. Alternatively, Surf can be used for increased accuracy but slightly less power. Ice Beam threatens Grass-types like Tangrowth, Amoonguss, and Zarude as well as Dragon-types like Salamence and Hydreigon. Thunderbolt threatens Water-types like Slowking, Primarina, Gyarados, and Keldeo. Recover is used to alleviate the Life Orb and heal off entry hazard damage, improving Starmie's longevity against foes like Keldeo. It can often use the move against common Pokemon it forces out such as Cobalion and Nihilego. Life Orb combined with Analytic gives Starmie an incredible damage output, letting it 2HKO nearly the entire tier.

Starmie best fits on offensive teams due to its great Speed tier and solid wallbreaking power. Due to Starmie's frailty, it appreciates pivot support from Pokemon like Thundurus-T, Scizor, and Diggersby to get in safely against Pokemon like Nihilego and Salamence. Thundurus-T in particular likes Starmie's ability to deal with Ground-types like Hippowdon so it can freely use Volt Switch, and it also helps wear down Grass-types like Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth. Scizor is a key teammate in blanking foes like Chansey and Assault Vest Tangrowth for Starmie. Defoggers like Salamence help Starmie from getting worn down by clearing entry hazards, appreciating Starmie's ability to dispatch threats like Nihilego and Lycanroc-D. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Hippowdon, Nihilego, and Cobalion allows Starmie to break through opposing teams more easily, as it wears down Pokemon like Rotom-W and Chansey for it. The former two also serve as excellent answers to Salamence, while the latter counters Zarude and pressures Slowking and Tangrowth with its Swords Dance set. Tangrowth and Amoonguss are notable partners for Starmie, as they are able to deal with faster threats like Choice Scarf Diggersby for it. Both appreciate Starmie pressuring troublesome Pokemon like Moltres and Salamence for them in return.

Gyarados.overview: Gyarados is one of the most dangerous setup sweepers in UU due to its fantastic coverage and combination of Dragon Dance and Moxie, which allow it to muscle through almost everything in the tier. Great coverage moves like Ice Fang help it break through Grass- and Dragon-types like Zarude, Amoonguss, and Salamence, while Power Whip allows it to hit Water-types like Rotom-W, Swampert, and Slowking, and beat standard Unaware walls like Quagsire, unlike many other physical sweepers like Azumarill. It has good HP and respectable bulk, allowing it to withstand attacks from threats like Keldeo, Scizor, and certain Excadrill sets while setting up. Unfortunately, its only Flying-type STAB move is Bounce, which has low accuracy and is exploitable because it requires two turns to use without Power Herb. Meanwhile, Ice Fang's power can be underwhelming at times when facing bulky Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth. Unboosted Gyarados is outsped by many common threats such as Thundurus-T, Zarude, and Nihilego. Even at +1 Speed, it will still get outsped by Choice Scarf users like Zarude and Hydreigon. Gyarados's weakness to Stealth Rock and vulnerable Speed can keep it from safely setting up against more offensive teams. Gyarados struggles against defensive Pokemon like Umbreon, Mandibuzz, Skarmory, and Tangrowth due to their immense bulk and ability to hinder Gyarados from gaining too many boosts.
Gyarados.comments:
Other Options

Intimidate can be used on a more balance-oriented team to set up more freely against physical foes, but it notably lessens Gyarados's sweeping potential. A Substitute set with Waterfall, Bounce, and Leftovers as an item can help Gyarados break through defensive teams, as Substitute blocks status and Gyarados can easily boost multiple times against foes like Celesteela and Hippowdon. However, the lack of coverage causes it to struggle with foes like Rotom-W and Quagsire.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Electric-types like Thundurus-T, Raikou, and Rotom-W reliably outspeed and KO Gyarados. While they can also withstand an unboosted hit, Rotom-W loses to boosted Power Whip, Raikou drops to +1 Waterfall, and Thundurus-T can get KOed by Ice Fang.

Physical Walls: Many physical walls can be challenging for Gyarados, as it requires multiple boosts to KO them. Mandibuzz and Umbreon can take multiple boosted hits from Gyarados and OHKO it with Foul Play. Skarmory can simiarly take several hits and chip it down with Rocky Helmet while forcing it out with Whirlwind, but Mystic Water Gyarados can break through Skarmory with a flinch. Rocky Helmet Tangrowth can give Gyarados problems if it does not have Bounce, as +1 Ice Fang does not 2HKO. Chansey can withstand several boosted hits and cripple Gyarados with Toxic.

Revenge Killers: Gyarados is slow, and many Choice Scarf users like Hydreigon, Diggersby, and Zarude will outspeed it at +1 and deal heavy damage with STAB or coverage moves, so Gyarados needs to boost to +2 Speed to overcome these threats. Lycanroc-D can revenge kill Gyarados with Accelrock, though Gyarados must be slightly chipped to guarantee the KO.

sets.name: Dragon Dance Sweeper
sets.description:
Ice Fang hits many threats like Salamence, Hydreigon, Mandibuzz, and Zarude. However, Gyarados requires multiple boosts to reliably KO bulky Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss with it. Bounce can be used over Ice Fang, as it can more reliably KO a chipped Amoonguss with just one boost. However, Bounce requires a Power Herb as the item to limit its exploitability from Protect, Substitute, or switching. Even so, once the Power Herb is consumed Gyarados will still fall victim to these issues. Power Whip offers essential coverage against bulky Water-types like Quagsire, Slowking, and Rotom-W. Moxie is the preferred ability, as it enables Gyarados to snowball through a team after one or two boosts. Mystic Water allows Gyarados to break through Celesteela, Skarmory, and Mandibuzz much easier with Waterfall, letting it break through the latter two with only one flinch instead of two at +1. Meanwhile, Lum Berry is an alternative option to allow Gyarados free setup twice against foes like Chansey and Swampert. On more bulky offense teams, Heavy-Duty Boots can be used to prevent Stealth Rock damage, allowing Gyarados to switch in more frequently. An Adamant nature is preffered for extra wallbreaking power, plus it guarantees an OHKO on Azumarill with unboosted Power Whip as well as Thundurus-T with +1 Ice Fang. However, a Jolly nature has merits in outspeeding Choice Scarf Diggersby as well as Togekiss when unboosted.

Gyarados is best used on hyper offense and bulky offense teams due to the offensive pressure it offers. Gyarados is primarily used as a late-game cleaner, but it struggles against defensive Pokemon like Chansey and Amoonguss. A teammate that offers entry hazard support like Krookodile and Excadrill helps wear these foes down enough for Gyarados to break through them. Both of these Pokemon can absorb Electric-type attacks and keep Stealth Rock off with Taunt or Rapid Spin, allowing Gyarados to use Lum Berry or Mystic Water. Early game wallbreakers and sweepers like Celesteela, Scizor, and Thundurus-T can break through walls like Mandibuzz, Chansey, and Celesteela, allowing Gyarados to clean these typically bulky threats up more easily. Sticky Web setters like Ribombee can make up for Gyarados's mediocre Speed tier and prevent Choice Scarf users like Diggersby from revenge killing it. On more bulky offense teams, Hatterene is a great partner to block Stealth Rock from Swampert and Hippowdon as well as counter Skarmory and Mandibuzz. Amoonguss can take on faster threats like Zarude and Thundurus-T for Gyarados.

Ditto.overview: The combination of Imposter and Choice Scarf allows Ditto to outspeed the foe, making it a strong setup deterrent and one of the best revenge killers to sweepers like Thundurus-T, Salamence, and Gyarados. Ditto also has utility against stall teams, as it cannot be easily PP stalled, especially if it is able to switch into Knock Off from Tangrowth, and can take advantage of transforming into opposing clerics like Umbreon and Chansey. However, Ditto can be awkward to fit onto teams, as it often cannot switch into anything safely or provide any defensive utility outside of Regenerator. Imposter also fails against Substitute, which can be problematic against sweepers like Primarina. Ditto is also unable to effectively stop bulkier setup sweepers with recovery such as Galarian Slowbro due to being Choice-locked.
Ditto.comments:
Other Options

Ditto's value is rooted in its revenge killing capabilities, so it should never run anything besides Choice Scarf.

Checks and Counters

Substitute Users: Substitute users like Jirachi, Nidoking, and Primarina can prevent Ditto from revenge killing them and proceed to wreak havoc.

Choice Scarf Users: Opposing Choice Scarf users like Hydreigon and Diggersby will always Speed tie with Ditto and cannot be reliably revenge killed.

Knock Off: Ditto relies on Choice Scarf to outspeed and properly check threats, so it should avoid taking a Knock Off except when it is copying Regenerator or facing a stall team.

sets.name: Imposter
sets.description:
Transform is the only move Ditto learns. The provided EVs allow Ditto to do more damage with Future Sight after transforming into a Pokemon like Slowking.

Ditto is able to function as a revenge killer on any archetype but is most often found on bulky balance or stall teams that are too passive to efficiently prevent Pokemon from setting up. Chansey is an excellent partner that can get Ditto in safely with Teleport to immediately pressure strong wallbreakers like Salamence and Lycanroc-D. Since Ditto is grounded before transforming, it is vulnerable to all entry hazards besides Sticky Web; entry hazard removal from Salamence and Mandibuzz is valuable to keep Ditto healthy. Skarmory is able to provide Spikes to wear down the opposing team to better facilitate a countersweep from Ditto. Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss appreciate Ditto's ability to countersweep, since Pokemon like Salamence often use them as setup fodder. In return, Tangrowth and Amoonguss can switch into opposing Choice Scarf users like Diggersby and Zarude, which Speed tie with Ditto, and sponge Knock Off. Regenerator users such as the aforementioned Reuniclus, Amoonguss, and Tangrowth work well with Ditto, as they can PP stall defensive walls like Chansey together. On stall teams, Pokemon like Haze Quagsire and Articuno can beat Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro, which Ditto is unable to revenge kill.

Articuno.overview: Pressure + Defog gives Articuno a solid niche on defensive teams to PP stall entry hazard setters such as Hippowdon, making it a capable solo or primary Defogger. Alongside this, Pressure bleeds the PP of opposing hazard removers such as Salamence and Mandibuzz, which helps its teammates' hazards stay up, enables Spikes semi-stall playstyles, and lets Articuno dominate hazard control against opposing defensive teams. Heal Bell provides more crucial utility, and it works amazingly with Pressure, allowing Articuno to beat Toxic users such as Hippowdon one-on-one. Further still, Articuno is a crucial secondary check to Pokemon like Primarina, Salamence, Gyarados, and even Azelf against teams that use a Stealth Rock setter it counters, such as Hippowdon, Chansey, or Registeel. However, Articuno struggles with some other hazard setters in Nihilego, Cobalion, and Spikes + Iron Defense Skarmory. Its Stealth Rock weakness also makes it an unreliable Defogger against the more common Taunt variants of Stealth Rock Krookodile, given Knock Off and Articuno's reliance on Heavy-Duty Boots, although Krookodile still fears Freeze-Dry when using Taunt. Without a second hazard remover such as Flygon alongside Articuno, Spikes teams often rely on using the overwhelming threat of their own hazards to win the hazards war, forcing the opponent to remove these hazards instead of setting their own. Due to its typing, Articuno can also be exploited or set up on by threats like Scizor, Cobalion, and Nihilego, which only fear a freeze from repeated Freeze-Dry usage, mandating solid defensive support.
Articuno.comments:
Other Options

Haze is an option to check Pokemon such as Calm Mind + Rest Primarina and Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro, but Articuno can struggle to fit it over Heal Bell, which is required to beat Hippowdon. Articuno can be run on VoltTurn teams with U-turn over Heal Bell, letting it maintain momentum and generate switch-in opportunities for threats such as Diggersby and Chandelure while Defogging for them. Articuno also provides these teams a key switch-in to Primarina, which they struggle to fit when using Zarude as their Grass-type. Articuno can optionally run Heal Bell instead of U-turn on these structures to reliably Defog against Hippowdon and support teammates such as Scizor, letting it be more aggressive with switching into Slowking's Scald and attacking Moltres, but losing U-turn leaves Articuno much more passive.

Checks and Counters

Steel-types: Due to its low power and lack of coverage, Articuno can be setup fodder for Steel-types such as Scizor and Cobalion. In addition to this, Steel-types such as Cobalion, Excadrill, and Jirachi are Stealth Rock setters Articuno cannot beat. Celesteela takes little damage from Freeze-Dry despite not resisting it and can pressure Articuno heavily, and Iron Defense Skarmory can boost up against and beat Articuno to keep Spikes up. Skarmory must, however, be wary of Freeze-Dry damage due to its poor Special Defense, and non-Iron Defense variants are unable to keep Spikes up versus Articuno, since they can't threaten it enough with Body Press.

Nihilego: Nihilego can shrug off any damage Articuno can throw at it with its massive special bulk, reliably keeping Stealth Rock up against it, while forcing Articuno out with its Rock-type STAB moves. Nihilego can use the multiple free turns Articuno gives it to either debilitate key teammates with Knock Off + coverage or set up with Meteor Beam.

Knock Off and Stealth Rock: Articuno's 4x weakness to Stealth Rock leaves it uncomfortable against Krookodile, which can remove its Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off and potentially stop it from Defogging with Taunt and good prediction, but it must be wary of Freeze-Dry. Pokemon like Azelf and Tangrowth that Articuno can usually check are able to force it out with Knock Off if they are paired with an entry hazard setter that Articuno's team cannot beat.

Electric-types: Thundurus-T cannot switch into Articuno safely, given its Ice weakness, but can threaten Articuno with its Electric-type moves and Knock Off. Raikou also pressures Articuno with Thunderbolt. Rotom-H can shrug off anything Articuno can throw at it, but it can't directly harm Articuno without Nasty Plot due to its low Special Attack.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Freeze-Dry lets Articuno threaten Pokemon such as Primarina, Amoonguss, and Zarude. Its 10% freeze chance is low at face value, but adds up over a long game versus threats like Scizor, which commonly switch into it, due to its high PP. Defog alongside Pressure lets Articuno beat entry hazard setters like Hippowdon and Chansey one-on-one, and even against teams with other setters, its defensive profile lets it Defog on Pokemon like Primarina and Amoonguss. With Heal Bell and Pressure, Articuno can safely PP stall any one Pokemon's Toxic while offering key cleric support to teammates, opening up superior move options on teammates such as Toxic on Umbreon and Stealth Rock on Chansey. 56 Speed EVs let Articuno outspeed Choice Specs Primarina, and high Special Defense investment with a Calm nature helps it check Pokemon such as Primarina and Salamence. Articuno can opt to run 204 Defense EVs instead with a Bold nature to improve its matchup versus Dragon Dance Gyarados and Salamence, but this should only be done on teams without Umbreon to handle them, as it lowers Articuno's ability to switch into Defog Salamence as reliably.

Articuno fits primarily on semi-stall and stall teams that appreciate a Defogger that beats Hippowdon solo while compressing Heal Bell support. Skarmory is a fantastic fit alongside it, checking Pokemon such as Conkeldurr and Swords Dance Scizor with Iron Defense. Skarmory values Articuno letting it run Spikes over Defog, as well as bleeding the PP of Defog users such as Salamence and Mandibuzz, helping its Spikes stay up more easily. Defensive wallbreakers such as Taunt Jellicent, Hex Chandelure, and Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro appreciate Articuno enabling Spikes Skarmory, helping them break through opposing teams. Jellicent, in particular, provides key defensive value as a check to threats such as Keldeo, Cobalion, and Scizor, and it appreciates Articuno clearing it of status it may pick up from Pokemon like Skarmory and Amoonguss, while Galarian Slowbro can double up as a late-game wincon and appreciates Articuno checking Hippowdon. On full stall teams, secondary Defog users such as Skarmory and Flygon cover entry hazard setters Articuno cannot beat. Iron Defense Skarmory can help beat Excadrill and opposing Skarmory, while Flygon can counter Nihilego and beat pivot Thundurus-T and opposing Skarmory. Primary special walls such as Umbreon and Chansey are important to check threats such as Moltres and Chandelure and not have Articuno overwhelmed by Salamence and Primarina. Umbreon can offer Wish support to Articuno and check threats such as Swords Dance + Knock Off Scizor, while Chansey can provide a Stealth Rock setter. Ground-types such as Hippowdon and Quagsire can check Pokemon such as non-Grass Knot Thundurus-T and Nihilego, and Rotom-H for Articuno. Hippowdon can also provide Stealth Rock support and a Hatterene answer with its Rocky Helmet sets, while Quagsire can reliably counter Pokemon like Swords Dance Cobalion and Scizor and Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro.

Moltres.overview: Moltres stands out as a solid offensive pivot thanks to U-turn complementing its good STAB combination and its ability to check tier staples like Scizor, Amoonguss, Skarmory, and Excadrill. Flame Body makes Moltres great at punishing the many U-turn users of the tier, including Scizor, Crobat, Zarude, and Diggersby. Moltres can also function as a solid support Pokemon with its Mystical Fire + Toxic set, wearing down Pokemon like Slowking, Hippowdon, and Rotom-W to support teammates like Mamoswine. Heavy-Duty Boots greatly improves Moltres's efficiency at its roles, but it is extremely reliant on them, making it very susceptible to Knock Off from Pokemon it would normally check like Mamoswine, Tangrowth, and especially Scizor. Teams with Moltres often have to run entry hazard removal so that Moltres can properly check these threats. Moltres can also be taken advanatage of by pivots it checks like Scizor, Crobat, and Diggersby to bring in threats like Nihilego, Primarina, and Keldeo if it does not proc the Flame Body burn. Salamence gives Moltres heavy competition because of its better typing, Intimidate, and greater resilience to Knock Off.
Moltres.comments:
Other Options

Moltres can run Defog for role compression thanks to it matching up well against entry hazard setters like Excadrill and Skarmory, but it suffers from poor matchups against other common setters like Nihilego, Hippowdon, and Chansey. Dropping U-turn severely limits Moltres's offensive potential as well. A Substitute + Toxic set with an EV spread of 152 HP / 132 SpD / 224 Spe, a Timid nature, and Pressure can be used to cripple and PP stall many of Moltres's counters, such as Hippowdon, Rotom-H, and Rotom-W, but it makes Moltres very passive in general. Scorching Sands threatens Nihilego for massive damage, but that's it.

Checks and Counters

Knock Off and Stealth Rock: Moltres becomes extremely vulnerable to Stealth Rock upon losing its Heavy-Duty Boots. Pokemon that usually lose to Moltres, such as Scizor, Tangrowth, and Conkeldurr, can take advantage of this by using Knock Off against Moltres as it switches in. The former two do fear getting burned by Flame Body, however.

Rock-types and Rock-type Coverage: Nihilego and Rhyperior can easily tank Moltres's STAB moves and blow it away with massive damage, though the latter does have to be wary of Toxic. Lycanroc-D outspeeds and OHKOes Moltres with Stone Edge. Cobalion, a Pokemon that Moltres is supposed to check, often carries Stone Edge, making it hard for Moltres to switch into. Pokemon that Moltres can normally check, such as Excadrill and Tapu Bulu, may sometimes carry Rock-type coverage moves, forcing Moltres to scout these attacks.

Electric-types: Rotom-W, Rotom-H, Raikou, and Thundurus-T can easily take advantage of Moltres with Volt Switch. The former two are especially good counters thanks to resisting Fire.

Water-types: Primarina, Swampert, and Slowking can tank Moltres's attacks and deal big damage back with their STAB attacks, though the latter two do not like Toxic. Keldeo can outspeed Moltres and OHKO it with Hydro Pump, but it cannot switch into Moltres safely. Gyarados can take a Hurricane and use Moltres as setup fodder.

Specially Defensive Walls: Hippowdon, Umbreon, and Chansey easily tank Moltres's STAB attacks and have reliable recovery; however, Hippowdon greatly dislikes Toxic, and Moltres can easily take advantage of Umbreon and Chansey via U-turn.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Flamethrower and Hurricane serve as strong neutral coverage, with the latter being able to hit Fire-resistant foes like Primarina, Keldeo, and Slowking for big damage. U-turn allows Moltres to pivot against threatening Pokemon like Slowking, Nihilego, and Chansey while bringing in wallbreakers like Zygarde-10% and Keldeo. Roost gives Moltres the longevity necessary to check Zarude, Scizor, and Celesteela. Flame Body punishes U-turn users like Scizor, Zarude and Diggersby.

Moltres works best on bulky offense, balance, and VoltTurn teams that appreciate its ability to punish Pokemon like Excadrill and Zarude while providing momentum against foes like Hippowdon. Knock Off absorbers, such as Cobalion and Amoonguss, are key in helping alleviate Moltres's biggest concern when facing foes like Scizor. Cobalion is a particularly good partner for Moltres, as it acts as a secondary check to Scizor, potentially forms a VoltTurn core with it, and checks Nihilego and Chansey. Toxic Cobalion luring in Hippowdon creates opportunities for Moltres to get past it. Zarude, Swampert, and Slowking deal with Pokemon like Hippowdon and Keldeo for Moltres while also forming momentum cores with it. Scizor also creates a momentum core and pressures Moltres checks like Chansey, Slowking, and Nihilego. Amoonguss, Tangrowth, and the aforementioned Zarude take on threatening Water- and Electric-types like Primarina, Keldeo, Rotom-W, and Thundurus-T for Moltres. Entry hazard support from Pokemon such as Hippowdon and Nihilego is useful for helping Moltres break through Slowking. These Pokemon can also check Thundurus-T and Rotom-H. Physical wallbreakers, such as Zygarde-10% and Conkeldurr, can break through special walls like Chansey and overwhelm shared checks like Slowking. Zygarde-10% also revenge kills faster threats such as Nihilego and Rotom-W.

sets.name: Support
sets.description:
Mystical Fire weakens switch-ins to Moltres such as Nihilego, Hydreigon and Primarina. Toxic cripples Slowking, Hippowdon, and Rotom-W. U-turn creates momentum for teammates like Mamoswine. 252 HP EVs allow Moltres to sponge hits from Zarude and Scizor more easily.

Moltres works well on balance teams that appreciate its ability to cripple Hippowdon and Slowking with Toxic and offensively check Scizor and Zarude. Walls such as Hippowdon and Assault Vest Tangrowth can switch into Pokemon like Nihilego, Hydreigon, and Primarina, which is made easier thanks to Moltres's Mystical Fire. These Pokemon also check threats like Zygarde-10% and Cobalion, and the former can set up Stealth Rock to wear down Pokemon like Rotom-W and Slowking. Wallbreakers like Mamoswine and Zygarde-10% greatly appreciate threats like Rotom-W, Slowking, and Hippowdon being crippled by Toxic, which helps them overwhelm bulkier teams. In return, Moltres can provide switch-in opportunities with U-turn and check Scizor. Fairy-types, like Primarina, Hatterene, and Togekiss, can help take care of Dragon-types like Hydreigon and Salamence. In return, Moltres can check threats like Zarude and Scizor.

Crobat.overview: Crobat acts as a fast offensive pivot thanks to its incredible natural Speed, allowing it to outspeed fast offensive Pokemon like Azelf, Zygarde-10%, Keldeo, and Noivern. Crobat can make use of its high Speed and offensive pivoting with STAB Brave Bird and U-turn to outlast checks such as Nihilego and Rotom-W, making it threatening to many common team styles. Taunt prevents would-be checks like Salamence, Skarmory, Hippowdon, and Chansey from recovering while also preventing the latter two and Amoonguss from using status moves. While Crobat's Poison / Flying typing allows it to switch in on Grass- and Fighting-type attacks from Pokemon like Zarude, Amoonguss, and Conkeldurr, it must beware switching directly into a status move like Stun Spore or Spore from Amoonguss, or strong attacks like Darkest Lariat from Zarude and Knock Off and Facade from Conkeldurr. Furthermore, Crobat's average bulk makes it struggle to switch in on strong attacks from offensive Pokemon like Hydreigon, Azelf, and Zygarde-10%. Crobat's lack of relevant resistances also makes it fear moves from Pokemon it would otherwise check, such as Facade from Conkeldurr and Hydro Pump from Keldeo. Lastly, Crobat is dependent on Heavy-Duty Boots to be effective, forcing it to play carefully against Knock Off users like Diggersby and Scizor. This flaw also forces Crobat to think twice about switching into Knock Off users it would otherwise counter like Tangrowth.
Crobat.comments:
Other Options

Inflitrator can be used instead of Inner Focus to allow Crobat to bypass Substitute, preventing Pokemon like SubCM Keldeo and Primarina from getting a safe hit on Crobat from behind a Substitute. Defog can be used over Taunt to make Crobat an entry hazard remover. However, foregoing Taunt limits Crobat's offensive potency and stops it from keeping Stealth Rock off the field against some common setters, like Cobalion, Hippowdon, and Nihilego. Hypnosis can be used in the final moveslot to cripple switch-ins, although it suffers from low accuracy and opportunity cost in not using the more reliable Taunt. A set of Nasty Plot, Sludge Bomb, Heat Wave, and Roost can be used to break through Crobat's usual Steel-type checks, and it provides excellent Fire / Poison coverage against most of the UU tier. This set is particularly effective against bulkier teams due to the aforementioned coverage, Crobat's reliable recovery, and its Toxic immunity. However, this set can be hard to justify over Crobat's usual utility. In addition, Crobat's base Special Attack is low, so this set usually requires multiple Nasty Plot uses to break through its targets. Finally, Super Fang could be used over U-turn and alongside Taunt to weaken sturdy Crobat checks like Celesteela for its teammates. This turns Crobat into a dangerous stallbreaker.

Checks and Counters

Steel-types: Steel-types like Celesteela, Skarmory, and Jirachi take very little damage from Brave Bird and can hinder Crobat. Skarmory can lose one-on-one against Crobat due to Taunt preventing it from healing with Roost, but it would still damage Crobat significantly in the process, especially if Skarmory is holding a Rocky Helmet. Cobalion does not resist Brave Bird, but it's never 2HKOed thanks to its great physical bulk, and it can threaten Crobat with Stone Edge or Volt Switch and chip it with Rocky Helmet as well. Scizor also does not resist Brave Bird and does not like switching into it, but it can revenge kill a weakened Crobat with Bullet Punch.

Knock Off: Crobat's reliance on Heavy-Duty Boots makes Knock Off a giant threat to its longevity, making it dangerous to switch into Pokemon like Tangrowth and Krookodile, which would otherwise be less threatening.

Electric-types: Electric-types like Raikou, Thundurus-T, Rotom-W, and Rotom-H resist Crobat's Brave Bird and threaten heavy damage or OHKOs on it. They can be worn down over time with repeated hits, however, and are not safe switch-ins at low HP.

Rock-types: Rock-types like Nihilego, Lycanroc-D, and Rhyperior resist Brave Bird and threaten heavy damage on Crobat. Rhyperior in particular stonewalls Crobat. While Lycanroc-D and especially Nihilego take more damage from Brave Bird and must be more careful about switching into Crobat, they can survive a hit from it and revenge kill in return. Lycanroc-D also has priority Accelerock to prevent Crobat from hitting it first.

Physically Defensive Pokemon: Hippowdon and Swampert can take repeated hits from Crobat without fearing a KO. Swampert can use Flip Turn to pivot into a Pokemon that can threaten Crobat, while Hippowdon mandates Taunt use with Slack Off and forces sand chip damage. Both can also hit Crobat with a super effective Earthquake if it is forced to use Roost, and Hippowdon can potentially punish Brave Bird and U-turn with Rocky Helmet. Hippowdon will usually fail to beat Taunt Crobat one-on-one, but Rocky Helmet and sand can significantly chip Crobat in the process. Slowking can also comfortably take a Brave Bird and threaten heavy damage with Psychic.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description:
Brave Bird allows Crobat to maintain offensive presence with a strong STAB attack, threatening heavy damage on fast, frail offensive Pokemon like Azelf, Zygarde-10%, and Keldeo. U-turn lets Crobat escape Pokemon it cannot meaningfully damage, like Jirachi and Celesteela. U-turn also wears down switch-ins and offensive checks like Rotom-W, Thundurus-T, Raikou, and Nihilego, allowing Crobat to beat them long-term. Roost keeps Crobat healthy, allowing it to last in long games, beat bulky threats like defensive Salamence and Chansey one-on-one, and utilize its typing to switch into Zarude. Roost can also be used to remove Crobat's Flying typing for a turn, reducing its damage from moves like Volt Switch from Rotom-W and Rotom-H and Stone Edge from Cobalion. Roost also helps compensate for the recoil damage Crobat takes from using Brave Bird. Taunt lets Crobat shut down status moves from Pokemon like Amoonguss and Chansey, as well as healing attempts from Pokemon like Salamence and Skarmory. Even if Crobat itself does not fear Toxic from Pokemon like Chansey and Hippowdon, its teammates may appreciate Taunt shutting down the threat of Toxic after they switch in. Taunt can also prevent Defog attempts from Pokemon like Salamence and Mandibuzz. Inner Focus is the preferred ability, as it prevents Salamence from lowering Crobat's Attack with Intimidate upon switch-in, and it additionally makes Crobat immune to flinches from attacks like Choice Scarf Hydreigon's Dark Pulse and +1 Speed Jolly Gyarados's Waterfall. Maximum Speed investment and Jolly are necessary to keep Adamant Dragon Dance Gyarados and Adamant Choice Scarf Diggersby in check.

Crobat pairs well with other pivots like Zarude, Thundurus-T, Rotom-H, and Rotom-W to keep momentum up. These can also bring Crobat in safely against targets like Amoonguss, reducing Crobat's need to use Roost often. Rotom-H and Rotom-W make particularly good partners, as Crobat appreciates them checking Mamoswine and Steel-types like Scizor and Celesteela. Ground-type teammates like Hippowdon and Excadrill absorb Electric- and Rock-type moves aimed at Crobat from Pokemon like Rotom-H and Nihilego, respectively. Knock Off absorbers like Amoonguss and Tangrowth prevent Crobat from losing its Heavy-Duty Boots. Amoonguss and Tangrowth can also check Electric-types like Thundurus-T and Raikou for Crobat. Wallbreakers like Choice Specs Hydreigon and Keldeo pair well with Crobat, as Crobat can bring them in against Pokemon like Rotom-W and Celesteela with U-turn.

Azumarill.overview: Azumarill is an offensive powerhouse and effective wallbreaker when equipped with a Choice Band due to Huge Power, being able to nearly 2HKO the entire tier with the right move. It can also utilize a Belly Drum set to be a scary late-game cleaner. Water / Fairy is a great offensive typing, allowing Azumarill to beat key threats like Excadrill and Hydreigon. Access to great coverage moves such as Knock Off and Ice Punch lets Azumarill break past Pokemon like Tentacruel and Amoonguss that would otherwise check it by resisting its STAB combination, while Aqua Jet allows it to also be a great revenge killer against top threats like Zygarde-10% and Azelf that have taken chip damage. Azumarill also has decent natural bulk and a great defensive typing, which allows it to blanket check threats such as Hydreigon and Salamence. Unfortunately, Azumarill is quite slow, so it is easily forced out by faster Pokemon such as Tentacruel and Thundurus-T when it is not boosted with Belly Drum. Additionally, Rotom-W and faster Grass-types like Tapu Bulu and Zarude can revenge kill Belly Drum Azumarill, as they can stomach a +6 Aqua Jet. This gives Azumarill limited opportunities to fire off an attack due to its only decent bulk. Belly Drum Azumarill is restricted to only getting one setup opportunity, which usually forces it to be preserved until late-game. Azumarill faces large competition from Primarina as it offers more defensive utility with its bulk and doesn't have to deal with Rocky Helmet damage from physical walls like Skarmory and Amoonguss.
Azumarill.comments:
Other Options

An Assault Vest set can help Azumarill more comfortably switch into Keldeo, Salamence, and Hydreigon and KO them back. Azumarill can run a trapping set with Sap Sipper and Whirlpool, Perish Song, and Protect. This can trap passive foes like Celesteela as well as Grass-types like Tapu Bulu and Tangrowth, but the effectiveness of this set is purely restricted to punishing walls and is deadweight against a majority of the offensive threats in UU. Protective Pads lets Azumarill not worry about being chipped by Rocky Helmet from Skarmory and Amoonguss, but its wallbreaking prowess is significantly hindered.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Faster Grass-types like Zarude and Tapu Bulu are the biggest threats to Azumarill because even a Belly Drum Azumarill cannot OHKO them with Aqua Jet and they OHKO back. Defensive Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth can usually switch into Choice Band Azumarill and threaten it with their own STAB moves as well as scout and switch out with Regenerator.

Electric-types: An unboosted Azumarill is easy prey for Thundurus-T and Raikou. Without being at +6, Azumarill cannot come close to KOing them with Aqua Jet, and both will in turn OHKO Azumarill. Rotom-W resists Aqua Jet and can also outspeed and cripple Azumarill with Will-O-Wisp or pressure it with an Electric-type attack.

Faster Water-resistant Pokemon: Anything faster that resists Aqua Jet is bound to pressure Azumarill. These Pokemon include Gyarados, Tentacruel, and Rotom-W. Salamence can also pressure Azumarill, but it is also pressured by Azumarill with Play Rough, so Azumarill would have to be significantly chipped for Salamence to KO it.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Liquidation lets Azumarill muscle past Hippowdon, Celesteela, and Chansey. Play Rough is Azumarill's main attack to remove foes like Zarude, Primarina, and Slowking. Aqua Jet becomes a very powerful STAB priority move when bolstered by Huge Power and a Choice Band, allowing it to OHKO Nihilego and revenge kill Thundurus-T and Rotom-H after they have taken sufficient chip damage. Ice Punch allows Azumarill to break through Amoonguss by 2HKOing it on the switch. It also hits Tangrowth hard. Knock Off can be used to burden anything that switches in, such as Tangrowth and Tentacruel, by removing their item. A Choice Band allows Azumarill to maximize the wallbreaking potential its STAB attacks have to offer. Adamant is the preferred nature to make it as strong as possible, notably 2HKOing Skarmory with Liquidation after Stealth Rock.

Choice Band Azumarill fits best on bulky offense teams as a powerful early-game wallbreaker. Pivots like Thundurus-T and Scizor can bring Azumarill in against their checks like Nihilego and Moltres to fire off an attack. Nidoking, Moltres, and Salamence can remove bulky Grass-types like Amoonguss, Tangrowth, and Tapu Bulu for Azumarill to fire off its STAB attacks easier. Keeping entry hazards up is important to ease Azumarill's ability to break through Tangrowth and Skarmory, so partners such as Excadrill and Nihilego are essential. The former provides entry hazard removal to keep Azumarill from getting worn down while the latter offensively checks Thundurus-T. Tapu Bulu and Zarude threaten to revenge kill Azumarill, as they are faster and resist Aqua Jet, so partners like Salamence and Amoonguss that can comfortably switch into them are ideal. Having a good Electric-immune teammate, such as Swampert or Hippowdon, helps deal with Electric-types like Rotom-W and Thundurus-T.

sets.name: Belly Drum
sets.description:
