A +6 Aqua Jet will KO almost anything that doesn't resist it, so it is very hard for anything to revenge kill Azumarill. Play Rough pressures slower threats like Slowking and RestTalk Primarina after a boost, as it can OHKO anything that does not resist it, including a fully defensive Tangrowth. A boosted Knock Off will OHKO Amoonguss and defensive Celesteela. Sitrus Berry allows Azumarill to set up more reliably and puts it at a comfortable amount of HP after a Belly Drum. 4 HP is needed to activate Sitrus Berry after Belly Drum. Adamant is the preferred nature to guarantee an OHKO on Amoonguss with Knock Off.

Belly Drum Azumarill fits best on hyper offense teams due to its nature as a late-game cleaner and need for dedicated support. Krookodile and Excadrill provide entry hazard support to put threats like Tentacruel and Skarmory in range of Azumarill's attacks while also providing an Electric immunity. Similarly, Ribombee can provide Sticky Web support to offset Azumarill's vulnerable Speed tier, allowing it to now outpace Tentacruel and Tapu Bulu. Once Azumarill is boosted with Belly Drum, it typically will not get another chance to do so, so removing faster Water-type resists is key. Good offensive teammates include Salamence and Gyarados to help take out foes like Zarude and Keldeo. Thundurus-T pressures Skarmory, Scizor, and Mandibuzz for Azumarill and provides a valuable Electric immunity. Early-game sweepers like Scizor and Azelf can pave the way for an Azumarill sweep by removing threats to Azumarill like Tangrowth and Keldeo.

Quagsire.overview: Quagsire possesses a unique niche in the UU metagame with its ability in Unaware, which lets it stop setup sweepers such as Nasty Plot Thundurus-T, Swords Dance Scizor, and Dragon Dance Salamence in their tracks. A Water / Ground typing allows Quagsire to act as a Volt Switch absorber while also checking Pokemon such as Rotom-H and Lycanroc-D. As such, these attributes make Quagsire a staple on stall teams. However, Quagsire's 4x weakness to Grass makes it unable to check Pokemon such as Nihilego, Gyarados and pivot Thundurus-T, as they commonly carry Grass-type coverage. Quagsire's bulk only goes so far, as very strong wallbreakers such as Crawdaunt and Azumarill can break through it with minimal effort. Finally, Quagsire's poor special bulk leaves it unable to take on special attackers well, leaving it vulnerable to Pokemon such as Keldeo.
Quagsire.comments:
Other Options

A Curse set turns Quagsire into a bulky sweeper, but it will need many boosts before it can cause serious damage and is even more vulnerable to Grass-types. Additionally, it must drop Scald from its moveset, making Quagsire much more passive.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types and Grass-type Moves: Grass-types like Zarude, Amoonguss, and Tangrowth resist any attack Quagsire throws at them and proceed to force it out, with the former two being able to bypass Toxic through Jungle Healing or its typing. Pokemon that can lure in Quagsire and KO it with a coverage move, such as Gyarados, Azelf, and Nihilego, are also threats to Quagsire.

Strong Wallbreakers: Quagsire's bulk is only decent; extremely strong attacks coming from the likes of Conkeldurr, Keldeo, Diggersby, and Necrozma will easily overwhelm it.

Residual Damage: Status such as Toxic and burn hinder Quagsire, as it has to use Recover more often. Chip damage from Spikes can also wear down Quagsire for wallbreakers like Keldeo to KO it more easily.

sets.name: Unaware Wall
sets.description:
Scald has a good chance to burn threats such as Scizor and Tapu Bulu. Earthquake hits Pokemon such as Raikou, Jirachi, and Nihilego. Toxic cripples Pokemon attemping to set up on Quagsire like Thundurus-T as well as defensive walls like Slowking and Tangrowth. Haze is an option to stop setup sweepers such as Galarian Slowbro and Celesteela in their tracks. Heavy-Duty Boots is an option to avoid damage from Spikes and Toxic Spikes; however, Quagsire is already resistant to Stealth Rock, and the passive recovery brought by Leftovers is generally much more appreciated. The given EV spread allows Quagsire to take on special attackers such as Rotom-W more comfortably while maximizing its physical bulk.

Quagsire fits best on stall teams, stopping setup sweepers with Unaware. Amoonguss and Tangrowth are excellent partners for Quagsire, as they check Grass-types such as Tapu Bulu and Zarude. Additionally, these Pokemon are able to check wallbreakers that Quagsire struggles with, such as Conkeldurr and Keldeo. Chansey forms a solid defensive core with Quagsire, being able to check special attackers such as Nihilego and Thundurus-T, while Quagsire checks physical threats for it in return. Chansey's Heal Bell also allows it to cure status that easily wear down Quagsire. Umbreon can provide Wish support and counter Gyarados for Quagsire. Salamence can help provide Defog support to remove Spikes for Quagsire. Ditto can provide offensive support and deter wallbreakers like Diggersby and Crawdaunt that Quagsire can't deal with properly.

Umbreon.overview: Umbreon's stellar mixed bulk and Dark typing make it a strong pick on defensive teams, checking threats like Excadrill, Gyarados, Salamence, and Swords Dance + Knock Off Scizor. It provides fantastic team utility as a Wish passer, getting plenty of opportunities to heal up its teammates versus Pokemon like Azelf and Salamence. While unable to pressure some defensive Pokemon such as Amoonguss, Celesteela, and Teleport Chansey at all, Umbreon can freely use them to pass Wish, and Foul Play + Toxic greatly punishes many offensive checks switching in and prevents Umbreon from being too passive. However, it can offer a lot of opportunities to dangerous Fairy- and Fighting-types like Primarina, Cobalion, and Conkeldurr that can greatly threaten bulkier teams. Umbreon also struggles versus some of the stronger special attackers in the tier like Thundurus-T and Meteor Beam Nihilego, and chip damage can bring it into 2HKO range of Pokemon it checks like Mamoswine and Nidoking.
Umbreon.comments:
Other Options

A Calm nature is an option to prevent Nidoking from 2HKOing Umbreon after Stealth Rock. This, however, makes Umbreon unable to check Mamoswine and more damaged by Pokemon like Excadrill and Dragon Dance Gyarados. Heal Bell is an option that lets Umbreon clear status from itself and its teammates. However, dropping Toxic for it makes Umbreon noticeably more passive and invites offensive Pokemon in, giving it far fewer opportunities to safely pass Wish. Therefore, it should only be used on teams with absolutely no better options against status.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: Fighting-types like Cobalion, Keldeo, and Conkeldurr are some of the biggest threats to Umbreon. Conkeldurr can be deterred by Umbreon stalling for burn damage, but Drain Punch variants can easily regain their HP versus Umbreon's teammates, forming a long-term threat. Cobalion's Toxic immunity and ability in Justified let it safely switch into Umbreon as well.

Fairy-types: Defensive Primarina variants can easily wall Umbreon and sponge Toxic while pressuring its teammates. For non-defensive sets, Umbreon can outspeed and poison Substitute + Calm Mind variants or scout Choice Specs variants, but the former sets up for free if not immediately poisoned, and the latter poses a serious threat to Umbreon's teammates. Hatterene can easily set up on Umbreon, bouncing back Toxic. While Togekiss cannot beat Umbreon without Heal Bell due to Inner Focus, Heal Bell + Nasty Plot variants can set up provided they have enough Heal Bell PP remaining.

Dark-types: Crawdaunt is a huge threat to Umbreon thanks to its titanic damage output and resistance to Foul Play. Zarude's resistance to Foul Play and ability to sponge Toxic with Jungle Healing make it a great pivot into Umbreon; however, it cannot easily beat Umbreon itself unless Umbreon has wasted a lot of PP, and Zarude must be careful to not waste too much Jungle Healing PP if it needs check a teammate like Slowking. Choice Specs Hydreigon can easily overwhelm Umbreon if it switches into Draco Meteor.

Chip Damage: Pokemon such as Mamoswine and Nidoking can easily get the edge versus Umbreon if it has been chipped by entry hazards, lost its Leftovers to Knock Off from a Pokemon like Nihilego or Mamoswine itself, or statused. While Umbreon still avoids being 2HKOed by Life Orb Mamoswine without its Leftovers, Stealth Rock makes the 2HKO decently likely. Modest Nidoking can 2HKO Bold Umbreon with Stealth Rock up, forcing it to waste passive turns on Protect, which can be easily predicted.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description:
Foul Play lets Umbreon do considerable damage to physical attackers, being particularly key to checking Dragon Dance users like Gyarados and Salamence. Toxic lets Umbreon punish special attackers like Salamence and Moltres for using Roost against it and most of the broader metagame effectively. Wish alongside Protect keeps Umbreon and its teammates healthy. Protect is also useful to scout Choice-locked Pokemon, like Primarina and Keldeo, and absorb attacks from Pokemon like Cobalion and Conkeldurr paired with Future Sight from Slowking. Inner Focus lets Umbreon avoid flinches from Pokemon it checks, like Mamoswine, Gyarados, and Jirachi, and check non-Heal Bell variants of Togekiss. Maximum Defense investment with a Bold nature lets Umbreon avoid the 2HKO from Mamoswine's Earthquake after Stealth Rock while improving its matchup versus Pokemon like Excadrill.

Umbreon predominantly fits on balance, semi-stall, and stall teams as a fantastic check to threatening Pokemon like Azelf and Gyarados, as well as key team support through Wish. Hippowdon and Skarmory can check threats like Conkeldurr and Tapu Bulu for Umbreon. Skarmory can also provide an additional Excadrill check, Spikes support, and an Azumarill check. Slowking can check Keldeo and Primarina for Umbreon, while Umbreon checks Zarude and Hydreigon for it. Cleric support is vital, as Umbreon gets easily statused by Pokemon it checks like Hippowdon. Togekiss is a great option that can help check Hydreigon and provide an extra wincon with Nasty Plot versus the bulkier teams Umbreon struggles to make progress against, as well as checking Conkeldurr. Chansey is another fantastic option that can counter Primarina, Hydreigon, and Nidoking, while Articuno can also provide simultaneous Heal Bell and Defog support alongside Pressure, beating and PP stalling entry hazard setters like Hippowdon and Skarmory. Quagsire is a superb teammate on stall teams, dealing with Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro, Belly Drum Azumarill, and Nasty Plot Thundurus-T. Nihilego can check Hydreigon and Thundurus-T for Umbreon while providing Stealth Rock and Knock Off support against Pokemon like Excadrill and Scizor.

Slowking.overview: Slowking's useful resistances, excellent ability in Regenerator, and superb natural bulk make it one of the best defensive pivots in the metagame. These traits, combined with Teleport, allow Slowking to consistently force progress against many teams by allowing wallbreakers such as Thundurus-T and Zygarde-10% to enter the field safely. Due to its incredible bulk and typing, Slowking can easily come in on threats like Keldeo, Cobalion, Celesteela, Excadrill, and Nihilego and then pivot to a revenge killer with Teleport. However, as a result of its somewhat below average physical defense, Slowking is unable to consistently wall strong physical attackers such as Conkeldurr and Swords Dance Excadrill. Slowking also gets forced out by threats such as Zarude, Hydreigon, and Thundurus-T quite easily due to its initial passivity and can get overwhelmed by status from Pokemon it checks like Toxic from Moltres and Sludge Bomb poisons from Nihilego. Slowking's typing also holds it back, as it is weak to U-turn as well as Knock Off. Slowking competes with Chansey for the role of a defensive pivot, as Chansey isn't weak to foes such as Hydreigon. Slowking also competes with Primarina, which has a better defensive typing and a better matchup against Hydreigon.
Slowking.comments:
Other Options

Slowking can opt to run Trick over Teleport while running a Choice Scarf in order to cripple would be switch-ins like Zarude. Counter is another option over Teleport that can punish Pokemon like Zarude and reflect damage from U-turn users. Thunder Wave cripples common answers such as Hydreigon as well as Meteor Beam Celesteela while still punishing Keldeo. However, running it instead of Psyshic STAB leaves Slowking vulnerable to Primarina and Conkeldurr. Running Thunder Wave over Teleport is also fine, as long as the team has enough pivot support. This can open some doors for teammates like Conkeldurr and SubToxic Jirachi, as Conkeldurr is faster than paralyzed Hydreigon and Zarude, and Jirachi outspeeds revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Hydreigon and Choice Scarf Zarude if they are paralyzed. A Trick Room + Teleport Slowking set can be used as a teammate for slow wallbreakers like Alolan Marowak and Conkeldurr on semi-Trick Room teams.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Dark-types such as Zarude and Hydreigon wall Slowking due to their Psychic immunity and Scald resistance. Zarude is an especially good answer to Slowking, as it can heal off Scald burns via Jungle Healing.

Grass-types: Tapu Bulu and Tangrowth threaten Slowking immensely with their supereffective attacks. In particular, Tapu Bulu can OHKO Slowking or use it as setup fodder, but it should be wary of Scald. Amoonguss threatens Slowking with Spore and Sludge Bomb poisons, but it can be worn down by Psychic if it is not running Synthesis.

Electric-types and Electric-type Coverage: Electric-types like Thundurus-T and Raikou heavily pressure and force out Slowking. Electric-type coverage like Thunderbolt on Starmie and Thunder on Reuniclus keep Slowking from switching into them.

Status: Status forces Slowking to use Slack Off more often. Chansey is difficult for Slowking to overcome, as it can cripple Slowking with Toxic and shrug off Scald burns with Natural Cure. Slowking is also vulnerable to status from Pokemon it checks, such as Toxic poison from Excadrill and Moltres, Sludge Bomb poisons from Nihilego, and Scald burns from Primarina.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
Scald reduces Slowking's passivity, burning switch-ins like Hydreigon and Tangrowth. Psychic threatens foes such as Amoonguss as they switch in. Additionally, Psychic discourages Conkeldurr from staying in to use Knock Off. Future Sight can be used instead to support Slowking's wallbreaking teammates. In addition to being an excellent pivot move, Teleport works well with Future Sight to bring in an offensive teammate such as Conkeldurr to capitalize on Future Sight absorbers, which are mainly Dark-types. Psyshock can be used over Psychic or Future Sight to prevent Slowking from becoming setup fodder for Calm Mind + Substitute Primarina and Meteor Beam Nihilego, though it makes Slowking more vulnerable to Conkeldurr. Colbur Berry allows Slowking to avoid an OHKO from Conkeldurr's Knock Off, improve its matchup against Mamoswine, and give it the ability to pivot against Hydreigon with Teleport. However, Heavy-Duty Boots can instead be used to keep Slowking from getting worn down by Spikes and Stealth Rock. 0 Speed IVs let Slowking underspeed opposing Slowking and gain momentum with a slower Teleport. 56 Special Defense EVs with a Sassy nature improve Slowking's matchup against foes such as Primarina and Moltres; however, it should be noted that this worsens Slowking's matchup against Zygarde-10%.

Slowking fits best on bulky offense, VoltTurn, and balance teams that appreciate its ability to tank special attacks and pivot in strong wallbreakers. Frail wallbreakers such as Zygarde-10% and Thundurus-T appreciate Slowking's ability to safely pivot them onto the field via Teleport. These teammates also enjoy Future Sight pressuring Amoonguss and Nihilego. Slowking forms an excellent defensive core with Grass-types such as Amoonguss and Tangrowth, which appreciate its ability to switch into Fire-type attacks and check Poison-types such as Tentacruel. In return, they can come in on Grass- and Electric-types like Tapu Bulu, Zarude, and Thundurus-T that force out Slowking. Slowking forms a strong pivot core with Moltres, with Moltres pressuring Grass-types such as Tangrowth and Tapu Bulu and Slowking checking foes such as Keldeo. Slowking appreciates entry hazard control from teammates such as Excadrill, Mandibuzz, and Rotom-H. Skarmory is also a good teammate for Slowking, as it checks Zarude easily and helps against Mamoswine, Conkeldurr, and Scizor. Its Whirlwind also synergizes with Future Sight, heavily damaging shared checks like Thundurus-T or outright KOing Fighting-types. Hippowdon acts as a switch-in to Rotom-H, Raikou, and Choice Scarf Hydreigon for Slowking.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Calm Mind enables Slowking to become a dangerous offensive threat and set up on common Pokemon such as Nihilego and Moltres while retaining its longevity. After a boost, it is able to survive moves such as Dark Pulse from Choice Specs Hydreigon and stomach attacks such as Nidoking's Thunderbolt and Salamence’s Hurricane. Scald helps Slowking threaten switch-ins such as Hydreigon and enemy Slowking with burns. Psyshock helps against Chansey, opposing Slowking, Calm Mind Primarina, and Galarian Slowbro. Colbur Berry improves Slowking's matchup against Conkeldurr and Mamoswine, though it still has watch out for Facade from the former if it's below 66% HP.

Calm Mind Slowking fits best on balance, semi-stall, and stall teams as a wincon that maintains crucial defensive utility against Pokemon such as Mamoswine and Azelf. Nihilego and Chansey are useful Stealth Rock setters that check Thundurus-T and Hydreigon. Nihilego is more offensively potent and provides Knock Off support, whereas Chansey has more longevity and can also provide cleric support instead of setting Stealth Rock. However, while teams using Calm Mind Slowking want cleric support, keeping Slowking burned helps it set up in front of Chansey and Swampert without fear of Toxic. Quagsire provides an Electric immunity and checks Pokemon like Swords Dance Scizor and Belly Drum Azumarill.Defensive Salamence and Skarmory are great assets for their ability to answer Grass-types like Zarude and Zarude while providing Defog support. They also ensure that Slowking does not get overwhelmed by foes such as Conkeldurr and Swords Dance Excadrill. Umbreon provides additional insurance against Mamoswine and Energy Ball Azelf while having the option to provide Wish support. It also enjoys Slowking's ability to set up on threats such as Cobalion and Keldeo. Calm Mind Slowking can have problems against Teleport Slowking, which can bring in Pokemon that threaten it such as Hydreigon, so counters to Slowking like Zarude are great teammates.

Skarmory.overview: Skarmory is one of the key defensive pillars of UU thanks to its sky-high Defense, reliable recovery, and amazing defensive typing, checking dangerous offensive threats like Excadrill, Zarude, Scizor, and Gyarados with ease. Skarmory has a bevy of utility moves. Spikes wears down defensive threats like Hippowdon and Chansey for its team, and Skarmory can set Spikes easily thanks to its defensive utility and good matchup versus Excadrill. Furthermore, Whirlwind prevents Pokemon like Dragon Dance Gyarados and Swords Dance Scizor from setting up, while Iron Defense alongside Body Press allows Skarmory to improve its matchup versus threats like Azumarill, Swords Dance Scizor, and Conkeldurr. Skarmory can even run Defog on stall teams thanks to its great matchup against entry hazard setters like Excadrill and Hippowdon. These traits, in addition to its synergy with top defensive picks like Amoonguss, Slowking, and Chansey, allow Skarmory to fit on a wide range of archetypes ranging from bulky offense to stall. However, Skarmory has an extremely vulnerable Special Defense stat, making it a Steel-type that can't check specially offensive Fairy- and Psychic-types like Hatterene, so it faces competition from other Steel-types like Celesteela. Common threats like Thundurus-T, Rotom-W, and Moltres also limit Skarmory's consistency due to its passivity. Skarmory also often struggles to fit all the moves it likes at once. For example, it wants Iron Defense to be reliable in a 1v1 last Pokemon scenario versus Scizor, but it then becomes extremely passive and unable to punish Defog users such as Moltres and Salamence without Toxic.
Skarmory.comments:
Other Options

Skarmory can compress both Spikes and Defog on more defensive teams, acting as an emergency Defog option and opening up moveslots for other teammates. Skarmory can replace its attacking moveslot to fit both, or even other combinations of utility moves. It is still able to beat Excadrill as long as it keeps Rocky Helmet. However, these sets are very team specific. Skarmory can attempt to compress entry hazards by running both Spikes and Stealth Rock, but it struggles to fit Stealth Rock over more valuable options like Whirlwind or Toxic and pairs well with Stealth Rock setters like Nihilego anyway.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Common Electric-types like Thundurus-T, Rotom-W, and Rotom-H all are unbothered by Skarmory and can use it to gain momentum with Volt Switch. Thundurus-T can also boost with Nasty Plot as it forces Skarmory out.

Fire-type Pokemon and Coverage: Fire-types like Chandelure and Moltres come in easily on Skarmory and force it out. Skarmory must also be wary of Pokemon like Celesteela, Salamence, and Azelf due to them commonly running Fire-type coverage.

Strong Special Attackers: Powerful special attackers like Keldeo, Primarina, and Hydreigon can all break through Skarmory due to its poor special bulk. Hatterene in particular completely walls Skarmory, denying its entry hazards and ignoring Whirlwind and Toxic with Magic Bounce.

sets.name: Iron Defense
sets.description:
Iron Defense allows Skarmory to better check Pokemon such as Azumarill, Mamoswine, and Scizor by boosting its Defense, and it increasing Body Press's damage makes Skarmory more threatening in front of foes such as Hippowdon and Mandibuzz. Roost maintains Skarmory's health and keeps it steadfast against strong attackers like Conkeldurr and Zygarde-10%. Spikes allows Skarmory to support its team, easily setting them up against common Pokemon such as Amoonguss, and the additional chip damage is helpful against Pokemon like Keldeo. Alternatively, since Skarmory has great matchups against entry hazard setters like Excadrill and Hippowdon, Defog is useful to consistently remove their hazards while forcing them out. Rocky Helmet is helpful to punish Excadrill's Rapid Spin and other physical attackers like Zarude and Diggersby. Safety Goggles is an alternative option to allow Skarmory to fully counter Amoonguss, setting up Iron Defense or Spikes without needing to use a teammate as sleep fodder. However, this forces Skarmory to avoid taking Knock Off from foes like Mamoswine and Scizor in order to ignore Spore. 96 Speed EVs allow Skarmory to outspeed Azumarill.

Iron Defense Skarmory fits on bulky offense, balance, and stall teams for handling physical threats such as Scizor while either setting Spikes to wear down foes for its teammates or reliably negating common entry hazard setters like Hippowdon and Swampert. Spikes Skarmory complements other hazard setters like Nihilego and Hippowdon excellently. Both teammates check dangerous threats like Thundurus-T and Moltres, and they also help maintain hazards against hazard removers Skarmory cannot handle, like Salamence. Teammates such as Slowking and Chansey form excellent defensive cores with Skarmory thanks to their ability to check dangerous special attackers like Keldeo and Hydreigon. Slowking can act as a wincon on stall teams with Calm Mind, while Chansey can act as a cleric. Tangrowth provides additional support for Skarmory to ensure Zygarde-10% or Rotom-W does not overwhelm it. Tangrowth also absorbs Knock Off so Skarmory does not have to risk its own Rocky Helmet or Safety Goggles. Articuno can be paired with Skarmory on hazard stacking semi-stall teams to bleed the PP of hazard removers such as Salamence and Mandibuzz. Alternatively, Articuno can pair up with Defog Skarmory in a double Defog core, keeping entry hazards off almost indefinitely. Quagsire can check Rotom-H while providing backup against Dragon Dance Salamence. In return, Skarmory helps Quagsire against the Grass-types in the tier and threats like Gyarados. Hatterene enjoys Spikes pressure chipping Pokemon like Excadrill and Skarmory being a reliable check to Scizor. Hatterene's Magic Bounce also helps Skarmory avoid being worn down by opposing entry hazards. Other offensive teammates include Calm Mind Slowking and Galarian Slowbro, which enjoy Spikes support wearing down threats like Amoonguss and Hippowdon while checking foes like Zarude and Diggersby.

sets.name: Physical Wall
sets.description:
Body Press utilizes Skarmory's amazing Defense to hit many opposing Pokemon hard, devastating the likes of Excadrill, Mamoswine, and Zarude. It also keeps Hydreigon from coming in freely. Alternatively, Brave Bird lets Skarmory hit Conkeldurr, Keldeo, and Amoonguss super effectively and deal solid damage to Azumarill and Gyarados. Spikes wears down common defensive Pokemon like Chansey, Amoonguss, and Hippowdon. Skarmory has plenty of opportunities to set Spikes up against Pokemon that typically cannot threaten it, like Jirachi and Tangrowth. Toxic cripples threats like Moltres and Thundurus-T that typically have free entry on it, and hinders Defoggers like Salamence and Mandibuzz from removing Spikes in the long run. Alternatively, Whirlwind can be used due to its great synergy with Spikes, forcing chip damage on switch-ins like Primarina. It also prevents setup sweepers like Gyarados and Belly Drum Azumarill from setting up. Skarmory can run Defog on stall teams thanks to its ability to handle entry hazard setters like Hippowdon, Excadrill, and Swampert. Rocky Helmet allows Skarmory to punish pivoting attempts from Swampert, Diggersby, and Zarude, prevent Excadrill from freely using Rapid Spin, and wear down threats like Azumarill and Gyarados quickly. The given Speed EVs allow Skarmory to outspeed Azumarill and Conkeldurr.

Skarmory best fits on bulky offense, balance, and stall teams that appreciate its Spikes support and walling capabilities. Chansey makes an excellent partner for Skarmory, taking on dangerous special attackers like Hydreigon, Moltres, and Thundurus-T, while Skarmory handles physical attackers like Excadrill and Diggersby. Slowking similarly checks Moltres and special Salamence, and it also acts as a secondary check to Conkeldurr and Mamoswine with Colbur Berry. Additionally, its Future Sight alongside Skarmory's Whirlwind can hinder offensive Pokemon like Thundurus-T. Stealth Rock setters like Hippowdon, Nihilego, and Excadrill form great entry-hazard stacking cores with Skarmory. Nihilego beats Moltres and Thundurus-T and can hinder Scizor with Knock Off to make it vulnerable to Spikes, while Excadrill can pressure Hatterene and remove opposing entry hazards without compromising Skarmory's own Spikes. Bulky Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth make good secondary checks to Tapu Bulu and Conkeldurr so Skarmory doesn't get overwhelmed checking them. They also can absorb Knock Off for the team, allowing Skarmory to preserve Rocky Helmet and chip down Diggersby. Zarude and the aformentioned Grass-types can help take on strong Electric- and Water-types like Rotom-W and Primarina as well. Powerful wallbreakers like Keldeo, Thundurus-T, and Zygarde-10% all appreciate Skarmory's Spikes wearing down checks like Tangrowth and Chansey. On stall teams, Quagsire can provide an Electric immunity to block Volt Switch and check Thundurus-T. It also can handle setup sweepers that can bypass Skarmory like Belly Drum Azumarill and Swords Dance Scizor. Umbreon acts as a primary check to Dragon Dance Salamence and Gyarados, secondary check to Mamoswine, and way to beat Chandelure.

Raikou.overview: Raikou is a solid fast pivot in UU due to its base 115 Speed, which allows it to outspeed and threaten common Pokemon like Keldeo, Nihilego, and Cobalion, giving it a niche over other Electric-type pivots like Thundurus-T. Being a fast pivot makes Raikou hard to wear down and allows it to bring in threatening Pokemon like Keldeo to wallbreak. It has multiple coverage moves that hinder switch-ins; Scald chips Ground-types like Hippowdon, Nidoqueen, and Swampert and threatens them with a potential burn, while Aura Sphere nails Zarude and Hydreigon. However, Raikou has limited defensive utility due to its average bulk and typing. Its frailty is also worsened by its offensive limitations, as it has a hard time breaking through foes like Hippowdon and Nihilego and gets completely stopped by Amoonguss, Chansey, and Assault Vest Tangrowth. It also struggles to trade with common offensive threats, such as Nidoqueen and Zarude. Because of this, Thundurus-T is generally the superior choice, being stronger, having more versatile coverage, and also providing better typing that can make up for it being slower than Raikou.
Raikou.comments:
Other Options

Extrasensory hits Amoonguss and Conkeldurr for super effective damage, though is usually outclassed by Aura Sphere. Raikou can also run Toxic to hinder Pokemon like Hippowdon and Assault Vest Tangrowth, but it is hard to justify over Aura Sphere, as offensive threats like Zarude can negate status with options like Jungle Healing. Calm Mind + Substitute makes it a late-game sweeper that can also stall out Pokemon like Amoonguss with Pressure, but the presence of Hippowdon, Zarude, and Assault Vest Tangrowth makes this set unreliable and hard to get going. Calm Mind + Volt Switch is another set Raikou can run, but it is usually overshadowed, as the extra damage isn't enough to break through Raikou's counters while also keeping up good momentum.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Bulky Ground-types like Hippowdon, Swampert, and Nidoqueen block Volt Switch from Raikou and can take a Scald, though they hate risking a burn from Scald. Seismitoad and Gastrodon essentially counter Raikou, as their abilities negate Scald entirely. Offensive Ground-types like Zygarde-10% and Choice Scarf Diggersby can both outspeed and OHKO Raikou.

Grass-types: Grass-types like Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth can switch in on Raikou and chip it down easily. Zarude can also take a hit from Aura Sphere and deal massive damage to Raikou, and it easily tanks any other move.

Specially Defensive Walls: Specially defensive Pokemon, like Nihilego, Chansey, and Assault Vest Galarian Slowbro, can easily take attacks from Raikou while also threatening to chip it or hinder it with status. The latter two also have easy recovery, which makes it very difficult for Raikou to wear them down.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description:
Volt Switch makes Raikou a powerful pivot that can consistently bring in teammates like Moltres against switch-ins like Amoonguss and Tangrowth. Thunderbolt gives Raikou a stronger STAB move to break past targets that shrug off Volt Switch, like Slowking, Salamence, and Scizor. Scald punishes Ground-type switch-ins like Hippowdon, Nidoqueen, and Excadrill with a burn chance, as well as 2HKOing the latter two. Scald also hits Nihilego and Rotom-H for super effective damage while being Raikou's best coverage move for Thundurus-T. Aura Sphere hits Dark-types like Hydreigon and Zarude, both of which otherwise wall Raikou. It can also heavily threaten Cobalion, forcing a chipped Cobalion to switch out. Raikou runs Heavy-Duty Boots to negate entry hazard damage, which allows it to come in more frequently and retain momentum with pivoting. Inner Focus is used to prevent flinches from faster threats like Choice Scarf Hydreigon using Dark Pulse.

Raikou best fits on offensive teams that can form strong momentum cores with it. Zarude, Scizor, and Moltres make great partners for Raikou, forming VoltTurn cores with it and luring in the likes of Skarmory and Primarina for Raikou to come in on. Zarude also beats Ground-types like Hippowdon and Swampert, while Scizor and Moltres pressure Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Skarmory, Hippowdon, Nihilego, and Swampert helps Raikou wear down switch-ins like opposing Hippowdon and Nihilego, as well as Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth. Fighting-type wallbreakers like Keldeo and Swords Dance Cobalion can pressure specially defensive walls like Chansey and Nihilego, which are hard for Raikou to break through. Water-types like Primarina and the aforementioned Keldeo pressure Ground-types like Hippowdon, Mamoswine, and Excadrill, as well as Nihilego, all of which otherwise stop Raikou from making progress with ease. Primarina can also check Hydreigon, which offensively checks Raikou. Switch-ins to Grass-types, such as Amoonguss and Mandibuzz, can annoy Tangrowth and Zarude, giving Raikou a much easier time. Mandibuzz also dissuades Spore from from opposing Amoonguss thanks to Overcoat. Flying-types like the aforementioned Mandibuzz and Skarmory, in addition to Salamence, can switch into Ground-type moves for Raikou.

Entei.overview: Sacred Fire, a nice Speed tier, and decent bulk all lend themselves to Entei having a fair niche in UU. Sacred Fire's burn chance is Entei's claim to fame, making it immensely frustrating for even Fire-resistant foes like Rhyperior and Salamence to switch into. Entei is able to outspeed and threaten common threats like Scizor, Tangrowth, and Celesteela. Good bulk alongside a pure Fire typing grants Entei a decent amount of defensive utility and makes it a short-term check to Pokemon such as Jirachi and Zarude. Entei's biggest drawbacks are its Stealth Rock weakness and lack of longevity, which is exacerbated by Flare Blitz recoil. Entei also struggles with various bulky Water-types in the tier, namely Slowing, Rotom-W, and RestTalk Primarina. It struggles during long games due to its low-PP moves and can be awkward to build around due to its demand for team support.
Entei.comments:
Other Options

Heavy-Duty Boots gives Entei more opportunities to switch in and lessens the need for entry hazard removal, but it stops Entei from breaking through Pokemon as efficiently. A set consisting of Substitute, Calm Mind, Protect, and Lava Plume with Leftovers and Pressure can act as a wincon for bulkier teams and stall out defensive Pokemon, but it suffers from a lack of setup opportunities and a Stealth Rock weakness.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Pokemon such as Keldeo, Swampert, and Rotom-W can come in on any of Entei's Fire-moves and proceed to OHKO it. Defensive Water-types such as Primarina and Slowking easily take hits from Entei and retaliate with Scald.

Dragon-types: Offensive Salamence can take any attack from Entei outside of Stone Edge and heavily damage it, while defensive Salamence can comfortable take Stone Edge too. Zygarde-10% outspeeds and OHKOes Entei with Thousand Arrows. Hydriegon can take a Fire-type attack from Entei and hit it massively hard in return. However, none of these appreciate a burn from Sacred Fire.

Rock-types: Rhyperior and Nihilego can force out Entei and set up entry hazards, while Lycanroc-D can revenge kill it. However, none of them appreciate a burn, and Nihilego and Lycanroc-D take large amounts of damage from Entei's attacks.

Residual Damage: Entei is easily worn down by Stealth Rock, Flare Blitz recoil, and status.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Sacred Fire spreads burns and discourages Pokemon such as Salamence and Hippowdon from switching in, but it has low PP and cannot be used liberally. Flare Blitz scores 2HKOs on Pokemon that Sacred Fire misses out on, such as Hatterene, Hippowdon and Chansey. It also has perfect accuracy for cleaning. Stone Edge hits Rotom-H and Moltres, which would otherwise come in easily on Entei. It is also Entei's best way to hit Water-types such as Slowking and Primarina. Extreme Speed revenge kills faster threats such as Azelf and Choice Scarf Hydreigon. Inner Focus ignores Intimidate from foes like Krookodile and Salamence.

Entry hazard removal is necessary for Entei to properly function as an early-game wallbreaker. Pokemon such as Salamence, Rotom-W, and Excadrill are highly recommended; Rotom-W can also lure in Grass-types and pivot into Entei with Volt Switch. Grass-types such as Zarude and Amoonguss are also ideal partners, as they check bothersome Water- and Rock-types such as Primarina and Rhyperior. Zarude can also bring Entei in against foes like Scizor and Skarmory to fire off Sacred Fire. Since it struggles against Dragon-types like Salamence, Entei greatly appreciates Fairy-types like Hatterene and Azumarill; Hatterene can also dissuade Stealth Rock with Magic Bounce. RestTalk Primarina and Slowking can take on annoyances like Hydreigon and Hippowdon for Entei. Slowking can also bring Entei in safely with Teleport. Fast teammates like Raikou, Noivern, and Choice Scarf Diggersby can revenge kill faster foes that threaten Entei, such as Keldeo, Zygarde-10%, and Azelf.

Suicune.overview: Despite its average movepool, Suicune is a decent setup sweeper due to its astounding bulk and valuable defensive typing that allow it to set up against distinguished threats such as Scizor, Cobalion, and Excadrill. With Pressure, Calm Mind, and its superb bulk, Suicune is able to stall out threatening walls such as Amoonguss, Chansey, and even Assault Vest Tangrowth if it gets burned by Scald, allowing it to take many unsuspecting teams by surprise if it gets a few free turns. However, Suicune is held back by the prevalence of Grass- and Electric-types that can limit it from boosting like Tangrowth, Thundurus-T, and Zarude, the latter of which can cure Scald burns with Jungle Healing and use Power Whip to break past it. Powerful wallbreakers like Keldeo and Choice Specs Hydreigon are able to force Suicune into using Rest before it sets up, limiting its offensive presence and exploiting its somewhat limited defensive value as a Water-type. Rest is also unreliable recovery, forcing Suicune to rely on Leftovers alongside Rest in order to regain HP. This makes Suicune susceptible to Knock Off, as losing Leftovers would require Suicune to use Rest more often, limiting its ability to face threats like Scizor. In addition, its overreliance on Sleep Talk isn't great either, as you rely on RNG to choose the ideal move. Suicune faces competition from Calm Mind Primarina, which sports an additional Fairy-typing to better threaten foes with neutral damage, but Suicune's ability to potentially turn Assault Vest Tangrowth into setup fodder is an important niche.
Suicune.comments:
Other Options

Substitute + Calm Mind + Protect is an alternative set that lets Suicune avoid Toxic from foes like Hippowdon while still being able to set up on Pokemon like Amoonguss. However, without Rest, Suicune remains extremely vulnerable to entry hazards and becomes unable to trade with Pokemon like Scizor and Tangrowth. Ice Beam can be to immediately threaten Grass-types like Zarude and Tangrowth as well as other threats like Hydreigon and Thundurus-T.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Pokemon such as Raikou and Thundurus-T can severely damage Suicune with Thunderbolt, even after a Calm Mind boost. Rotom-W can chunk it with Volt Switch and bring in a powerful wallbreaker that can force it out.

Grass-types: Grass-types such as Tapu Bulu and Zarude pose an immense threat to Suicune with their powerful STABs. Jungle Healing variants of Zarude, in particular, completely counter Suicune, as they can switch into Scald without fear due to their ability to remove status. Assault Vest Tangrowth can deal heavy damage with Power Whip and force Suicune into Rest for another teammate to take advantage of early-game, but if burned by Scald, Tangrowth becomes setup fodder.

Powerful Wallbreakers: Dangerous wallbreakers like Choice Specs Keldeo, Choice Specs Hydreigon, and Conkeldurr can deal heavy damage to Suicune and force it into Rest before setting up. Keldeo is especially annoying due to its resistance to Scald and Secret Sword's ability to target Suicune's unboosted physical Defense.

Water-immune Pokemon: As Scald is Suicune's only offensive move, it can't damage Water-immune foes such as Jellicent and Gastrodon, with the former having Taunt to lock Suicune into using Scald or force it to switch out and the latter forcing Suicune to use Rest more often due to Toxic. Despite this, Suicune can still annoy both through Pressure stalling.

Knock Off and Trick Users: Knock Off removes Leftovers, preventing Suicune from regaining passive recovery over the course of a battle and forcing it to use Rest more often. Common Pokemon Suicune would like to set up on, like Scizor, can use Knock Off to hinder it. Trick users such as Jirachi and Rotom-W can force Suicune into being Choice-locked.

sets.name: CroCune
sets.description:
Calm Mind allows Suicune to become a threatening bulky sweeper. Scald is Suicune's only offensive move, which it can use to spread burns and sweep. Scald is especially useful for weakening Assault Vest Tangrowth's Power Whip, allowing Suicune to set up on it more easily and stall it out. Rest allows Suicune to easily recover HP while also curing any status conditions. Sleep Talk prevents Suicune from being too passive during sleep turns by letting it continue to boost its special stats or attack foes. Pressure lets Suicune stall out defensive threats like Amoonguss and Chansey.

Suicune best fits on balance teams that provide it ample opportunities to sweep. Cobalion is an excellent teammate for Suicune, countering Zarude and breaking past Chansey and Slowking. Cobalion also absorbs Knock Off from Scizor and Nihilego, offensively checks Thundurus-T, and can potentially set Stealth Rock to wear down Chansey and Tangrowth. Nihilego also sets Stealth Rock and can remove Chansey's Eviolite with Knock Off. Salamence can check threats like Keldeo and Zarude and provide Defog support for Suicune to keep entry hazards like Spikes from wearing it down. Suicune appreciates Ground-types such as Nidoqueen and Hippowdon to take on Electric-types like Thundurus-T and Raikou. Fast threats like Crobat and Choice Scarf Diggersby can offensively pressure threats to Suicune like Keldeo, Tapu Bulu, Zarude, and Choice Specs Hydreigon. Bulky Grass-types like Amoonguss, Tapu Bulu, and Assault Vest Tangrowth check dangerous foes like Keldeo and Zarude, with the latter two being solid Thundurus-T answers as well. Tapu Bulu's Grassy Terrain support also gives Suicune additional passive recovery, allowing it to not be forced into Rest as much. Umbreon provides Wish Support to keep Suicune healthy and takes on wallbreakers like Hydreigon and Mamoswine. Demon Registeel can form a double sweeping core with Suicune, allowing them to outstall and overcome common bulky offense teams.

Swampert.overview: An excellent typing, a plethora of utility moves such as Toxic, Yawn, and Stealth Rock, and good matchups against the tier's entry hazard removers like Excadrill, Tentacruel, and Salamence make Swampert a solid hazard setter. Good matchups against notable threats like Rotom-W, Cobalion, and Raikou contribute to Swampert's great defensive utility. Flip Turn also lets it be a slow pivot, limiting its passivity, making progress against walls such as Chansey, and bringing in slower teammates like Thundurus-T to wallbreak. However, the plethora of Grass-types like Amoonguss, Tangrowth, and Zarude is incredibly hindersome to Swampert, scaring it out with 4x super effective attacks. Moreover, powerful wallbreakers like Hydreigon, Keldeo, and Primarina take advantage of its lack of reliable recovery to break through it. Swampert is very vulnerable to status and Knock Off, especially from Pokemon it should check like Excadrill and Nihilego, which make it much less effective as a tank. Swampert also faces severe competition from Hippowdon as a Ground-type Stealth Rock setter, which possesses reliable recovery to let it consistently check Zygarde-10% and Cobalion throughout a game. However, Swampert's access to Flip Turn and ability to blank Rotom-W gives it a solid niche over Hippowdon on more offensive VoltTurn teams.
Swampert.comments:
Other Options

A Choice Band set with Liquidation, Earthquake, Ice Punch, and Flip Turn takes advantage of Swampert's solid Attack while also dealing with the Dragon- and Grass-types of the tier more effectively. Scald can potentially burn foes like Skarmory and Scizor that Swampert otherwise struggles against, but it is hard to slot into Swampert's moveset over its other utility moves. High Horsepower is a good alternative to Earthquake if Swampert is being run alongside Tapu Bulu, since Grassy Surge weakens Earthquake, but is an inferior pick otherwise. Rest allows Swampert to offset its lack of recovery, but Swampert misses out on a utility move like Toxic.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types and Grass-type Coverage: Pokemon such as Amoonguss, Zarude, Tangrowth, and Tapu Bulu can easily scare Swampert out with their 4x super effective STAB moves, though the latter two do not like the potential of being inflicted by Toxic. Swampert similarly fears Grass-type coverage, leaving it unable to deal with Gyarados's Power Whip and properly check Thundurus-T and Nihilego until it scouts for Grass Knot.

Toxic: Pokemon like Excadrill and Rotom-H that struggle to deal with Swampert otherwise can use Toxic to cripple it, drastically worsening its longevity.

Powerful Wallbreakers: Thanks to Swampert's lack of reliable recovery, Pokemon like Choice Specs Hydreigon, Choice Specs Primarina, and Keldeo can overwhelm it and take it out easily.

sets.name: Mixed Wall
sets.description:
Earthquake deals massive damage to entry hazard removers like Excadrill and Tentacruel. Flip Turn makes progress against foes like Zarude and Salamence while also bringing in teammates like Zygarde-10% safely. Toxic cripples walls such as Tangrowth and Slowking that force out Swampert. Yawn instead can shut down offensive powerhouses like Primarina that may threaten Swampert's teammates and force switches, allowing Swampert to generate even more momentum. Ice Beam lets Swampert threaten Dragon- and Grass-types like Salamence, Amoonguss, and Tangrowth. However, this forces Swampert to forego one of its utility moves. 112 Special Defense EVs allow Swampert to tank powerful special hits from foes like Thundurus-T and Salamence, while 144 Defense EVs prevent Swampert from getting 2HKOed by Excadrill and Zygarde-10%. A Sassy nature is used so that Swampert can underspeed defensive Celesteela and thus absorb its Leech Seed before pivoting out to a teammate.

Slow wallbreakers, such as Conkeldurr and Mamoswine, greatly appreciate Yawn crippling enemies and Flip Turn giving them safe entry against Pokemon like Hydreigon and Amoonguss. Offensive pivots such as Thundurus-T, Azelf, Crobat, and Zarude form momentum cores with Swampert while also overwhelming foes that Swampert can't handle, such as Tangrowth, Keldeo, and Hydreigon. Tapu Bulu gives Swampert much-appreciated additional recovery through Grassy Terrain. In turn, Swampert can help deal with Poison-types such as Nidoqueen, Nihilego, and Tentacruel, which threaten Tapu Bulu. Wish recovery from clerics such as Jirachi is also great for its longevity. Swampert greatly appreciates teammates like Skarmory and Moltres that can check the Grass-types that it fears so much. The former also forms an entry hazard stacking core with Swampert, while the latter forms a momentum core with it. Entry hazard removers like Tentacruel, Excadrill, and Salamence stop Spikes from punishing Swampert's longevity. Celesteela is able to block threats like Skarmory and Togekiss for Swampert and keeps it from being overwhelmed by Nihilego, appreciating Swampert taking on Tentacruel and Rotom-H in return.

Torkoal.overview: Torkoal is the primary sun setter in UU, using its great physical bulk to switch into Pokemon like Scizor and Zarude and set up sun while also providing role compression as a Stealth Rock setter and entry hazard remover. Torkoal serves as a great partner for sun wallbreakers like Venusaur, Darmanitan, and Chandelure by providing utility with moves such as the previously mentioned Stealth Rock alongside Yawn, Toxic, and Rapid Spin. However, Torkoal struggles with longevity, as it needs to use Heat Rock over Heavy-Duty Boots to provide more sun turns for its teammates, meaning every time it comes in it risks taking significant chip from entry hazards like Stealth Rock. It also has a lack of recovery, making it vulnerable to common enemy leads like Excadrill and Krookodile. Torkoal is also a momentum sink, meaning that the player will have to either switch directly into their sun sweepers like Venusaur and Darmanitan, potentially forcing them to take damage, or sacrifice Torkoal to bring them in safely. Torkoal is quite passive, often requiring status to stop Pokemon like Gyarados from setting up on it. It is also weak to common Pokemon like Zygarde-10%, Nihilego, and Nidoqueen, meaning Torkoal appreciates defensive support from other Pokemon like Chansey to help it set sun more reliably throughout the game. Lastly, the presence of Hippowdon and its ability to set sand means Torkoal struggles to reliably keep up sun.
Torkoal.comments:
Other Options

Thanks to its low Speed, Torkoal can also be run on Trick Room teams, utilizing a powerful sun-boosted Eruption. However, Torkoal is weak to chip and entry hazard damage caused by switching in too many times if it is running Choice Specs over Heavy-Duty Boots, weakening Eruption as a result. Lastly, when Trick Room is over, Torkoal can be easily used as setup fodder or KOed by an opposing Pokemon.

Checks and Counters

Rock-types: Rock-types like Nihilego, Rhyperior, and Lycanroc-D can all hit Torkoal for super effective damage, with the latter two not caring about its sky-high Defense, limiting the ability to set sun in the future due to Torkoal's lack of momentum or reliable recovery. The former two can also set up Stealth Rock, limiting the amount of times Torkoal can come in.

Ground-types: Ground-types such as Krookodile, Nidoqueen, and Diggersby also can hit Torkoal for super effective damage, limiting Torkoal's ability to set sun in the future. The former two are also able to set up Stealth Rock against Torkoal, limiting the amount of times it can come in. Krookodile can also hinder Torkoal with Taunt, preventing it from punishing setup sweepers with Toxic or Yawn. Hippowdon is Torkoal's biggest enemy, being able to reset sun with its Sand Stream and easily set Stealth Rock in front of it.

Water-types: Water-types such as Primarina, Keldeo, and Azumarill all can threaten Torkoal with their powerful Water-type attacks. However, if the sun is up, the power of these moves will be halved, and Torkoal will be able to switch out into Venusaur, forcing them out in return.

Special Attackers: Due to Torkoal's average Special Defense, strong special attackers like Moltres, Hydreigon, and Salamence all can nail Torkoal for heavy damage. They can also use the sun to boost their Fire-type attacks and hit Fire-weak Pokemon like Venusaur even harder.

sets.name: Sun Setter
sets.description:
Thanks to Torkoal's great physical bulk, it can set up Stealth Rock against Pokemon it can force out with Lava Plume like Scizor, Skarmory, and Zarude, allowing wallbreakers like Venusaur and Darmanitan to power through their defensive answers more easily. Lava Plume limits Torkoal's passivity thanks to its Base Power boosted by the sun and 30% chance to burn the foe. Rapid Spin prevents Pokemon like Darmanitan from being heavily chunked by Stealth Rock. Toxic puts Pokemon like Rotom-H, Swampert, and Hydreigon on a timer, forcing them out. Yawn allows Torkoal to force opposing Pokemon out such as setup sweepers like Gyarados that can attempt to set up on it while also giving a free switch for a teammate, but Toxic is preferred for its ability to inflict more damage throughout the game. Rest + Sleep Talk can be used to boost Torkoal's longevity, especially when paired with Stealth Rock setters like Swampert to free up the moveslot. Heat Rock should always be run to maximize the amount of sun turns, allowing sun sweepers like Venusaur and Darmanitan to break through opposing teams more easily.

Powerful sun sweepers like Venusaur, Darmanitan, and Chandelure all act as great partners to Torkoal, as they appreciate its entry hazard support and removal as well as sun boosting their moves to clean through teams. Venusaur in particular is a fantastic partner for Torkoal, as sun activates Chlorophyll and turns its Weather Ball into a strong Fire-type attack for Steel-types like Scizor, Jirachi, and Celesteela. Venusaur also appreciates Torkoal's ability to put answers to it like Moltres and Chandelure on a timer with Toxic. In return, Torkoal appreciates Venusaur breaking through Rock-types like Lycanroc-D, Ground-types like Hippowdon, and Water-types like Primarina and Slowking. Meanwhile, Darmanitan can use the sun to boost its incredibly powerful Flare Blitz and revenge kill threats like Nihilego and Nidoking that threaten Torkoal. It can also bring in Torkoal safely with U-turn. Chansey can provide a defensive stop to Pokemon that threaten Torkoal such as Nihilego and Chandelure while also being able to provide momentum with Teleport to bring in Pokemon like Venusaur and Chandelure safely. Swampert also acts as a defensive stop to threats like Salamence and Nidoqueen and frees up Stealth Rock for Torkoal. Hatterene can act as a secondary entry hazard control option, alleviating the pressure from Torkoal while also dealing with Pokemon like Salamence. It also appreciates its Mystical Fire being boosted by the sun, allowing it to break through Pokemon like Celesteela and Assault Vest Tangrowth more easily. Skarmory and Celesteela provide intergral defensive support against Hippowdon for sun teams. Setup sweepers like Autotomize Celesteela appreciate having their Fire-type coverage boosted by the sun to break through defensive answers like specially defensive Celesteela more easily.

Crawdaunt.overview: Sporting a high Attack stat, Adaptability, and high-Base Power moves, Crawdaunt is an extremely powerful wallbreaker in UU capable of KOing even the bulkiest walls. Water + Dark is a deadly STAB combination that feasts on common defensive Pokemon like Hippowdon, Slowking, and Scizor, with resists to this combo like Primarina and Keldeo still taking massive damage from its Choice Band-boosted attacks. Access to a strong priority move in Aqua Jet allows Crawdaunt to bypass its low Speed and pick off targets such as Azelf and Thundurus-T, while Close Combat crushes Hydreigon and Zarude attempting to switch in. However, Crawdaunt is extremely slow, being outsped and KOed by common threats such as Cobalion and Keldeo. This, combined with its poor bulk and weaknesses to common typings, leaves it with limited opportunities to switch in and forces Crawdaunt to rely on pivots to facilitate its wallbreaking attempts.Crawdaunt faces competition as a Water-type wallbreaker from Keldeo, Primarina, and Azumarill, all of which sport superior defensive utility. However, Crawdaunt's STAB Knock Off is a relevant advantage that lets it break the likes of Amoonguss and Tangrowth more easily.
Crawdaunt.comments:
Other Options

Swords Dance with a Life Orb turns Crawdaunt into a terrifying wallbreaker, OHKOing physically defensive Tangrowth and Skarmory at +2. However, Crawdaunt's poor bulk and low Speed give it little chances to set up before being forced out, making Choice Band's immediate power preferred on most teams. Liquidation can be used over Crabhammer due to its better accuracy, but it's much weaker, failing to 2HKO foes like maximum HP Primarina.

Checks and Counters

Faster Water-resistant threats: Due to its low Speed, Crawdaunt is forced out by anything faster that can take a boosted Aqua Jet like Gyarados, Hydreigon, Rotom-W, and Salamence.

Grass-types: Both Amoonguss and Tangrowth can take a hit from Knock Off, though they have to be careful switching into it if they have their item at risk of being 2HKOed. Tapu Bulu resists Crawdaunt's STAB combination, allowing it to pivot into it multiple times and threaten to OHKO back. Zarude outspeeds Crawdaunt and resists a boosted Aqua Jet, allowing it to revenge kill Crawdaunt with ease.

Fighting-types: Though it would prefer to not switch in, Keldeo resists Crawdaunt's STAB combination and can OHKO it back. Conkeldurr is able to revenge kill Crawdaunt with Mach Punch. Cobalion takes Aqua Jet well and KOes Crawdaunt in return.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Crabhammer and Knock Off cover the majority of the tier, destroying common Pokemon like Hippowdon, Celesteela, and Slowking. Aqua Jet allows Crawdaunt to threaten frailer faster foes like Azelf, Thundurus-T, and Choice Scarf Diggersby. Close Combat destroys Hydreigon and Zarude attempting to switch into Crawdaunt. Lash Out is an option to crush defensive Salamence attempting to switch into Crabhammer while being a solid alternative STAB to Knock Off.

Crawdaunt is intended to be used as an early- or mid-game wallbreaker on more offensive teams, tearing open defensive cores to allow its teammates to clean late-game. Pivots are essential to give Crawdaunt as many wallbreaking attempts as possible. Slowking is not only one of Crawdaunt's favorite targets, but an amazing teammate as well, defensively checking Keldeo and Noivern while also giving Crawdaunt safe entry with Teleport. Slowking also can provide Future Sight support to help Crawdaunt KO Pokemon like Salamence and Amoonguss that attempt to switch into it. Noivern, Choice Scarf Hydreigon, and Choice Scarf Diggersby can revenge kill faster threats like Cobalion, Zarude, and Raikou for Crawdaunt as well as bring it in against Hippowdon with U-turn. Scizor can bring in Crawdaunt with U-turn against threats like Celesteela as well as wear down Tangrowth and Salamence with Knock Off. It also answers Zarude. Entry hazard support is essential in wearing down bulky Pokemon due to Crawdaunt's inability to take a hit if it fails to KO its target. Nidoqueen and Hippowdon can provide Stealth Rock support for Crawdaunt, with the former checking foes like Thundurus-T and Hydreigon and the latter threatening Grass- and Fairy-types like Tangrowth, Tapu Bulu, and Primarina. Entry hazard removal from Pokemon like Tentacruel and Salamence keep Crawdaunt from being worn down by entry hazards, boosting its longevity. Defensive Grass-types like Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth can defensively answer revenge killers to Crawdaunt like Primarina, Thundurus-T, and Keldeo. Pokemon that can spread paralysis such as Nihilego and Togekiss can help Crawdaunt bypass its low Speed. Late-game cleaners like Zygarde-10% and Swords Dance Cobalion appreciate Crawdaunt's wallbreaking and can finish off weakened foes like Skarmory while also keeping faster threats like Hydreigon and Zarude in check throughout a game.

Salamence.overview: Salamence is a very versatile defensive and offensive presence. Its typing, natural bulk, and Intimidate allow it to check common threats such as Excadrill, Zarude, Scizor, and Conkeldurr. It's also a solid Defogger, matching up well against entry hazard setters such as Excadrill, Skarmory, and Cobalion. Salamence can utilize its solid Special Attack, decent Speed tier, and powerful moves like Hurricane and Draco Meteor as a strong special attacker, or it can sweep teams with Dragon Dance and Moxie. That, coupled with coverage in Flamethrower and Earthquake, makes Salamence difficult to predict and revenge kill. However, its reliance on Heavy-Duty Boots means Salamence does not appreciate Knock Off from Pokemon it’s supposed to check, such as Tangrowth and Scizor. Bulky Fairy-types like Hatterene and Primarina can easily take a hit and KO Salamence, while many other threats like Keldeo, Gyarados, and Nidoking carry Ice-type coverage. Offensive threats such as Thundurus-T and Nihilego outspeed it, and Dragon Dance sets are also vulnerable to revenge killers with priority such as Mamoswine and Lycanroc-D. Salamence also faces fierce competition from Hydreigon; Hydreigon's higher Special Attack stat alongside Dark-type STAB moves lets it better deal with popular defensive stalwarts such as Slowking, and it has greater item versatility by virtue of its neutrality to Stealth Rock. However, Salamence has a far better matchup against Pokemon such as Conkeldurr and Scizor, and it's able to outspeed and revenge kill opposing Hydreigon.
Salamence.comments:
Other Options

An Intimidate Dragon Dance set using Roost over Outrage can work on Magneton teams to check problematic answers to Excadrill such as Zarude while remaining offensively potent, but this set fails to get past Hippowdon. Fire Blast over Flamethrower on the special attacking set gives Salamence more power against Steel-types like Celesteela; however, it is less reliable and the additional power is often unneeded. Lum Berry can give Salamence more room to set up on Pokemon like Swampert and Tangrowth, but it doesn't carry as much consistent utility as Life Orb. Choice Scarf alongside Moxie can give Salamence surprising sweeping potential, as it doesn't require a setup turn to outspeed targets such as Keldeo and revenge kills sweepers such as Gyarados. Choice Specs improves Salamence's wallbreaking ability and can lure Hippowdon in to nail it with Hydro Pump.

Checks and Counters

Fairy-types: Pokemon such as Azumarill, Togekiss, Primarina, and Hatterene take advantage of Salamence's lack of coverage for them, having the bulk to take a hit and either set up or KO Salamence.

Rock-types: Without Draco Meteor, special Salamence struggles to relieve Stealth Rock pressure from Nihilego, though it must be wary of Earthquake. Lycanroc-D can OHKO offensive variants of Salamence with -1 Stone Edge after minimal chip damage and easily revenge kill it with Accelerock, though Lycanroc-D cannot switch into Salamence safely.

Walls: Pokemon like Chansey and Slowking can handle special Salamence with their massive special bulk and use it for momentum with Teleport. However, the two cannot reliably tank hits from Dragon Dance sets. Umbreon and Mandibuzz have the natural bulk to survive Salamence's special attacks and take advantage of Dragon Dance sets with Foul Play. Celesteela is an especially detrimental defensive threat because it completely walls Dragon Dance sets without Fire Blast. Hippowdon can take hits from both physical and special sets and cripple Defog Salamence with Toxic.

Mamoswine: Mamoswine is the most consistent revenge killer against Salamence, as Ice Shard OHKOes any set.

sets.name: Special Attacker
sets.description:
Draco Meteor helps Salamence revenge kill Hydreigon and deals solid damage to neutral targets like Swampert, Rotom-W, and Rotom-H. Hurricane 2HKOes Assault Vest Tangrowth and has a significant chance to OHKO Amoonguss after Stealth Rock. It also prevents Slowking from switching into Salamence. Defog can be used over either STAB move, though this sacrifices neutral coverage against Pokemon like Nihilego and Azumarill. Flamethrower is solid coverage against Pokemon such as Scizor and Skarmory and can finish off weakened targets such as Tangrowth and Conkeldurr without risking a Hurricane miss. Roost alongside Heavy-Duty Boots makes Salamence harder to wear down by threats like Scizor and Zarude. Intimidate makes Salamence a more reliable switch-in to threats such as Conkeldurr, Scizor, and Excadrill while making them easier to pivot around.

This set fits on bulky offense and balance teams for its wallbreaking capabilities against Pokemon like Amoonguss and important defensive utility against other foes like Scizor. Swampert, Nidoqueen, and Excadrill are able to break through Salamence's checks like Nihilego, provide Stealth Rock support to soften up defensive Pokemon such as Celesteela, and capitalize on support against Tangrowth. Excadrill also pressures Hatterene and Togekiss and provides Rapid Spin support so Salamence can drop Defog. Scizor and Mamoswine takes advantage of Salamence removing potential roadblocks such as Amoonguss and Skarmory, and they threaten Stealth Rock setters Salamence has troubles against like Chansey and Nihilego. Zarude, Slowking, and Cobalion are effective pivots to safely bring Salamence into foes such as Hydreigon and Tangrowth. Slowking in particular provides slow pivoting with Teleport so Salamence can safely enter on Grass-types, as well as providing a stronger backbone against Conkeldurr with Colbur Berry. Rotom-W also acts as a pivot to bring Salamence in on Tangrowth and can check Mamoswine and Celesteela. Azelf can handle faster Pokemon such as Nihilego and Lycanroc-D. Defensive partners like Amoonguss and Hippowdon handle threats like Primarina and Nihilego.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
At +1 Speed, Salamence outspeeds revenge killers like Azelf, Thundurus-T, and Choice Scarf Hydreigon. At +2 Speed, it blows past even faster revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Zarude. +1 Outrage destroys many neutral targets like Rotom-W, Rotom-W, and Swampert, though there is always the risk of Fairy-types like Azumarill and Primarina revenge killing Salamence. +1 Dual Wingbeat OHKOes targets such as Conkeldurr, Zarude, and Amoonguss after Stealth Rock. Dual Wingbeat also has the benefit of hitting Keldeo through Substitute, though risking a burn from Scald is not ideal. Earthquake OHKOes Cobalion and Jirachi at +2. Fire Blast can be used instead to lure in and break through Skarmory and increase Salamence's chances for a Moxie sweep. Life Orb can be used to OHKO Pokemon such as bulky Moltres with +1 Outrage and Primarina with +2 Dual Wingbeat. It can also be used alongside a Naive nature to ensure that Fire Blast OHKOes Skarmory after Stealth Rock. However, Salamence's Stealth Rock weakness and Life Orb recoil will quickly put it into range for Lycanroc-D's Accelerock. Moxie helps Salamence get multiple boosts to KO bulky targets like Hippowdon and makes it more difficult to revenge kill.

This set fits on offense and hyper offense teams as a wallbreaker or late-game cleaner with Moxie. Excadrill is an excellent lead that sets Stealth Rock to wear down bulky Pokemon such as Rotom-W and provides Rapid Spin. Sticky Web from Ribombee lets Salamence outspeed foes such as Nihilego. Celesteela walls this set, so early-game wallbreakers such as Nasty Plot Thundurus-T and Azelf are decent options. They also appreciate Salamence's ability to threaten Chansey. Other teammates that overwhelm physically bulky Pokemon such as Quagsire and Skarmory, such as Gyarados and Autotomize Celesteela, are valuable assets to this set. They also heavily benefit Salamence by overwhelming checks like Amoonguss and Primarina. Pivots such as Diggersby and Zarude can position Salamence to set up on Pokemon like Tangrowth. Zarude also blanks Hippowdon and Rotom-W for Salamence. Mamoswine is a consistent revenge killer against Salamence, so teammates that take it on such as Slowking and Scizor are appreciated. Magneton is able to trap and remove Skarmory, Celesteela, and Scizor for Salamence. It also wipes out Primarina and Togekiss.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Dual Wingbeat is a reliable STAB move that helps against threats to defensive teams such as Substitute Keldeo. Toxic can be used instead to cripple Stealth Rock setters such as Hippowdon and wear down wallbreakers such as Thundurus-T, though Salamence becomes much more passive against Conkeldurr. Flamethrower nails Steel-types like Excadrill and Scizor, though Earthquake can be used to KO Nihilego while retaining coverage for the former. Intimidate alongside the additional HP investment makes Salamence a more sturdy switch-in to Conkeldurr, Zarude, and Scizor. Maximum Speed investment is needed to make Salamence less passive against offensive threats such as Hydreigon and Krookodile.

This set is suited for balance and stall teams to relieve entry hazard pressure from setters like Excadrill and Skarmory and check dangerous Pokemon like Scizor and Zarude. Other entry hazard setters such as Hippowdon and Nihilego are significant threats, so Chansey can help outlast them while also providing their own Stealth Rock support. Umbreon can check Pokemon Salamence can't handle by itself like Mamoswine and Gyarados, and it heavily appreciates Salamence’s support against Fighting-types like Keldeo. Quagsire keeps Salamence from being overwhelmed by opposing Dragon Dance Salamence and Lycanroc-D and benefits from Salamence checking Grass-types. Knock Off support from teammates such as Nihilego is very beneficial so that Salamence can outlast threats such as Swampert. Bulky Grass-types like Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth are useful switch-ins into special attackers such as Primarina and Thundurus-T. Amoonguss and physically defensive Tangrowth are also good switch-ins to Knock Off. Hatterene can ease Salamence's role as a hazard remover with Magic Bounce.

Registeel.overview: Registeel serves the purpose of a bulky ChestoRest + Double Dance sweeper, as its bulk, combined with its amazing Steel typing, gives it the edge in a multitude of matchups. It is able to set up on common UU staples such as Nihilego, Chansey, and Scizor and bait offensive threats that hit it super effectively, such as Zygarde-10%, Conkeldurr, and pivot Thundurus-T, using them as setup fodder to start a sweep. Because of its ability to boost its physical and special bulk, Registeel has multiple opportunities to set up and can potentially steamroll teams lacking a Ghost-type, Taunt, or certain sweepers that don't take much from Body Press. It also has a good amount of PP on Iron Defense, Amnesia, and Rest combined, so it is able to stall out defensive Pokemon like Slowking and Amoonguss. Registeel is also a solid defensive Stealth Rock setter for many teams, checking various offensive threats, including Nihilego, Zarude, and Starmie. It also has access to status in Thunder Wave and Toxic, which makes it less passive against offensive teams. However, while Registeel's defensive profile is phenomenal, its passivity leads to inviting common wallbreakers and setup sweepers in, like Keldeo and Nidoking. It also faces stiff competition as a Steel-type Stealth Rock setter from the likes of Excadrill and Cobalion, both of which have an actual offensive presence. Registeel faces competition as a defensive Steel-type from Skarmory and Scizor; both have reliable recovery and Skarmory can check Pokemon like Gyarados and Diggersby. Registeel also greatly fears Knock Off because of how reliant it is on its item to stay healthy throughout a game. It's also often forced to use Rest between boosting, which gives wallbreakers like Keldeo and Nidoking chances to fish for critical hits to KO it through its boosts.
Registeel.comments:
Other Options

Heavy Slam is an option on Stealth Rock sets over Seismic Toss to better deal with Hatterene and Togekiss, but you sacrifice consistent damage on other targets like Scizor and Zarude.

Checks and Counters

Strong Wallbreakers: Powerful wallbreakers like Nidoking, Chandelure, and Mamoswine can keep Registeel from setting up freely due to their attacks forcing it to use Rest. However, they can struggle to take on Registeel if it accumulates enough boosts. Chandelure, in particular, is troublesome due to its immunity to Body Press; it almost effortlessly beats Double Dance Registeel.

Taunt and Trick: Taunt users such as Crobat annoy both Registeel. Trick users are extremely problematic as well, namely Choice Scarf Jirachi and Rotom-W, as they cripple Registeel and make it virtually useless.

Fighting-types and Fighting-type coverage: Fighting-types like Keldeo and Conkeldurr can immediately threaten Registeel with big damage and force it to use Rest, leaving it exploitable. Common users of Fighting-type coverage such as Iron Defense Skarmory, Nasty Plot Thundurus-T, and Swords Dance Scizor also immediately threaten Registeel. However, all of these Pokemon must come in before Registeel boosts the correct stat, or else they lose to it.

Fighting-Resistant Sweepers: Setup sweepers resistant to Body Press, including Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro, Calm Mind Hatterene, Nasty Plot + Flamethrower Togekiss, and Swords Dance Tapu Bulu, force Registeel out before it is able to start sweeping.

Quagsire: Quagsire staves off Body Press with no issue due to its Unaware allowing it to ignore Registeel's boosts. It can come in freely and use Haze, putting a stop to any sort of sweep.

sets.name: Demon Registeel (Double Dance)
sets.description:
Maximum Defense investment with a Bold nature is needed to fully strengthen Body Press and increase its damage output, allowing Registeel to more freely set up on Azumarill, Zygarde-10%, and Excadrill. Iron Defense, in particular, makes Body Press's power skyrocket to exceptional levels. At +6, Registeel becomes incredibly powerful and is able to 2HKO even physically defensive Slowking with a favorable damage roll or minor chip damage. With Amnesia and Iron Defense, it is able to set up on multiple Pokemon, including Hippowdon, Salamence, and Tangrowth. This gives Registeel room to boost its unboosted stat as well. After a single Iron Defense, for example, Conkeldurr cannot 2HKO Registeel. Amnesia leaves Pokemon that would otherwise counter Registeel such as Moltres and Nidoking unable to 2HKO it, forcing them to fish for a critical hit in order to KO. Rest, along with Chesto Berry, allows Registeel to rid itself of status that would otherwise get in the way of a sweep. Rest also gives Registeel longevity to last throughout a game and stay healthy versus the likes of Excadrill, Scizor, and Cobalion.

Registeel fits best on bulky offense and balance teams that provide it many opportunities to boost and sweep. Ghost-types are a massive problem for Registeel, as they are immune to Body Press and are usually able to power through it, so Hydreigon is a valuable teammate that can shut them down. Salamence and Slowking can check offensive Fighting-types such as Keldeo and Conkeldurr for Registeel. Registeel appreciates Knock Off absorbers like Amoonguss, Tapu Bulu, and Rocky Helmet Tangrowth to ensure safer setup. Tapu Bulu also provides Grassy Terrain support to give it passive recovery and weaken Earthquake from Mamoswine and Diggersby. Nihilego is a solid partner for Registeel, as it removes common Fighting-resistant Pokemon such as Hatterene and Togekiss, and provides Stealth Rock and Knock Off support that can aid in wearing down the opposition. It is also a reliable counter to Chandelure. Rotom-W threatens offensive Ground-types like Nidoking and Mamoswine, as well as Skarmory for Registeel. It can also provide valuable Defog support to clear the field of entry hazards. Calm Mind Hatterene is a good partner, due to countering Skarmory, which can KO Registeel after boosting alongside it with its own Body Press. It also prevents Skarmory from laying Spikes that would wear down Registeel a lot faster. Chansey can handle special attackers like Nidoking for Registeel while also providing Aromatherapy support to wake it up after Rest.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Body Press is also an option over Seismic Toss that allows Registeel to take advantage of its high Defense stat to deal significant damage to targets such as Zarude, Hydreigon, and Excadrill. Toxic cripples switch-ins, including Slowking and Hippowdon, and puts a timer on common Defog users like Salamence and Mandibuzz. Thunder Wave is also an option that cripples faster offensive threats including Azelf, Keldeo, and Gyarados. Earthquake allows Registeel to threaten various Toxic-immune Pokemon, including Nidoqueen and Galarian Slowbro. Most importantly, it OHKOes Nihilego. Maximum Special Defense with a Careful nature allows Registeel to better check Salamence and Meteor Beam Nihilego.

Registeel fits best on bulky offense and balance teams that appreciate the solid defensive utility it provides. Checks to Fire- and Fighting-type like Salamence and Slowking pair well with Registeel, taking on threats like Keldeo and Moltres. Thundurus-T and Rotom-W threaten common entry hazard removers, such as Salamence and Mandibuzz. Tentacruel, Mandibuzz, and the aforementioned Salamence can also remove Spikes, which cut into Registeel's longevity. Bulky Grass-types, such as Amoonguss and Tangrowth, are good partners that can check Keldeo and Zygarde-10%, which otherwise threaten Registeel.

Jirachi.overview: Jirachi's wide movepool, great utility options like Healing Wish, and amazing ability in Serene Grace make it a versatile force in UU. Serene Grace gives Iron Head a high chance to flinch slower foes like Hydreigon, making Choice Scarf Jirachi difficult to deal with for unprepared offensive teams. Additionally, Jirachi's above average bulk and great defensive typing allow it to check threats like Nihilego and Hatterene. Jirachi can fulfill a wide variety of roles on teams, whether it's revenge killing threats like Azelf with Choice Scarf, serving as a potent progress maker with its SubToxic set that can get through typical checks such as Amoonguss and Hippowdon, or healing its team with Wish. However, Jirachi's reliance on Leftovers for checking Pokemon like Salamence and Hatterene makes it susceptible to Knock Off from Nihilego and Tangrowth. Jirachi has only average offensive stats, making it very reliant on Iron Head flinches to make progress against foes it lacks coverage for, with common defensive staples like Skarmory, Excadrill, and Amoonguss walling it regardless. Jirachi, while jack of all trades, is master of none, and faces competition from Pokemon like Hydreigon as a revenge killer, Cobalion as a Steel-type Stealth Rock setter, and Umbreon as a Wish user, making its roles more specific.
Jirachi.comments:
Other Options

Jirachi can utilize a Stealth Rock set to support its team thanks to the switches it forces against foes like Nihilego. It can also run Healing Wish on this set to give sweepers like Calm Mind Keldeo another shot in the game. However, this set is quite passive and invites many threatening foes like Cobalion, Scizor, and Hippowdon in for free. Hippowdon, Nihilego, and Cobalion are often preferred as Stealth Rock setters instead due to their better matchups against common removers as well as the broader metagame. Jirachi can utilize a special attacker set with Meteor Beam to lure in and remove common switch-ins like Moltres and Rotom-H. However, this set struggles to cover everything. Jirachi can use Calm Mind sets to sweep on hyper offense teams, but these also struggle to choose their coverage. Jirachi can utilize a mixed set, which can notably KO Amoonguss with Psychic while nailing Hatterene with Iron Head, but it lacks in power compared to other offensive Psychic-types like Azelf.
