Jirachi can run Stored Power sets with Calm Mind and Weakness Policy to accumulate many boosts and sweep, but these sets struggle to get past Swords Dance Scizor and defensive Celesteela and can be ineffective without many boosts.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Rotom-H, Moltres, and Chandelure take very little from Jirachi's attacks and can force it out with their powerful STAB attacks. Jirachi especially dislikes a burn from Moltres's Flame Body. However, none of them like Jirachi using Trick to remove their Heavy-Duty Boots.

Steel-types: Celesteela takes very little from Jirachi's attacks and can wear it down with Leech Seed + Flamethrower. Scizor walls Jirachi without Fire Punch and can use it as setup fodder or force it out. Excadrill also walls Jirachi and can devastate it with Earthquake. Cobalion and Skarmory can set entry hazards in front of Jirachi and chip it with Rocky Helmet recoil, though they dislike Trick.

Water-types: Bulky Water-types like Rotom-W, Slowking, and Swampert take very little from Jirachi's attacks and can cripple it or decently damage it. However, they hate taking a Toxic from the SubToxic set. Offensive Water-types like Keldeo and Crawdaunt pressure Jirachi hard.

Dark-types: Dark-types like Zarude, Krookodile, and Hydreigon offensively threaten Jirachi and force it out. Zarude and Choice Scarf Hydreigon can revenge kill non-Choice Scarf Jirachi, with Choice Scarf Zarude outspeeding Choice Scarf variants as well. Mandibuzz and Umbreon don't mind Iron Head much and can wear it down with Foul Play. The latter also uses Inner Focus to block flinches and freely pass Wish to its teammates.

Knock Off: Pokemon carrying Knock Off like Tangrowth and Azelf can remove Leftovers to cripple defensive Jirachi, especially sets without Wish. Choice Scarf Jirachi becomes a much worse revenge killer without its item and can struggle to use Trick and Healing Wish effectively.

Residual Damage and Status: Due to Jirachi lacking reliable one-turn recovery, it is prone to getting worn down by entry hazards like Spikes as well as Rocky Helmet users like Skarmory, Tangrowth, and Amoonguss. Jirachi also hates burns and paralysis from Pokemon like Moltres and Chansey, with paralysis making it hard to outspeed threats like Excadrill and leverage U-turn.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Jirachi is a potent revenge killer, outspeeding threats like Zygarde-10%, Azelf, and +1 Dragon Dance Gyarados. Iron Head can OHKO Pokemon like Nihilego and Lycanroc-D and, in conjunction with Serene Grance, possibly break through Pokemon like Hydreigon and Primarina with flinches. U-turn gets momentum against switch-ins like Skarmory and Excadrill as well as Pokemon it may not have coverage for like Gyarados and Thundurus-T. Trick lets Jirachi cripple Scizor and defensive Pokemon like Chansey and Slowking, but losing Choice Scarf compromises Jirachi's ability to revenge kill Pokemon like Azelf and Zarude, so it should be used wisely. Ice Punch is an option to nail Thundurus-T and Salamence, while Thunder Punch more reliably beats Gyarados and Azumarill. Fire punch does massive damage to Scizor, and Zen Headbutt lets Jirachi slam Amoonguss, Keldeo, and Conkeldurr. However, locking into coverage moves leaves Jirachi open to threats like Cobalion and Excadrill. Jirachi can utilize Healing Wish late-game to give a teammate another chance to sweep or defensively answer a threat.

Choice Scarf Jirachi fits on balance and bulky offense teams, which appreciate its revenge killing capabilities and Healing Wish. Zarude makes an excellent partner for it, completely blanking Slowking and Hippowdon, threatening Excadrill, and absorbing status and Knock Off. Amoonguss can also absorb Knock Off and can check faster threats like Choice Scarf Zarude. Wallbreakers like Thundurus-T, Conkeldurr, and Hydreigon can be brought in via U-turn on checks like Moltres, Excadrill, and Tangrowth. They all can benefit from Healing Wish too. Moltres forms a solid pivoting core with Jirachi, with each bringing the other in on their answers. Moltres also helps check Celesteela, Excadrill, Scizor, and Amoonguss, while Jirachi can revenge kill threats like Nihilego and Lycanroc-D. Moltres and Excadrill can provide entry hazard control to keep Jirachi from getting worn down. Entry hazard support from Nihilego and Hippowdon helps Jirachi wear down Pokemon like Primarina and Hatterene more easily. Nihilego and Hippowdon can also help check threats like Moltres and Salamence.

sets.name: SubToxic
sets.description:
Jirachi can set up Substitute against Pokemon that are either unable or unlikely to break through it, such as Chansey and Slowking, and Pokemon that it can force out such as Hatterene and Nihilego. Substitute provides Jirachi with a safe opportunity to use Toxic against its checks like Hippowdon, Moltres, and Swampert, or a safety net to repeatedly use Iron Head against Pokemon like Tangrowth and Amoonguss without risk. Fire Punch offers coverage against Steel-types such as Scizor, Cobalion, and Skarmory while boasting a significant 20% burn chance via Serene Grace, which can be used to stack up damage alongside Iron Head flinches to better pressure Toxic-immune Pokemon like Skarmory and Amoonguss. On top of this, a burned Amoonguss is unable to break Jirachi's Substitute in a single hit, turning it into setup bait for later in the game. Toxic pairs fantastically with Substitute and Iron Head, letting Jirachi wear down and break through Pokemon it would otherwise struggle with such as Slowking and Mandibuzz, as well as crippling offensive checks such as Keldeo, Thundurus-T, and Choice Scarf Hydreigon. Maximum HP investment provides Jirachi with 101 HP Substitutes, preventing Chansey's Seismic Toss from breaking them, while reducing the chance for Slowking to break them with Scald to a low 12.5%. This HP investment also prevents Rotom-W and Rotom-H from breaking Jirachi's Substitute with Volt Switch.

SubToxic Jirachi fits best on balance teams that can defensively assist it against Pokemon like Scizor, Moltres, and Keldeo, which it can let in short-term, and provide other forms of support such as additional Toxic users and Heal Bell. Teammates that use Toxic reduce the number of setup turns Jirachi requires to break through checks such as Hippowdon. Celesteela and Skarmory are perfect candidates for this role, encouraging Pokemon like Hippowdon, Slowking, and Moltres to switch into them and be poisoned while providing key defensive support against Pokemon like Scizor, Zarude, and Excadrill. Skarmory can also provide Spikes support to further wear down switch-ins to Jirachi like Amoonguss and Excadrill. SubToxic Jirachi mandates partners such as Scizor and Krookodile that can remove Rocky Helmet from common users of it such as Skarmory, Tangrowth, and Amoonguss. Scizor is also able to remove the items of other notable Jirachi checks, such as Celesteela and Hippowdon's Leftovers and Moltres's Heavy-Duty Boots, while Krookodile can provide Stealth Rock support. Hippowdon and Excadrill are also fantastic options for Stealth Rock setters that pair well with Jirachi, switching into Knock Off variants of Nihilego so Jirachi can maintain its Leftovers. Hippowdon can help check Cobalion, Excadrill, and Zygarde-10% for Jirachi, while Excadrill can provide Rapid Spin support and a safer initial switch into an potential unrevealed Grass Knot Nihilego. Slowking is also fantastic due to checking various Steel-types such as Celesteela, Cobalion, and Excadrill, which Jirachi struggles with, and various other offensive threats such as Moltres and Salamence. Offensive teammates such as Keldeo and Moltres greatly appreciate Jirachi's ability to overwhelm their shared checks such as Amoonguss and Slowking, and in return they can provide Jirachi with useful pivots into these Pokemon. SubToxic Jirachi also fits well on more defensive balance and semi-stall teams, greatly appreciating Wish support from Umbreon letting it use Substitute more freely, and Heal Bell support from Pokemon like Chansey and Articuno lets it more aggressively switch into Slowking and freely attack Moltres. Umbreon and Chansey can also help check threats to Jirachi such as Moltres and Noivern, while Articuno can keep the field clear of entry hazards from Jirachi's checks such as Skarmory and Hippowdon.

sets.name: Wish + Protect
sets.description:
Wish keeps Jirachi healthy throughout a match, allowing it to check threats like Salamence and Hatterene more reliably. Jirachi can pass Wish to teammates that lack reliable recovery like Swampert. It distinguishes itself from Umbreon in this role thanks to U-turn, which makes passing Wishes easier. U-turn also allows Jirachi to pivot out against threats like Excadrill and Mandibuzz. Protect ensures Jirachi will receive its Wish and nets more Leftovers recovery. It also lets Jirachi scout Choice-locked threats like Zygarde-10% and Hydreigon. 240 Speed EVs let Jirachi outspeed Choice Specs Hydreigon, with the remaining EVs put in Special Defense and HP to better check Pokemon like Salamence and Nihilego.

This set best fits on balance teams, which appreciate Jirachi healing the team with Wish while bringing teammates in safely with U-turn. Wallbreakers that get worn down easily like Mamoswine, Keldeo, and Conkeldurr greatly enjoy Wish, and U-turn can bring them in on targets like Celesteela and Excadrill. Hippowdon, Rhyperior, and Nihilego check threats like Moltres, Thundurus-T, and Rotom-H. The latter two enjoy Jirachi offsetting their lack of recovery with Wish support in return. They can also act as primary checks to Salamence and Noivern to lessen the load on Jirachi. Amoonguss can check Zarude and absorb Knock Off for Jirachi. Moltres also checks Zarude and can beat Steel-types like Scizor and Skarmory that Jirachi lures in. Zarude can bring Jirachi in safely to use Wish against Zarude's checks like Togekiss while also removing Slowking. Rotom-W forms a great defensive core with Jirachi, being able to check threats like Moltres, Autotomize Celesteela, and Starmie. It also enjoys having the freedom to run Defog or Will-O-Wisp over Pain Split. Tentacruel and Excadrill can clear Spikes, while Jirachi can offset their lack of recovery.

Roserade.overview: Roserade is a potent entry hazard setter in the tier due to Spikes and the ability to punish switch-ins such as Salamence, Aegislash, and Jirachi with Sleep Powder. Its solid STAB moves in Leaf Storm and Sludge Bomb allow it to hit a plethora of staples such as Rhyperior, Primarina, and Tangrowth super effectively while also threatening others with Sludge Bomb poisons. Its typing lets Roserade check key Pokemon such as Rotom-W, Primarina, and Amoonguss. Roserade's Defense and Speed leave much to be desired, though, making it easy to revenge kill by many offensive Pokemon such as Krookodile, Lycanroc-D, and Salamence. It is also unable to touch Steel-types such as Celesteela, Jirachi, and Aegislash, barring Sleep Powder. Roserade faces competition with other Grass-types such as Amoonguss and Tangrowth, which offer better defensive utility against threats like Keldeo, Azumarill, and Krookodile but lack Spikes and are passive, and offense threats like Zarude, Nihilego, and Nidoking, which are more threatening due to better coverage and Speed.
Roserade.comments:
Other Options

A more specially defensive spread can be used to better check foes such as Keldeo, Raikou, and Primarina. Life Orb makes Roserade a greater offensive threat and lets it OHKO threats such as Buzzwole and Necrozma with entry hazard support; this does, however, severely worsen its longevity. Leaf Storm is a powerful move it can run; however, the Special Attack drop makes it easier to take advantage of. Toxic Spikes aids wallbreakers such as Keldeo and Zygarde-10% in breaking down checks like Tangrowth, Primarina, and Buzzwole and generally annoys the opposing team, but Spikes is usually better due to the abundance of Poison-immune Pokemon and Poison-types.

Checks and Counters

Steel-types: Roserade cannot touch Aegislash, Celesteela, and Jirachi, aside from an inaccurate Sleep Powder, and gives them a free switch or opportunity to set up.

Fire-types: Entei, Rotom-H, and Moltres threaten to OHKO Roserade with powerful Fire-type moves and force it out; however, they do not appreciate switching in on Sludge Bomb.

Psychic-types: Galarian Slowbro, Reuniclus, and Azelf are able to threaten Roserade with their STAB moves and force it out or set up on it. The former two can easily sponge Roserade's attacks, only fearing Sleep Powder. Azelf cannot switch into Roserade directly, but it can outspeed and force it out.

Faster Threats and Priority: Zarude, Salamence, Lycanroc-D, and Krookodile outspeed Roserade and threaten to deal heavy damage to it. Slower Pokemon with priority such as Mamoswine and Diggersby are also able to threaten Roserade.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Umbreon, Galarian Moltres, and Chansey can switch into Roserade, with Chansey also not fearing status due to Natural Cure. Mantine is notable, as it tanks Leaf Storm and removes Spikes with Defog.

sets.name: Spikes
sets.description:
Giga Drain provides recovery and make it easier to forgo Synthesis. Sludge Bomb hits Grass-resistant Pokemon like Zarude, Moltres, and Amoonguss while also threatening to poison foes like Mantine and Rotom-H. Roserade is excellent at setting Spikes due to its tendency to force switches. Sleep Powder is preferred to cripple switch-ins such as Aegislash and Galarian Slowbro, although Synthesis can be used to better check threats such as Primarina, Amoonguss, and Tangrowth and more comfortably set Spikes on walls such as Chansey and Mantine. Black Sludge helps Roserade better check Primarina and Rotom-W while also allowing it to passively heal up residual damage. The EV spread allows it to survive two Secret Swords from Choice Specs Keldeo.

Roserade's ability to set up Spikes makes it an excellent partner for powerful wallbreakers such as Keldeo, Lycanroc-D, Salamence, and Gyarados. Krookodile and Nihilego can form an entry hazard stacking core with Roserade, pairing up its Spikes with Stealth Rock. Krookodile also becomes able to switch into a slept Aegislash without getting punished by Toxic, while Nihilego is able to threaten Fire-types like Moltres and Rotom-H. They also remove items like Eviolite on Chansey and Leftovers on Aegislash with Knock Off, letting Roserade wear them down more easily. Due to its weakness to foes like Moltres and Mamoswine, Roserade appreciates Water-types such as Rotom-W, Keldeo, and Primarina; in return, Roserade resists Grass- and Electric-type moves for them. Steel-types such as Jirachi, Celesteela, and Aegislash also make for stellar teammates, as they resist Flying- and Psychic-type attacks that Roserade struggles with. Pokemon such as Moltres, Nidoking, and Buzzwole threaten Steel-types that Roserades struggle with. Entry hazard removers such as Starmie, Rotom-W, and Salamence allow Roserade to stay healthy throughout longer games, although Defoggers like the latter two also remove its Spikes. Faster Pokemon such as Noivern, Mienshao, and Zygarde-10% threaten problematic foes such as Zarude, Krookodile, and Salamence and benefit from Spikes wearing down their checks.

Gastrodon.overview: Gastrodon is an incredible mixed wall for balance teams due to its incredible typing and access to Recover. Its ability in Storm Drain gives it an important Water immunity that allows it to switch into threats such as Rotom-W and scout Keldeo with a Choice item, while Gastrodon's stellar typing lets it reliably switch into most Fire- and Electric-type Pokemon not running specific coverage for it such as Rotom-H, Thundurus-T, and Chandelure. It additionally serves as a consistent answer to Nidoking. Gastrodon, however, carries a quadruple weakness to Grass, leaving it taken advantage of by Grass-type Pokemon such as Tangrowth and Amoonguss. Zarude in particular is very problematic as Jungle Healing prevents it from being crippled by Toxic or a Scald burn. Gastrodon is also vulnerable to coverage from threats such as Nihilego with Grass Knot and Gyarados with Power Whip. Gastrodon is also rather passive due to its mediocre attacking stats, it relies heavily on status to make progress in games against bulkier teams, and struggles to stop setup sweepers such as Kommo-o and Gyarados. Gastrodon is also crippled by status, as it bleeds into its longevity, with Toxic specifically forcing it to leave the field often to avoid being taken out by chip.
Gastrodon.comments:
Other Options

Gastrodon can utilize a Curse set to attempt to be on the more offensive end, but it's highly niche due to how hard it is to set up, as well as threats such as Amoonguss, Tapu Bulu, and Tangrowth being able to easily make work of it.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types and Grass-type Coverage: Grass-type Pokemon such as Tangrowth and Amoonguss take advantage of Gastrodon's 4x weakness to make quick work of it, as it has little to no way to answer them offensively and it folds to their STAB attacks. Zarude counters Gastrodon as it can easily pivot into it and heal off status. Gastrodon also has to be careful of Grass-type coverage on Pokemon like Gyarados, Nihilego, and Azelf.

Strong Physical Breakers: Wallbreakers such as Mienshao, Diggersby, and Mamoswine can overpower Gastrodon with their powerful attacks.

Setup Sweepers: Galarian Moltres, Gyarados, and Autotomize Necrozma can threaten to break through Gastrodon's defenses after setup but must be wary to not get hit by status in their attempt to set up.

sets.name: Mixed Wall
sets.description:
Gastrodon's main STAB options in Scald and Earthquake allow it to generate offensive presence while on the field, dealing good damage to tier staples like Lycanroc-D and Moltres, with the former having potential to spread burns onto the opponent. Ice Beam pressures Salamence while catching Grass-types off guard, but due to Gastrodon's relatively weak attacking power, it is unable to 3HKO Amoonguss or Zarude. Dropping Scald also gives Gastrodon no way to punish Rotom-H. Toxic allows Gastrodon to passively chip bulkier targets such as Rotom-W and Salamence which otherwise don't care too much for Gastrodon's STAB attacks. Clear Smog is useful for stopping setup sweepers such as Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro, but it makes Gastrodon painfully passive. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Gastrodon to repeatedly switch in without being worn down by hazards, as they remove a large part of Gastrodon's functionality as a defensive Pokemon. Leftovers is an optional item to give Gastrodon passive recovery, but Heavy-Duty Boots is preferred due to how great ignoring hazard chip is. The spread allows Gastrodon to avoid being 3HKOed by Salamence's Hurricane and Nidoking's Earth Power while having enough defense investment to take on physical attackers such as Rhyperior and Barraskewda reliably. Gastrodon can also run a physically defensive spread, allowing it to better check Lycanroc-D, but powerful wallbreakers like Mamoswine and Diggersby can still overwhelm it easily.

Gastrodon belongs on balance and bulky offense teams, where its defensive capabilities shine the most. Grass-types such as Amoonguss are incredible for covering Gastrodon's one weakness, while Gastrodon checks the Fire-types like Moltres that would otherwise threaten them. Both Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth can also take on problematic Pokemon like Keldeo and Primarina for Gastrodon, as their powerful attacks can overwhelm it quickly. Zarude in particular enjoys the presence of Gastrodon, as it can bring Gastrodon in on annoying checks to it like Moltres. In return, Zarude can revenge kill wallbreakers like Mamoswine and Diggersby that threaten Gastrodon. Buzzwole and Celesteela can stomach physical attacks for Gastrodon while being solid Grass-resistant Pokemon. Togekiss appreciates Gastrodon taking on Electric-types like Thundurus-T and can take on Grass-types like Zarude in return. It also can function as a cleric to remove status from Gastrodon that would otherwise hinder it. Fire-types such as Chandelure and Rotom-H appreciate Gastrodon's immunity to Water-type moves, as it can switch into those attacks for them. If Gastrodon chooses to run Leftovers, entry hazard removal from the aformentioned Rotom-H and Salamence can help keep Gastrodon from getting worn down by entry hazards.

Hippowdon.overview: Hippowdon is an extremely potent mixed wall in UU thanks to its amazing bulk, solid typing, and reliable recovery. Its naturally high Defense allows it to invest in Special Defense to check Salamence and Thundurus-T while still answering physical attackers like Excadrill, Zygarde-10%, and Cobalion. Its bulk even lets it trade with threats that hit it super effectively like Tangrowth and Rotom-W and cripple them with Toxic. Hippowdon is a great Stealth Rock setter due to matching up well against common entry hazard removers like Salamence, Mandibuzz, Excadrill, and Tentacruel and easily setting Stealth Rock against Pokemon it walls like Excadrill, Cobalion, and Nihilego without Grass Knot. Utility options, like Toxic to cripple Tangrowth and Rotom-W and Whirlwind to keep setup sweepers like Scizor from setting up on it, limit Hippowdon's passivity. However, Hippowdon is still quite passive, relying on Toxic to cripple the common Grass- and Water-types that beat it; even then, threats like Zarude and RestTalk Primarina don't mind it. Certain setup sweepers like Bulky Swords Dance Scizor and Autotomize Celesteela can use Hippowdon as a free entry point, as well as setup fodder if it forgoes Whirlwind, which usually happens due to Toxic being very difficult to drop. Even Pokemon Hippowdon should check, like Nihilego, Thundurus-T, Rotom-H, and Moltres, can get around it by using coverage moves like Grass Knot or crippling it with Toxic.
Hippowdon.comments:
Other Options

Hippowdon can run a Curse set, but the presence of common Water- and Grass-types keeps this set from succeeding. Ice Fang can hit Salamence and Thundurus-T without Hippowdon relying on Toxic, while Fire Fang threatens Scizor. However, these moves fail to provide the utility Toxic provides. Heavy-Duty Boots can be used on teams without entry hazard removal to stop Spikes from wearing down Hippowdon, but it typically gets hit by Knock Off from switching into threats like Nihilego and Thundurus-T.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types and Grass-type Coverage: Zarude completely walls Hippowdon, ignoring Toxic thanks to Jungle Healing and threatening to KO it. Tangrowth and Tapu Bulu hate Toxic but can threaten Hippowdon with heavy damage. Grass-type coverage on Nihilego, Thundurus-T, and Azelf means Hippowdon must scout their movesets before switching in.

Water-types: Offensive Water-types like Keldeo, Azumarill, and Gyarados deal massive damage to Hippowdon with their attacks. Rotom-W, Slowking, and RestTalk Primarina can switch into Hippowdon well, though the former two hate Toxic.

Status Moves: Hippowdon gets worn down more easily if crippled by Toxic, with many common threats like Chansey and Swampert carrying this move. Even Pokemon Hippowdon is supposed to check like Moltres, Rotom-H, and Zygarde-10% can fit Toxic to cripple it.

Toxic-immune Setup Sweepers: Sweepers like Autotomize Celesteela, Iron Defense Skarmory, and Swords Dance Scizor use Hippowdon as setup fodder unless it fits Whirlwind, exploiting its low damage output and their immunities to Toxic.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Earthquake hits threats like Nihilego, Nidoqueen, Raikou, and Excadrill hard. Hippowdon's naturally high Attack also prevents Amoonguss from switching in for free, especially with additional sand damage and Stealth Rock, wearing it down despite Regenerator. Toxic cripples switch-ins like Slowking, Rotom-W, and Tangrowth. It also makes Hippowdon less passive against wallbreakers like Thundurus-T and Hydreigon and lets it beat Defoggers like Salamence and Rotom-W. Whirlwind is an option to phaze setup sweepers like Swords Dance Scizor and Autotomize Celesteela, but Toxic crippling so many answers to Hippowdon makes it too good to pass up most of the time. However, Whirlwind and Toxic can be run together if Hippowdon is used alongside another Stealth Rock setter like Nihilego. Slack Off gives Hippowdon reliable recovery to consistently handle threats like Salamence, Thundurus-T, and Zygarde-10%. Sand Stream helps chip down threats like Chansey and Thundurus-T, though Sand Force can be used if sand damage is detrimental to Hippowdon's team. Leftovers gives Hippowdon passive recovery and lets it spend fewer turns using Slack Off, while Rocky Helmet chips down threats like Cobalion, Scizor, and Diggersby. Rocky Helmet also lets Hippowdon counter lead Excadrill by preventing it from using Rapid Spin, allowing itself to set Stealth Rock. The given EV spread alongside an Impish nature lets Hippowdon OHKO Excadrill with Earthquake, avoid the 2HKO from Zygarde-10%'s Outrage if it has Leftovers, and better check special attackers like Salamence and Thundurus-T. If running Rocky Helmet, 112 Defense EVs are needed to avoid the 2HKO from Outrage.

Hippowdon best fits on bulky offense, balance, and stall teams that appreciate a reliable Stealth Rock setter that is also a sustainable wall. Skarmory forms a great entry hazard-stacking core with Hippowdon, providing Spikes to complement its Stealth Rock while also beating Zarude, Mamoswine, and Scizor; in return, it appreciates Hippowdon beating Defoggers it loses to like Salamence. Nihilego makes a solid partner due to it beating Autotomize Celesteela and serving as a potent Stealth Rock setter, allowing Hippowdon to run both Toxic and Whirlwind. Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss check Water-types like Keldeo, Primarina, and Azumarill for Hippowdon, with the latter also handling opposing Tangrowth. Zarude can counter Rotom-W and Slowking and switch into a predicted Grass Knot from Thundurus-T. Entry hazard removers like Mandibuzz and Tentacruel remove Spikes, which wear down Hippowdon. Mandibuzz also acts as a secondary check to Zygarde-10% and can discourage Swords Dance Scizor from boosting with the threat of Foul Play. Moltres and Salamence like Hippowdon's entry hazards and sand chip damage wearing down Slowking, and they remove Scizor, Skarmory, and Zarude for it in return. On stall teams, Umbreon can be used to increase Hippowdon's longevity with Wish and answer Mamoswine and Gyarados, while Articuno can remove status with Heal Bell.

Rhyperior.overview: Rhyperior stands out as an Electric-immune Pokemon and Stealth Rock user, as it is one of the few defensive Ground-types available, while also having the benefit of being a Flying-type resist. It has a stronger offensive presence than Swampert and more defensive utility than Nidoqueen and Krookodile with its typing that allows it to switch into Rotom-H, Crobat, Togekiss, and Salamence. Its unique Solid Rock ability also allows it to blanket check a good portion of the metagame, stomaching strong super effective hits like Bullet Punch from Scizor and Earthquake from Diggersby. Its STAB moves have reliable coverage for a majority of the metagame, covering Pokemon like Thundurus-T, Crobat, and Galarian Slowbro hard and threatening common entry hazard removers such as Salamence and Rotom-H. However, it remains vulnerable to common Grass-, Water-, and Fighting-types such as Zarude, Primarina, and Keldeo, which threaten to KO it with little to no chip. Regenerator users like Tangrowth, Slowking, and Amoonguss are annoying too, as they can take a majority of Rhyperior's attacks just to heal off with a switch or immediately pressure it with a STAB attack. Powerful wallbreakers like Nidoking, Mamoswine, Conkeldurr, and Hydreigon can muscle past Rhyperior easily, taking advantage of its reliance on Leftovers for recovery. Rhyperior faces severe competition from other Stealth Rock setters like Excadrill and Nihilego who provide better defensive utility because of their typings and check more relevant threats. Hippowdon in particular largely outclasses Hippowdon thanks to its access to Slack Off, allowing it to consistently check foes like Salamence, as well as offset Spikes damage. It only being 2x weak to Grass- and Water-types means it can afford to stay in against foes like Tangrowth and Rotom-W and cripple them with Toxic, something Rhyperior cannot do.
Rhyperior.comments:
Other Options

Choice Band Rhyperior can be a strong wallbreaker but is outclassed by Lycanroc-D, which has a better Speed tier to take advantage of its coverage with. Megahorn can improve Rhyperior's matchup against Psychic-types like Reuniculus while OHKOing Zarude. High Horsepower can be used over Earthquake to avoid being weakened by Grassy Terrain but is only worth the decreased power and accuracy when Tapu Bulu is on the same team.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Primarina, Azumarill, and Rotom-W all have the bulk to switch into Rhyperior and can OHKO it with a STAB move. RestTalk Primarina and Pain Split Rotom-W can be especially difficult to wear down.

Fighting-types: Rhyperior is forced out by common Fighting-types such as Keldeo and Conkeldurr. Keldeo can threaten Rhyperior out with 4x super effective STAB moves and proceed to set up or use Flip Turn. Conkeldurr can stomach a hit and regain lost health with Drain Punch.

Grass-types and Grass-type Coverage: Amoonguss and Tangrowth can sponge anything Rhyperior throws at them and heal back with Regenerator or threaten it with a STAB move. Tapu Bulu weakens Rhyperior's Earthquake with its Grassy Terrain and can switch into its moves. Zarude can outspeed and OHKO Rhyperior with Power Whip. Rhyperior also has to be careful of Grass-type coverage from Pokemon like Nihilego, Thundurus-T, and Azelf as well.

Status: Pokemon that Rhyperior frequently pivots against such as defensive Salamence and Rotom-H can wear it down with Toxic and make it hard to deal with them throughout the match.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Stone Edge and Earthquake are Rhyperior's best STAB moves with consistent power, threatening common Pokemon like Crobat, Salamence, and Cobalion. Toxic cripples switch-ins like Tangrowth, Slowking, and Hippowdon. Heat Crash is an option to keep Amoonguss, Scizor, and Skarmory from switching into it, 2HKOing all of them. Swords Dance lets Rhyperior set up on Pokemon that it can wall like Rotom-H to muscle past slower foes such as Amoonguss and Celesteela. Rhyperior runs maximum Special Defense investment to take advantage of its typing, being able to switch into moves such as Rotom-H's Overheat and Salamence's Hurricane more comfortably.

Rhyperior tends to fit on bulky offense teams with its amount of resistances in combination with its offensive presence. Rhyperior appreciates entry hazard removal from Tentacruel and Rotom-W to keep it from getting worn down by Spikes. In return, Rhyperior can switch into Rotom-H and check Thundurus-T. Electric-types like Thundurus-T beat opposing Water-types that could break through Rhyperior with ease such as Azumarill and Primarina. Thundurus-T appreciates entry hazard support wearing down checks like Tapu Bulu in return. Bulky Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss can help against those Water-types in addition to Keldeo and Rotom-W. Both Tangrowth and Amoonguss benefit from Rhyperior countering Rotom-H and Moltres. Steel-types such as Jirachi and Scizor appreciate Rhyperior's Fire resistance and ability to check Moltres and Rotom-H too, and, in return, they can check Tapu Bulu. Jirachi can also provide Wish support for Rhyperior so it can be played more aggressively early-game. Tapu Bulu itself also can provide Grassy Terrain support and check Water-types like Azumarill for Rhyperior.

Tangrowth.overview: Tangrowth's stellar ability in Regenerator, massive defense stat, good defensive typing, and solid offensive presence makes Tangrowth one of the best walls in the tier. Tangrowth typically operates with an Assault Vest set, becoming a mixed wall that can check threats like Primarina and Thundurus-T on the special end and Excadrill and Zygarde-10% on the physical end. Meanwhile, full investment in physical defense lets it check Zygarde-10%, Zarude, and Conkeldurr more reliably. Access to coverage moves like Knock Off, Focus Blast, and Sludge Bomb let Tangrowth severely cripple defensive Pokemon such as Chansey, Cobalion, and Salamence, with physically defensive sets even utilizing Sleep Powder to shut down Scizor. However, Tangrowth is still incredibly vulnerable to types like Poison, Flying, and Fire, causing it to run from threats like Amoonguss, Crobat, and Salamence. Tangrowth faces competition from Amoonguss as a defensive Grass-type, as the latter's Poison typing lets it check threats like Primarina, Keldeo, and opposing Tangrowth more reliably; it can also put foes to sleep more reliably thanks to Spore. However, Tangrowth's huge Defense, generally lower passivity, and ability to cripple walls like Chansey with Knock Off are invaluable. Tangrowth hates being setup fodder for Pokemon like Scizor and Galarian Slowbro, which often force it to switch out against them, and its abysmal Special Defense means its physically defensive set struggles against special attackers like Primarina and Thundurus-T. Finally, Assault Vest Tangrowth is prone to Knock Off from Pokemon it would check, like Azelf, which defeats its role as a special wall.
Tangrowth.comments:
Other Options

Leech Seed is an option to wear down switch-ins like Scizor, but it is easily avoided by switching out and by pivoting from Pokemon like Rotom-W and Moltres. Other Pokemon like opposing Tangrowth, Hatterene, and Amoonguss are not affected by Leech Seed, making it hard to justify using over Giga Drain's immediate recovery. Stun Spore can be considered to slow down and cripple Pokemon like Nidoking, Salamence, and Tentacruel, but its accuracy is shaky and common Pokemon like Thundurus-T and Amoonguss are immune to it.

Checks and Counters

Steel-types: Many of the tier's Steel-types can switch directly into Tangrowth. Skarmory completely blanks Tangrowth and can set Spikes against it for free. Celesteela forces physically defensive Tangrowth out with Flamethrower and cripples Assault Vest variants with Toxic, but hates taking Knock Off. Scizor can use both Tangrowth sets as setup bait, though it hates a possible Sleep Powder.

Poison-types: Nidoqueen, Nihilego, Amoonguss, and Tentacruel can hit Tangrowth with their respective STAB moves, and Tentacruel can also damage Tangrowth with Liquid Ooze if it ever uses Giga Drain. Since they force Tangrowth out with offensive pressure, the former two can use it to set Stealth Rock. Amoonguss takes little from Tangrowth's moves and only dislikes Knock Off, forcing Tangrowth to switch out; this gives Amoonguss a free opportunity to put one of Tangrowth's teammate to sleep via Spore. Tentacruel can remove Tangrowth's Assault Vest with Knock Off.

Fire-types: Tangrowth is extremely pressured by Fire-types such as Rotom-H, Moltres, and Chandelure and is almost always forced out. The former two can use Volt Switch or U-turn, respectively, to predict a switch and keep momentum, but Tangrowth can stomach a Fire-type attack from them and remove their item with Knock Off in return if needed.

Special Attackers: Even with an Assault Vest, Azelf, Salamence, and Hydreigon can all get past Tangrowth with their powerful super effective STAB attacks.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
Power Whip is near-mandatory to beat Substitute + Calm Mind Primarina while also dealing greater damage to the likes of Zygarde-10%, Keldeo, and Slowking. Alternatively, Giga Drain allows Tangrowth to sustain its health on the field while dealing good damage to Pokemon like Conkeldurr and Keldeo, though it sacrifices the Primarina matchup. Leaf Storm is another option to deal massive damage to Hippowdon, which otherwise can afford to stay in on Power Whip and cripple Tangrowth with Toxic. Knock Off is extremely useful for crippling common Tangrowth answers like Salamence and Crobat. Sludge Bomb has a decent chance to poison foes like Salamence and is also Tangrowth's best way to hit Zarude and opposing Tangrowth. Focus Blast hits Hydreigon and Cobalion for heavy damage. Earthquake is another option used to pressure Pokemon such as Tentacruel and Nihilego. Assault Vest boosts Tangrowth's miserable Special Defense stat, allowing it to pivot in on Pokemon it normally can't, such as Primarina, Keldeo, and Thundurus-T. The given EV spread allows Tangrowth to avoid the 2HKO from Zygarde-10%'s Outrage while also being able to take a +2 Megahorn from Cobalion.

Tangrowth acts as an effective glue on many playstyles, being a reliable defensive pivot that sponges attacks from scary wallbreakers such as Primarina and Thundurus-T. However, Tangrowth can still be overwhelmed by Choice Specs Primarina and Nasty Plot Thundurus-T, so it can't face them alone. Teammates such as Chansey and Nihilego appreciate Tangrowth's ability to cripple these offensive threats and help check foes like Moltres, Skarmory, and Salamence in return. Tangrowth can't take Fire- and Ice-type attacks from threats such as Moltres and Mamoswine, so teammates like Slowking and Swampert are appreciated. They also act as secondary checks to Zygarde-10%. Despite the amazing Regenerator, Tangrowth is extremely prone to being weakened by Stealth Rock and Spikes, so entry hazard removers like Excadrill and Salamence prevent it from being too worn down. Moltres scares out Amoonguss and Skarmory for Tangrowth. Cobalion helps act as a secondary check to Zarude since Tangrowth cannot chip it due to having an Assault Vest. It also absorbs Knock Off for it.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description:
Knock Off lets Tangrowth cripple switch-ins such as Celesteela, Mandibuzz, Aegislash, and Chansey. Sludge Bomb helps Tangrowth to not be setup fodder for Gyarados and does heavy damage to Tapu Bulu, Hatterene, and opposing Tangrowth. Sludge Bomb's poison chance also helps Tangrowth potentially cripple switch-ins like Salamence and Moltres. Alternatively, Focus Blast can keep Cobalion from having free entry into Tangrowth. Sleep Powder can put foes like Scizor to sleep that would otherwise set up on Tangrowth. Synthesis provides another method of recovery for Tangrowth, allowing it to check threats like Azumarill easier without switching out or attacking. Rocky Helmet allows Tangrowth to punish physical attackers like Lycanroc-D, Azumarill, and Zarude.

Tangrowth fits very well on archetypes like bulky offense, balance, and stall, which appreciate its defensive capabilities and the utility it provides. Because of Tangrowth's miserable Special Defense, partners that can take on special attackers for it such as Chansey and Celesteela are very appreciated. Chansey can take on Pokemon like Primarina and Hydreigon and set Stealth Rock; its Toxic wearing down common Tangrowth checks such as Moltres is also very appreciated. Water-types such as Rotom-W and Slowking can take strong Fire- and Ice-type attacks for Tangrowth and check threats such as Chandelure and Mamoswine. Slowking also checks Keldeo for Tangrowth. These Water-types appreciate Tangrowth pivoting directly into Zarude and Tapu Bulu. Excadill and Salamence in particular also work as entry hazard removers, and Tangrowth needs this help to avoid getting too weakened. Ground-types such as Excadrill like having Tangrowth as a teammate, as it can take on Water-types such as Azumarill for them.

Togekiss.overview: Togekiss's typing, Roost, and Nasty Plot make it a bulky wallbreaker and a check to top threats like Zarude, Krookodile, and Kommo-o. It's also an amazing stallbreaker, as it can beat Chansey and Quagsire with flinches thanks to Nasty Plot and Heal Bell. However, Togekiss requires heavy support to break through common Pokemon such as Rhyperior, Aegislash, and Rotom-W. It hates Knock Off, as losing Heavy-Duty Boots greatly reduces its ability to check Pokemon like Buzzwole and Kommo-o with Stealth Rock up. Togekiss is outsped by a majority of offensive Pokemon such as Nidoking and Lycanroc-D. It's also very weak before a Nasty Plot boost and is very passive against offensive teams if it lacks Thunder Wave.
Togekiss.comments:
Other Options

Defog can be potentially run on a more defensive utility set, but Togekiss cannot threaten common Stealth Rock users such as Jirachi and Nihilego. Choice Scarf + Trick can outspeed Pokemon such as Keldeo and cripple walls such as Chansey and Umbreon. However, it is very matchup dependent and means Togekiss has to worry about Stealth Rock. Grass Knot can be used to lure in and nail Rhyperior on the offensive set, but Flamethrower is better due to hitting Steel-types such as Celesteela and Aegislash.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Thundurus-T, Rotom-W, and Rotom-H resist Air Slash and are immune to Thunder Wave, turning Togekiss into setup fodder for them.

Rock-types: Rhyperior shrugs off Air Slash and is immune to Thunder Wave. Lycanroc-D and Nihilego can outspeed and remove Togekiss, though they must watch out for Thunder Wave.

Steel-types: Celesteela and Aegislash can switch into Air Slash and threaten Togekiss out with their STAB attacks. Due to their lower Speed, they can potentially lose to flinches. Faster Steel-types such as Jirachi and Cobalion only fear Thunder Wave.

Poison-types: Tentacruel and Nidoking can outspeed and deal heavy damage to Togekiss. Assault Vest Galarian Slowbro can take multiple hits with its high special bulk, though must be careful of repeated flinches.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Nasty Plot allows Togekiss to break through bulkier teams by setting up on passive Pokemon such as Chansey, Tangrowth, and Umbreon. Heal Bell gives Togekiss and its team status removal for Toxic Aegislash, Will-O-Wisp Rotom-W, and stall staples such as Chansey and Umbreon. Thunder Wave slows down faster Pokemon such as Nihilego and stacks well with Serene Grace Air Slash. It can also act as an emergency check to Dragon Dance Salamence and Necrozma. Roost allows Togekiss to better check Krookodile, Zarude, and Buzzwole throughout a game. Maximum HP and Speed investment allows Togekiss to better check Pokemon such as Kommo-o and outspeed Buzzwole. A set with Flamethrower and a more offensive spread of 76 HP / 180 SpA / 252 Spe can be used to OHKO offensive Aegislash after a Nasty Plot boost.

Togekiss is a good pick on bulky offense and balance due to its great matchup against stall. Rhyperior and Seismitoad provide an Electric immunity to deal with Thundurus-T and the Rotom formes, can use Stealth Rock, and help weaken Pokemon such as Krookodile. Choice Scarf Krookodile and Aegislash can handle Pokemon such as Nihilego, Galarian Slowbro, and Lycanroc-D, while Togekiss can handle Buzzwole. Knock Off absorbers such as Amoonguss and Buzzwole can help Togekiss keep Heavy-Duty Boots, particularly against Krookodile. Buzzwole appreciates Togekiss slowing down threats such as Nihilego with Thunder Wave, and Togekiss appreciates Buzzwole breaking through Rhyperior, Celesteela, and Chansey. Fire-types like Volcanion and Entei can remove Steel-types such as Aegislash and Celesteela. Volcanion also threatens Rock-types like Rhyperior, while Entei can wear down Pokemon with Sacred Fire burns. Zygarde-10% and Mamoswine help Togekiss break through Poison-types such as Tentacruel and Nidoking. Primarina and Kommo-o greatly benefit from stall teams being worn down to enable cleanup.

Mamoswine.overview: Mamoswine is a very powerful wallbreaker in UU due to its amazing offensive typing that allows it to muscle through common walls like Tangrowth, Hippowdon, and Chansey. Ice Shard also gives it a priority option to threaten many faster threats like Thundurus-T, Zygarde-10%, and Salamence, allowing it to fit on teams as a potent revenge killer. Knock Off provides great utility to punish common switch-ins such as Rotom-H and Rotom-W. Unfortunately, Mamoswine has low defenses, below-average speeed, and a bad defensive typing, making it easy prey for common threats like Scizor, Keldeo, and Rotom-W. Without Thick Fat, it has virtually no defensive utility outside of switching into Electric-type attacks, and even then it cannot always check certain Electric-type threats, like Thundurus-T, which lives an Ice Shard from full and KOes back with Focus Blast. Other Ground-type wallbreakers like Excadrill and Zygarde-10% offer better defensive utility and greater Speed, respectively. Mamoswine is prone to wearing itself down between Life Orb recoil and entry hazards, limiting its ability to wallbreak throughout a game.
Mamoswine.comments:
Other Options

Choice Band can be used for more power without the recoil created by Life Orb, but Mamoswine prefers to be able to switch up its moves. Heavy-Duty Boots is another viable option for Mamoswine's item that prevents it from being worn down by entry hazards and Life Orb recoil while still retaining some wallbreaking power. Mamoswine can be used as a Stealth Rock setter but removing any of Mamoswine's four main moves severely limits its wallbreaking potential. Freeze-Dry is an option to OHKO Quagsire and nearly OHKO Swampert with Life Orb as well as better pressure Rotom-W. The utility offered by Knock Off is generally better, though, as it does nearly the same amount of damage as Freeze-Dry to Rotom-W, and Mamoswine can already nearly 2HKO Gastrodon and Quagsire with Earthquake. A Choice Scarf set allows Mamoswine to outspeed its typical fast checks like Zarude and Lycanroc-D, but this set faces a lot of competition from Diggersby, which also has access to U-turn to pivot out of unfavourable matchups.

Checks and Counters

Physical Walls: Mamoswine struggles to break through Skarmory, as it can stomach multiple Icicle Crashes and recover any lost health with Roost while also forcing it out with Body Press. However, Skarmory does need to be careful of taking on Mamoswine if it has taken lots of chip, as a flinch from Icicle Crash can lead to it being KOd. Colbur Berry Slowking also is a strong answer to Mamoswine, being able to take Knock Off and Earthquake well and KO it back with Scald. Swampert and Umbreon can trade damage with Mamoswine, but they can get overwhelmed between having their Leftovers removed and switching in and taking entry hazards.

Rotom-H and Rotom-W: Both Rotom-W and Rotom-H are immune to Earthquake and resist Ice, making it difficult for Mamoswine to break through them. Additionally, both of these Pokemon can typically force Mamoswine out with STAB attacks or status moves, though they need to be wary of Knock Off on the switch.

Faster Pokemon and Priority Users: UU has many threats like Cobalion, Gyarados, and Keldeo that are faster than Mamoswine and threaten to KO it with super effective attacks. Mamoswine is also weak to multiple priority attacks, allowing Scizor, Azumarill, and Conkeldurr to KO it after minimal chip.

Residual Damage: Since Mamoswine typically needs Life Orb to be effective, it will get worn down quickly, especially if it has to switch into Stealth Rock or Spikes.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Icicle Crash and Earthquake are a devastatingly powerful STAB combination, easily KOing common walls like Amoonguss, Primarina, and Mandibuzz. Ice Shard can threaten many faster threats like Thundurus-T and Zarude, and it can also OHKO offensive Salamence and Zygarde-10%. Knock Off is used to punish and cripple switch-ins like Rotom-H and Rotom-W, allowing Mamoswine or another teammate to break past them more easily later. Oblivious keeps Mamoswine from having its Attack lowered by Intimidate Salamence. Thick Fat in an option that offers better protection against Rotom-H and ensures it can take a Flamethrower from Moltres. Life Orb is preferred, as it allows Mamoswine to safely 2HKO almost anything in the tier, including Celesteela and Chansey. However, Never-Melt Ice also is an option to retain a powerful Icicle Crash while not wearing itself down with Life Orb, but this comes at the cost of a much weaker Earthquake, missing out on a 2HKO on Slowking, even after Stealth Rock. An Adamant Nature maximizes Mamoswine's wallbreaking potential.

Mamoswine best functions on offensive teams that provide it many opportunities to wallbreak. Late-game cleaners like Azelf appreciate Mamoswine's early-game wallbreaking and can deal with faster threats like Cobalion and Keldeo as well as walls like Skarmory. Azelf also wears down Slowking, allowing Mamoswine to break through it easier. Pivots like Zarude, Rotom-W, and Slowking lure in Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss and then pivot to Mamoswine for a more favorable matchup; Slowking in particular provides slow pivoting with Teleport to get Mamoswine in safely. Mamoswine is vulnerable to priority moves from Conkeldurr, Scizor, and Azumarill; Amoonguss can switch into most of their attacks. Entry hazard support from Cobalion and Nihilego can wear down Pokemon like Skarmory and Umbreon for Mamoswine to break past them more easily. Counterplay against Scizor is essential to keep Mamoswine from being revenge killed by Bullet Punch; the aformentioned Cobalion and Rotom-H serve as solid checks to it. Similarly, entry hazard control from Excadrill and Tentacruel can remove opposing entry hazards that would wear Mamoswine down. Primarina helps overwhelm Celesteela and Slowking for Mamoswine and takes on Keldeo.

Rotom-Heat.overview: Rotom-H's unique typing generates a solid offensive and defensive profile that grants it a good place in the metagame. As an Electric-type pivot, it distinguishes itself from Rotom-W and Thundurus-T thanks to its ability to immediately threaten and wipe out common Grass-type walls like Amoonguss and Tangrowth. Its typing also gives it the resistances to check Pokemon like Celesteela, Moltres, Scizor, Mamoswine. However, Rotom-H lacks reliable recovery, meaning it can get overwhelmed when trying to check multiple foes like Thundurus-T + Mamoswine. Pokemon it wants to switch into like Scizor and Tangrowth can remove its Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off, and most entry hazard setters, including Swampert, Hippowdon, Excadrill, and Nihilego, can beat it, though Swampert and Hippowdon fear Toxic. It's also outsped and KOed by various common threats such as Keldeo, Hydreigon, and Zygarde-10%. Rotom-W gives Rotom-H massive competition due to its ability to immediately threaten Ground-types like Hippowdon and Nidoking, allowing it to have a nearly unblockable Volt Switch.
Rotom-Heat.comments:
Other Options

Nasty Plot + Pain Split turns Rotom-H into a dangerous wallbreaker with the longevity needed to still check Scizor and Tangrowth, breaking through traditional checks like Hippowdon while targeting Fire-resistant Pokemon like Slowking. However, Rotom-H has an only average Speed tier and is subject to being overwhelmed by common Pokemon like Keldeo, Nihilego, and Hydreigon. Defog can be used against Pokemon Rotom-H forces out like Amoonguss, Jirachi, Celesteela, and Moltres, but Rotom-H loses to common Stealth Rock setters like Hippowdon and Nihilego. Furthermore, it must forego Pain Split, leaving it with limited longevity taking on Pokemon it should check like Scizor and Mamowswine. Choice Scarf + Trick cripples common Rotom-H answers like Chansey and Swampert and revenge kills +1 Gyarados. However, Trick sacrifices another valuable moveslot, and using Choice Scarf hampers Rotom-H's longevity by leaving it vulnerable to Stealth Rock.

Checks and Counters

Chansey: Chansey walls Rotom-H with its enormous special bulk, wears it down with Toxic, and keeps itself healthy with Soft-Boiled, but it has to be wary of Pain Split due to the huge amount of HP Rotom-H receives.

Rock-types: Lycanroc-D and Nihilego outspeed and OHKO Rotom-H, the latter of which being a reliable switch-in. Rhyperior can take Overheat with relative ease and OHKO back with Stone Edge. Nihilego and Rhyperior can also set Stealth Rock in front of Rotom-H.

Ground-types: Swampert, Hippowdon, and Nidoqueen all block Volt Switch and can threaten Rotom-H with massive damage or status, although the former two hate Toxic while the latter doesn't like taking Overheat. Zygarde-10% and Excadrill are both notable for outspeeding and OHKOing Rotom-H by getting past Levitate, the former using Thousand Arrows and the latter utilizing Mold Breaker Earthquake.

Water-types: Keldeo, Starmie, and Tentacruel all outspeed and threaten Rotom-H. Rotom-W, Slowking, and Primarina take Volt Switch well and threaten Rotom-H back with super effective damage. Crawduant and Azumarill can pick off Rotom-H with priority Aqua Jet.

Knock Off: Rotom-H hates Knock Off, as it loses its Heavy-Duty Boots and becomes susceptible to Stealth Rock. Pokemon Rotom-H normally would check like Mamoswine, Scizor, and Tangrowth can heavily hinder it, allowing them to overcome Rotom-H in the long-term as it takes additional damage from Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
Overheat and Volt Switch have good synergy, letting Rotom-H hit hard and then pivot. Toxic cripples most defensive answers to Rotom-H, such as Swampert, Hydreigon, and Hippowdon. Pain Split serves as Rotom-H's only recovery tool, taking advantage of checks that can consistently recover their HP such as Salamence and Chansey. Heavy-Duty Boots lets Rotom-H get onto the field safely and pivot more frequently. 152 Speed EVs let Rotom-H outspeed Modest Nidoking and nail it with a powerful Overheat, with the remaining EVs in HP and Defense to better check Scizor.

Rotom-H fits on bulky offense, VoltTurn, and balance teams that appreciate its ability to form a VoltTurn cores with Pokemon like Scizor and break through common foes like Amoonguss and Scizor. Additional pivots are essential teammates for Rotom-H; Scizor covers Rotom-H's weakness to Rock-types like Nihilego and Lycanroc-D, brings Rotom-H in against Skarmory and Celesteela with U-turn, and counters Hippowdon and Chansey. Slowking is a slow pivot that can switch into offensive checks like Keldeo and Nihilego for Rotom-H. Additionally, Amoonguss, Tangrowth and Zarude make for great partners, destroying Water-, Rock-, and Ground-types like Keldeo, Lycanroc-D, Zygarde-10%, and Hippowdon that trouble Rotom-H. In return, Rotom-H takes care of Steel- and Flying-types like Celesteela, Scizor, and Moltres. Krookodile is another useful teammate, as Rotom-H brings it in safely against foes like Nihilego and Chansey. Rotom-H also pressures Skarmory for Krookodile, and together they deal with Thundurus-T. Togekiss counters Hydreigon and Salamence for Rotom-H and can remove status with Heal Bell. Wallbreakers that are frail or slow, like Thundurus-T, Zygarde-10%, and Primarina, appreciate Rotom-H bringing them in safely against Pokemon such as Rotom-W and Salamence.

Rotom-Wash.overview: Rotom-W's typing and Levitate allow it to be an effective pivot that comes in against notable threats such as Mamoswine, Moltres, Pelipper, and Celesteela. Rotom-W can act as an effective entry hazard remover due to its great matchup against common entry hazard setters like Rhyperior and Krookodile. Other utility options like Pain Split and Will-O-Wisp allow it to make progress even when the opponent switches to its checks and counters. Its Choice Scarf set is also notable for addtionally providing solid speed control while still acting as a Ground-type immunity and hazard removal. Sadly, Rotom-W's poor HP stat in conjunction with its reliance on Leftovers and Pain Split for recovery holds back its ability to act as a reliable pivot and exacerbates its vulnerability to poison, burn, and Stealth Rock damage. While Rotom-W does have some useful resistances, it needs to be healthy or used with prediction to pivot against foes that can potentially dent it greatly, such as Ground-types that have a strong secondary STAB move like Nidoking and Diggersby.
Rotom-Wash.comments:
Other Options

Rocky Helmet has the benefit of punishing the likes of Jirachi for spamming U-turn or contact moves, though losing the passive recovery from Leftovers is not ideal. Maximum Defense investment with a Bold nature makes Rotom-W a more effective pivot against Keldeo and Mamoswine, but the loss in Speed hampers it against foes like Nidoking and Chandelure. Nasty Plot + Pain Split turns Rotom-W into a wallbreaker, but it still has immense problems with Grass-types. This set also sacrifices Volt Switch in favor of Thunderbolt or Discharge, which makes the matchup against Grass-types even worse. Rindo Berry can be used if the team is too weak to Dragon Dance Gyarados, as it can prevent an OHKO from +2 Adamant Power Whip and provide a safety net against Tapu Bulu if Will-O-Wisp misses.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types and Grass-type Coverage: Rotom-W cannot deal any significant damage to the likes of Tangrowth and Amoonguss aside from burning them. Though Tapu Bulu dislikes Will-O-Wisp, it can still threaten Rotom-W with Horn Leech to restore health. Zarude can use Jungle Healing to disregard status completely. However, all of them lose momentum to Volt Switch as they switch in. Rotom-W also must watch out for Grass-type coverage on Pokemon like Gyarados and Azelf.

Dragon-types: Kommo-o only dislikes status from Rotom-W and is able to freely set up with Clangorous Soul. Zygarde-10%'s Thousand Arrows ignores Levitate, meaning it heavily punishes teams that solely rely on Rotom-W to deal with Ground-types. Salamence outspeed and nails Rotom-W with a powerful Draco Meteor.

Seismitoad and Gastrodon: Seismitoad and Gastrodon shut down Rotom-W nearly completely if it is not carrying Toxic. Seismitoad can cripple Rotom-W with Toxic and is the only Stealth Rock setter that is immune to both Hydro Pump and Volt Switch, and Gastrodon does not care much about Will-O-Wisp.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
Volt Switch is required so Rotom-W can gain momentum against Grass- and Dragon-types such as Tangrowth and Kommo-o while bringing in teammates like Chandelure and Primarina to threaten them. Hydro Pump destroys common entry hazard setters such as Rhyperior and Krookodile. Pain Split is Rotom-W's only recovery move and gives Rotom-W more utility against bulkier teams, though it can be easy to play around. Will-O-Wisp cripples Amoonguss, Dragon Dance Salamence, and Tangrowth. Other status moves can be used over Will-O-Wisp; Toxic limits Seismitoad and Gastrodon's longevity better, whereas Thunder Wave cripples Noivern and Kommo-o. Defog is an alternative option because Rotom-W has several opportunities to remove hazards, such as when facing Celesteela and Jirachi, while having a good matchup against many of the entry hazard setters. Leftovers is Rotom-W's primary way of standing up to repeated U-turn and Stealth Rock damage. Maximum Speed EVs allow Rotom-W to outspeed and OHKO Nidoking as well as potentially cripple offensive Kommo-o with Will-O-Wisp.

Rotom-W fits on bulky offense and balance teams, which appreciate its ability to check Mamoswine and Moltres. U-turn users such as Zarude and Moltres form VoltTurn cores with Rotom-W that can be difficult to stop, as Rotom-W threatens their checks such as Rotom-H and Rhyperior. Rotom-W appreciates Moltres's ability to pressure Grass-types such as Amoonguss and Tangrowth. Wallbreakers such as Buzzwole, Entei, and Nidoking appreciate Rotom-W's Volt Switch allowing them to pressure defensive cores relying on Pokemon such as Chansey and Tangrowth. Grass-types such as Tangrowth and Zarude can help remove Seismitoad and Gastrodon and patch any weaknesses against Zygarde-10%. Zarude also forms a VoltTurn core with Rotom-W and appreciates Rotom-W sponging Krookodile's Knock Off if its item is still required, this being particularly important for Choice Scarf variants.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Rotom is effective at revenge killing targets like Krookodile, Entei, and Lycanroc-D with Hydro Pump. Volt Switch helps Rotom-W offensively threaten foes such as +1 Gyarados, Keldeo, and Starmie. Thunderbolt can be used over Volt Switch to apply more reliable pressure against foes like Mantine and Galarian Moltres, although Volt Switch is more consistent. Defog allows Rotom-W to remove entry hazards before being KOed or as it forces out Pokemon like Mantine and Moltres. Pain Split over Defog gives Rotom-W more longevity. However, finding other options for entry hazard removal can be challenging and create more strain on teambuilding. Trick is vital because it cripples defensive pivots such as Chansey, Amoonguss, and Tangrowth. However, Rotom-W should only use Trick after the additional Speed is no longer necessary, as it will no longer be able to outspeed threats such as Lycanroc-D and Zygarde-10%. Choice Scarf allows Rotom-W to revenge kill threats such as Lycanroc-D and Krookodile as well as maintain momentum against other Pokemon that would otherwise outspeed and deal massive damage such as Salamence. The additional speed also helps Rotom-W scout and maintain momentum against unfavorable matchups such as Zarude and Roserade more reliably.

Choice Scarf Rotom-W fits best on offense, balance, and bulky offense teams that appreciate its role compression as a Ground-immune offensive pivot and revenge killer that provides momentum and emergency entry hazard removal. Other pivots such as Mienshao form a potent VoltTurn core with Rotom-W, as they overwhelm each other's checks; Mienshao deals with Chansey and Zarude, while Rotom-W deals with Moltres and Nihilego. Entry hazard setters such as Jirachi, Nihilego, and Krookodile wear down targets for Rotom-W. The former is able to form a VoltTurn core with Rotom-W, while the latter two can cripple Pokemon such as Aegislash and Salamence with Knock Off. Wallbreakers such as Entei, Nidoking, and Mamoswine are fantastic partner that break through Pokemon Rotom-W grants them safe entry on, such as Tangrowth, Amoonguss, and Galarian Slowbro. Hatterene deals with Pokemon that would otherwise take advantage of Rotom-W like Seismitoad and Kommo-o. Hatterene's Magic Bounce also assists Rotom-W in its role as entry hazard control and makes Rotom-W more comfortable with running Pain Split. Rotom-W's role compression means it can struggle against Entei and Jirachi in the long-term, so teammates such as RestTalk Primarina, Aegislash, and Moltres help relieve pressure.

Azelf.overview: Azelf is a premier offensive threat in UU due to its elite Speed, high Special Attack, and large movepool. U-turn and Knock Off make it a great offensive pivot that cripples checks like Mandibuzz and Chansey, while coverage moves like Flamethrower, Energy Ball, and Dazzling Gleam allow it to threaten staples like Celesteela, Slowking, and Hydreigon. Meanwhile, Nasty Plot Azelf is a dangerous wallbreaker that threatens specially defensive Pokemon like Chansey, Celesteela, and Assault Vest Tangrowth. It's fast enough to outspeed and KO many other speedy Pokemon like Keldeo and Nihilego, only being naturally outsped by Noivern, Crobat, and the niche Salazzle. Though Azelf is powerful, its frailty means that it has to pivot out or make outright KOs if it wants to last long-term. Common Choice Scarf users like Hydreigon and Diggersby can KO or use U-turn against Azelf, and Azelf is quite vulnerable from priority attacks such as Lycanroc-D's Accelerock and Scizor's Bullet Punch. Azelf's great coverage is limited by its moveslots, as a pivot set will have to often choose between Knock Off for support, Energy Ball to threaten Hippowdon, Swampert, and Primarina, and Dazzling Gleam to better handle Dark-types like Hydreigon and Mandibuzz. Nasty Plot faces a similar conundrum, often choosing between Energy Ball and Dazzling Gleam. Thundurus-T gives Azelf stiff competition as both an offensive pivot and a Nasty Plot sweeper. While Azelf is faster and is better equipped to handle threats like Nihilego, Thundurus-T has a better defensive typing, higher Special Attack, and Electric-type STAB moves for threatening common defensive Pokemon that Azelf struggles to beat like Mandibuzz and Slowking.
Azelf.comments:
Other Options

Choice Specs gives Azelf immense power behind its attacks, threatening to OHKO Assault Vest Tangrowth after Stealth Rock as well as deal more damage to bulky foes like Primarina. A Choice Band set takes advantage of Azelf's high Attack stat to act as an incredibly strong pivot with U-turn, Knock Off, and solid options in Zen Headbutt, Ice Punch, Explosion, and Trick. While this can be effective on some teams, other Choice Band users like Zygarde-10% and Crawduant offer more spammable high-power attacks in Thousand Arrows and STAB Knock Off. Choice Scarf can be used to surprise other Choice Scarf users like Zarude and Hydreigon, as well as faster threats like Crobat. However, this set is very situational and will oftentimes not have much utility compared to other Choice Scarf users like Jirachi, which can spam Iron Head and use Healing Wish in addition to pivoting. Azelf is also naturally fast and doesn't need Choice Scarf to outspeed most unboosted foes. Azelf can act as a Stealth Rock setter, but it should only be used if the team has no other viable options. While Azelf also gets Taunt to prevent Defog, the prevalence of Pokemon like Excadrill that can both spin on Azelf, threaten it with Earthquake thanks to Mold Breaker, and also set up Stealth Rock itself, makes Stealth Rock Azelf less optimal. A Pokemon like Cobalion, Nihilego, or the aforementioned Excadrill is generally a better option for setting up Stealth Rock.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Pokemon like Umbreon and Mandibuzz stop most Azelf sets and can easily threaten to KO it in return, although having their item removed with Knock Off makes them much less effective in their defensive roles. More offensive Pokemon like Choice Scarf Zarude and Hydreigon outspeed and OHKO Azelf, and Hydreigon can also switch into non-Pivot Azelf if it is not running Dazzling Gleam.

Faster Threats and Priority: Choice Scarf users such as Zarude, Hydreigon, Jirachi, and Diggersby deal significant damage to Azelf with U-turn or simply OHKO it with a strong attack. Noivern, Crobat, and Salazzle outspeed Azelf naturally and also threaten heavy damage. Priority move users like Scizor, Mamoswine, and Azumarill can pick off a chipped Azelf.

Special Walls: Pokemon with high Special Defense like Chansey, Celesteela, Hippowdon, and Slowking can withstand Azelf's attacks and hinder it with chip damage or status, and Chansey and Slowing can often use Teleport to bring in an offensive check. However, the former two hate Knock Off and the latter three fear coverage options like Flamethrower and Energy Ball. Even Chansey is 2HKOed by +2 Psyshock with Life Orb.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
Psychic is Azelf's strongest and usually preferred STAB move, dealing big damage to the likes of Thundurus-T and Amoonguss, but Psyshock is an option to OHKO Nihilego and deal more damage to Tentacruel and Calm Mind users like Primarina and Keldeo. Flamethrower hits a wide range of defensive Pokemon like Scizor, Skarmory, and Tangrowth, while Fire Blast is a stronger option to help finish off Celesteela and Tangrowth, but the difference in damage is often not worth the accuracy drop. U-turn is Azelf's key move on this set, as its high Speed allows it to pivot out of danger from Pokemon like Mandibuzz and bring in a teammate safely. Azelf's last moves usually depend on the item it is running. If running Expert Belt, Energy Ball or Dazzling Gleam should be used. Energy Ball is the preferred final move to wipe out common foes like Slowking, Hippowdon, and Mamoswine, notably 2HKOing the former two and OHKOing the latter with the Expert Belt boost. Meanwhile, Dazzling Gleam is an option for Dragon-types and bulky Dark-types like Hydreigon, Salamence, Mandibuzz, and Umbreon. If using Heavy-Duty Boots to avoid Stealth Rock damage as Azelf pivots throughout the battle, Knock Off is the preferred final move to remove items from common switch-ins such as Chansey and Mandibuzz so Azelf can attempt to outlast them. Timid is the preffered nature as Azelf is not concerned about U-turn chip damage, though Naive can be used if running Knock Off for extra power as the loss in Special Defense barely affects Azelf and maintaining chip damage from U-turn and Knock Off can be beneficial. 4 Defense EVs ensure Azelf takes a Thousand Arrows from Zygarde-10%.

This set fits best on fast-paced balance and offense teams, where its pivot support can assist in getting other hard-hitting Pokemon like Mamoswine onto the field. Azelf is already a strong offensive presence, but wallbreakers like Keldeo, Hydreigon, Conkeldurr, and Mamoswine overwhelm shared checks such as Slowking, Chansey, and Mandibuzz. Stealth Rock setters like Nihilego and Spikes users like Skarmory put even more stress on the opposing team. Nihilego also can pressure Mandibuzz and wear down Slowking. Excadrill compresses setting and removing entry hazards, enabling Expert Belt Azelf to come in and break through the enemy team more easily. Azelf works best in combination with other pivots such as Zarude, Thundurus-T, and Slowking; all of which appreciating Azelf taking on Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss. Zarude can counter Hippowdon and Slowking and bring Azelf in against Skarmory, Thundurus-T can threaten Mandibuzz and Crobat, and a Slowking of your own can be used as a slower, defensive pivot to bring in Azelf against Pokemon like Tangrowth. Scizor can lure in Cobalion and Skarmory and use U-turn to give Azelf opportunities to wallbreak while also picking off priority users that threaten Azelf like Lycanroc-D and Mamoswine. Tangrowth and Amoonguss help check dangerous revenge killers like Diggersby and Zarude for Azelf, while Azelf can threaten Steel-types like Skarmory and Celesteela. Primarina can handle many threats to Azelf, including Mandibuzz and Choice Scarf Hydreigon, while Azelf can threaten Grass-types like Amoonguss. In addition to Primarina, bulky Pokemon like Slowking and Salamence can make up for Azelf's frailty by defensively answering threats to it.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
+2 Azelf can dismantle nearly the entire tier, depending on what coverage moves it chooses. Psyshock is usually preferred for STAB to OHKO Nihilego and Tentacruel before a boost and better threaten Chansey and Calm Mind Primarina. However, Psychic is an option to do more neutral damage to Pokemon like Salamence and Mamoswine if Azelf is not running super effective coverage for them. Fire Blast covers Grass-types like Tangrowth and Steel-types like Celesteela, OHKOing all after Nasty Plot. Azelf's other coverage depends on the team's needs. Energy Ball wipes out Swampert, Hippowdon, and Slowking. Dazzling Gleam hits Dark- and Dragon-types like Hydreigon, Umbreon, Mandibuzz, and Salamence. Substitute is an option over either of these moves to give it a safety net to either set up easier or take a hit and retaliate back. Azelf can often get up Substitute against who rely on hindering it with status like Hippowdon as well as Pokemon it forces out like Keldeo. Expert Belt is usually the preferred item on this set, as it allows Azelf to fire off attacks without consequence while still dealing enough damage to OHKO defensive Pokemon like Celesteela after Nasty Plot. Life Orb can be used for even more damage, in particular against Pokemon Azelf lacks coverage for like Chansey and Hatterene. Unfortunately, Life Orb wears down Azelf fairly quickly and leaves it susceptible to priority attacks like Bullet Punch from Scizor. Focus Sash allows Azelf to safely take a hit and boost or avoid being revenge killed, though this item is unreliable as it can easily be broken by Stealth Rock.

This set fits best on hyper offense teams, whose teammates can support Azelf. An entry hazard setter like Scolipede helps facilitate an Azelf sweep, and Excadrill can both set hazards and remove them. Azelf is naturally fast, but a Sticky Web setter like Ribombee invalidates Choice Scarf users like Diggersby and Zarude, letting Azelf easily sweep most teams. Sticky Web also allows Azelf to attack Starmie and Zygarde-10% without risking a Speed tie. Strong physical sweepers, like Gyarados and Diggersby, can work as secondary sweepers against teams that carry multiple stops to Azelf. Azelf can set up on most checks to these physical sweepers, including Tangrowth and Skarmory. A wallbreaker like Mamoswine can break through many checks to Azelf, such as Mandibuzz and Chansey, to allow Azelf to more easily sweep. Thundurus-T can also help threaten Pokemon like Mandibuzz, as Azelf struggles to break through it even with Dazzling Gleam. Nihilego can serve as a secondary sweeper with Meteor Beam and important coverage in moves such as Sludge Wave and Thunderbolt, while Azelf can assist in removing or weakening Nihilego's checks like Slowking, Chansey, and Jirachi.

Excadrill.overview: Excadrill has valuable role compression in UU as an Electric-immune entry hazard remover and potential Stealth Rock setter. It has the typing to check many threatening foes like Nihilego, Togekiss, Jirachi, and Galarian Slowbro. Mold Breaker allows Excadrill to bypass abilities like Levitate from Rotom-W and Magic Bounce from Hatterene to KO them or set Stealth Rock. Excadrill can also utilize a suicide lead set on hyper offense teams to pave the way for dangerous sweepers like Celesteela and Thundurus-T. Excadrill can also be a potent late-game cleaner with a Swords Dance + Rapid Spin set, boosting up to break through walls like Chansey and Amoonguss and clean through weakened teams. However, Excadrill is extremely vulnerable to the tier's Water-, Grass-, and Fighting-type Pokemon like Keldeo, Zarude, and Conkeldurr, all of which can easily take advantage of it due to their higher Speed or access to priority. Excadrill struggles to bypass common threats like Skarmory, Hippowdon, Moltres, and Celesteela. Skarmory and Hippowdon are especially troublesome, as Excadrill struggles to keep entry hazards removed against the most prevalent setters in the tier. Furthermore, Excadrill's defensive stats are lackluster without investment, which hinders its role as a Steel-type when checking threats like Hatterene and Hydreigon.
Excadrill.comments:
Other Options

On Hippowdon teams, Excadrill can use Sand Rush over Mold Breaker to be the fastest threat in the tier, though sand isn't a prominent archetype in UU and Excadrill fails to beat Celesteela and Skarmory anyway. Choice Scarf allows Excadrill to revenge kill threats like Azelf and be the fastest entry hazard remover in the tier, but it is typically undesirable to be locked into any of its moves. Sand Force alongside Choice Band on Sand teams turns Excadrill into a very dangerous wallbreaker, but like Choice Scarf this set struggles because Excadrill hates being locked into any of its moves. Assault Vest lets Excadrill better tank hits from Hydreigon and Galarian Slowbro, though it misses out on the passive recovery Leftovers provides.

Checks and Counters

Flying-types: Skarmory, Celesteela, and Moltres resist Excadrill's STAB combination, with the former two also being immune to Toxic. However, Moltres dislikes getting hit with Rock Tomb from suicide lead variants. Thundurus-T outspeeds Excadrill and nails it with Focus Blast. Salamence can switch into Excadrill and lower its Attack with Intimidate.

Water-types: Bulky Water-types like Swampert and Slowking can take a hit from Excadrill and retaliate with a super effective attack. Gyarados can use variants without Toxic as setup fodder. Azumarill and Keldeo can revenge kill Excadrill easily.

Grass-types: Tangrowth's massive physical bulk allows it to wall most Excadrill variants, though it has to be careful when taking on Swords Dance sets, as they can break through it with an Iron Head flinch, and Tangrowth needs chip damage to KO Excadrill back. Zarude's natural bulk lets it pivot into Excadrill; it does not fear Toxic because of Jungle Healing and forces it out due to its higher Speed. Dhelmise can block Rapid Spin attempts from Excadrill and threaten it back with heavy damage.

Fighting-types: Cobalion and Keldeo outspeed and force out Excadrill. Conkeldurr has enough physical bulk to take an Earthquake and recover its health with Drain Punch or OHKO Excadrill with Mach Punch if at full health.

Faster Threats: Faster threats like Krookodile, Zygarde-10%, Hydreigon, and Lycanroc-D all outspeed and threaten Excadrill. However, none of these Pokemon want to switch into it, barring Krookodile, which can in a pinch.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
Earthquake and Iron Head provide fantastic coverage for Excadrill, slamming common threats like Galarian Slowbro, Nihilego, and Mamoswine. Rapid Spin lets Excadrill clear entry hazards thanks to matching up well against other entry hazard setters like Nihilego and Chansey. Toxic burdens defensive checks like Tangrowth, Slowking, and Hippowdon, allowing Excadrill or a teammate to get past them in the long-term. However, Toxic is useless against certain answers like Skarmory. Alternatively, Stealth Rock can be run for more role compression thanks to Excadrill pressuring entry hazard control like Rotom-W and Hatterene and being able to set up Stealth Rock against Pokemon like Nihilego and Jirachi thanks to its typing. Moreover, finding another Pokemon to run Stealth Rock can strain teambuilding, though Excadrill becomes unable to cripple and wear down threats like Hippowdon. Magnet Rise is an option over Iron Head to completely shut down Hippowdon from setting up Stealth Rock, being immune to Earthquake and punishing it with Toxic, though Excadrill's offensive capabilities become more limited. Mold Breaker bypasses Levitate from Rotom-W, Rotom-H, and Hydreigon, allowing Excadrill to severely damage them with Earthquake while also allowing Excadrill to circumvent Hatterene's Magic Bounce. Maximum Attack investment lets Excadrill threaten Amoonguss and Primarina as much as possible, though maximum investment in Special Defense in an option to better check threats like Hatterene, Rotom-W, and Galarian Slowbro via directly switching in.

Excadrill both removing and setting entry hazards gives it a place on many bulky offense and balance teams. Thundurus-T is a great partner that can remove Flying-types like Skarmory, Celesteela, and Moltres that hinder Excadrill. Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss can switch into Water- and Grass-types like Azumarill and Zarude for Excadrill. They also scare out Hippowdon. Fighting-type checks like Salamence and Slowking provide great support against threats like Cobalion and Conkeldurr, with Salamence also beating Grass-types like Zarude and Tangrowth as well as helping Excadrill keep entry hazards off the field thanks to it beating entry hazard setters it struggles with like Skarmory and Swampert. Salamence also beats bulky variants of Swords Dance Scizor. Other entry hazard setters like Nihilego and Cobalion can cover setting Stealth Rock for Excadrill, freeing up a moveslot to run Toxic. Fast offensive threats like Zygarde-10%, Azelf, and Salazzle appreciate Excadrill's support and can deal with faster threats like Thundurus-T and Hydreigon. The latter two also check Amoonguss, Tangrowth, and Skarmory.

sets.name: Suicide Lead
sets.description:
