Faster threats and Priority: Faster threats like Azelf, Crobat, Zygarde-10%, Choice Scarf Diggersby, and Choice Scarf Hydreigon all take advantage of Tornadus's frailty to easily revenge kill it. Lycanroc-D and Mamoswine can easily OHKO Tornadus with their priority attacks, while other priority users such as Scizor and Azumarill can pick off a weakened Tornadus.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Chansey easily takes Tornadus's Choice Specs-boosted attacks and can cripple it with status or bring in an offensive check with Teleport. Nihilego is also a solid check to Tornadus's Choice Specs set, taking Hurricane with ease and limiting Tornadus's ability to repeatedly use it, but it fears Weather Ball in rain. However, both struggle to reliably check Tornadus's mixed offensive set, as it can cripple them with Knock Off and outlast them with U-turn + Acrobatics until they are in range of a KO. Celesteela similarly fares well against the Choice Specs set and has Leech Seed to regain lost health, though it still hates Knock Off removing its Leftovers albeit less than the other two. On the other hand, Hippowdon takes on the mixed offensive set well if lacking Grass Knot, but is unable to stand up to a Choice Specs-boosted Hurricane.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Under rain, Hurricane becomes an immensely difficult move to switch into, swiftly 2HKOing common Pokemon like Slowking, Hippowdon, and Primarina with ease when backed by Choice Specs. Knock Off cripples switch-ins such as Chansey, Celesteela, and Nihilego, though it is undesirable to lock into because of how weak it is. U-turn allows Tornadus to pivot against switch-ins like Rotom-W, Celesteela, and Chansey. Focus Blast nails Flying-resists such as Rotom-W and Nihilego. It can even 2HKO Chansey if Eviolite is removed. Weather Ball is an option for super effective damage on Rotom-H and Nihilego in the rain. Choice Specs is required to obtain the aforementioned 2HKOes and maximizes Tornadus's wallbreaking potential.

Choice Specs Tornadus primarily excels on rain teams. As such, Politoed is a mandatory teammate, being able to set rain and potentially punish Pokemon such as Rotom-W with a Scald burn. Secondary benefactors of rain are important in helping Tornadus wallbreak. Keldeo and Kingdra are excellent at overwhelming defensive cores with their overwhelming power and scaring out foes such as Nihilego and Rotom-H, with the latter being able to keep faster threats to Tornadus such as Zygarde-10%, Azelf, and Choice Scarf Hydreigon in line thanks to Swift Swim. Azumarill and Gyarados are able to break past specially defensive Pokemon like Chansey and Celesteela and enjoy Tornadus wiping out Grass-types like Tangrowth and Zarude. They also work with Tornadus to overwhelm Rotom-W. Excadrill provides entry hazard support and removal, being able to provide Stealth Rock to enhance Tornadus's wallbreaking while keeping it from getting worn down by Stealth Rock with Rapid Spin. Excadrill also checks Nihilego, Rotom-W, and Chansey for Tornadus. Amoonguss can provide defensive support to the rain team, checking foes that can take a hit like Primarina as well as faster checks to Tornadus like Raikou.

Thundurus-Therian.overview: Thundurus-T's amazing Special Attack, solid Speed, great coverage, and decent typing make it one of the best wallbreakers and pivots in UU. Thundurus-T's pivot set is able to wear down Pokemon like Salamence and Slowking and bring in teammates like Scizor, forming potent VoltTurn cores. Access to coverage options like Grass Knot, Knock Off, Focus Blast, and Psychic allows Thundurus-T to overcome counterplay like Swampert, Chansey, Excadrill, and Amoonguss, making it very difficult to scout its moveset. Thundurus-T also can utilize Nasty Plot to become a ferocious wallbreaker with no counters, being able to muscle past the sturdiest of specially defensive walls like Chansey and Assault Vest Tangrowth at +2 and crush balance teams. However, this set isn't too common in the metagame due to its average bulk, meaning it struggles to set up safely against common offensive teams. Even in matchups against bulkier teams, Thundurus-T usually gets inflicted with Toxic poison, allowing it to be played around easily. Because Thundurus-T's weakness to Stealth Rock mandates the use of Heavy-Duty Boots, it can't utilize boosting items like Life Orb to wallbreak easier. It also suffers from an exploitable Speed tier, leaving it vulnerable to being revenge killed by common threats like Nihilego, Zarude, Keldeo, Azelf, and Zygarde-10%. It is also vulnerable to priority from slower threats like Mamoswine. Thundurus-T is often reliant on trading with threats like Salamence with its pivot set due to Volt Switch's low Base Power, making it more vulnerable to the aforementioned revenge killers. Even Pokemon like Amoonguss and Scizor can stay in and trade with the pivot set if needed. Thundurus-T, despite having the coverage moves to get past its checks, cannot fit all of them and has to choose between being checked by at least one of Chansey, Zarude, or Hippowdon.
Thundurus-Therian.comments:
Other Options

Defog can be used for emergency entry hazard removal, as Thundurus-T fares well against entry hazard setters like Skarmory, but this significantly hinders Thundurus-T's offensive potential due to it losing out on valuable coverage options. An Agility set with a Modest nature allows Thundurus-T to offset its biggest issue in its Speed, but the lack of coverage and Nasty Plot make it much less effective.

Checks and Counters

Faster Threats: Thundurus-T has an exploitable Speed tier that leaves it revenge killed by common threats like Nihilego, Cobalion, Keldeo, Noivern, and Azelf.

Ground-types: Zygarde-10%, Mamoswine, and Choice Scarf Diggersby act as consistent revenge killers to Thundurus-T, though they fail to KO it from full. Swampert and Hippowdon hinder Thundurus-T by deterring Volt Switch and wall it if it lacks Grass Knot, though the former can get worn down over time. Hippowdon's sand also passively wears Thundurus-T down, letting a threat like Azelf or Zarude revenge kill it easier. Quagsire walls Nasty Plot sets thanks to Unaware, though it is vulnerable to Special Defense drops, which put it in 2HKO range of Focus Blast, and also must watch out for Grass Knot.

Grass-types: Zarude walls Thundurus-T without Focus Blast and can revenge kill it with ease. Tapu Bulu, Dhelmise, and Assault Vest Tangrowth can take hits from Thundurus-T and have reliable recovery or Regenerator, but they hate Sludge Bomb and can get muscled through by Nasty Plot.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
Volt Switch allows Thundurus-T to make progress by pivoting while also being a strong STAB attack against the likes of Primarina and Celesteela. Alternatively, U-turn can act as a pivoting move alongside Thunderbolt to better pressure Salamence, Scizor, and Slowking. U-turn also has the benefit of not getting blocked by Ground-types like Hippowdon, but this causes Thundurus-T to struggle even more with fitting necessary coverage. Volt Switch can even be used alongside Thunderbolt if Thundurus-T doesn't need the extra coverage. Psychic is key for hitting Amoonguss, Conkeldurr, and Nihilego super effectively while also being a good midground against Pokemon like Tangrowth, Zygarde-10%, and opposing Thundurus-T. Grass Knot is mandatory to break past Hippowdon while also beating Swampert and Quagsire. Focus Blast OHKOes Excadrill, Hydreigon, and Mamoswine and prevents Zarude from switching in without fear. Knock Off cripples switch-ins like Chansey, Nihilego, and Assault Vest Tangrowth, allowing Thundurus-T and its teammates to overcome them in the long run. Sludge Bomb can be used over Psychic to hit Tapu Bulu and Assault Vest Tangrowth harder, letting a teammate like Zygarde-10% wallbreak easier. Similarly, Incinerate can be used over Psychic to OHKO Scizor while still hitting Grass-types like Amoonguss super effectively, but it and Sludge Bomb are typically harder to fit. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Thundurus-T to pivot throughout a game and not worry about taking Stealth Rock damage, making it very resilient. 4 Defense EVs allow Thundurus-T to always survive a Life Orb Ice Shard from Adamant Mamoswine from full.

Pivot Thundurus-T best fits on VoltTurn and bulky offense teams that provide many partners that synergize with it well. Scizor is a phenomenal partner for Thundurus-T, revenge killing Nihilego and Zygarde-10% with Bullet Punch and punishing switch-ins to Thundurus-T like Tangrowth and Chansey. Other pivots like Zarude and Moltres form potent VoltTurn cores with Thundurus-T as well, bringing it in against Flying- and Water-types like Skarmory, Primarina, and Slowking. Zarude helps pressure Hippowdon and Nihilego, while Moltres can remove Grass-types like Tangrowth and Zarude. Slower pivots like Mandibuzz and Slowking also synergize well with Thundurus-T, having the added benefit of taking on revenge killers like Zygarde-10%, Azelf, and Mamoswine. Entry hazard setters like Cobalion and Swampert can set Stealth Rock to soften up checks like Nihilego and Chansey while also forming momentum cores and checking threats such as Zarude and Nihilego. Swords Dance Cobalion and Choice Scarf Diggersby pressure specially defensive Pokemon like Chansey and Nihilego, with the latter also revenge killing faster threats like Azelf and Zygarde-10%. Wallbreakers like Nidoking, Mamoswine, and Keldeo appreciate Thundurus-T bringing them in against Nihilego, Tangrowth, and Hippowdon. They also make up for the lack of initial power Thundurus-T can have at times.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Nasty Plot allows Thundurus-T to become one of the scariest wallbreakers in the tier, OHKOing or 2HKOing everything at +2. Thunderbolt OHKOes Salamence, Mandibuzz, Scizor, and Rotom-W after a boost. Psychic is key coverage for breaking past Nihilego and Amoonguss. +2 Focus Blast OHKOes Hydreigon and Excadrill and 2HKOes Chansey, Hippowdon, and Assault Vest Tangrowth. Grass Knot is an alternative option over Focus Blast to apply more immediate pressure to Hippowdon at the cost of being able to break past Chansey. While Heavy-Duty Boots is typically run to avoid Stealth Rock chip damage, other items like Life Orb can be used on teams with solid entry hazard control for more wallbreaking power.

Nasty Plot Thundurus-T best fits on hyper offense teams that provide it ample opportunities to sweep, though it can also work on bulky offense teams as a strong early- or late-game powerhouse. Leads like Excadrill, Krookodile, and Scolipede provide entry hazard support to weaken checks like Chansey and Swampert. Excadrill's Rapid Spin can also free up Thundurus-T to run another item over Heavy-Duty Boots. Ribombee can provide Sticky Web support to offset Thundurus-T's vulnerable Speed tier, allowing it to outspeed and KO typically faster threats like Keldeo and Nihilego. Late-game cleaners like Celesteela, Keldeo, and Scizor appreciate Thundurus-T's wallbreaking to clean easier. The former takes advantage of Thundurus-T wearing down Nihilego and luring in Zarude for free setup, while the latter two can force out Nihilego and Zygarde-10%. On bulky offense teams, pivots like Noivern and Zarude can bring in Thundurus-T against checks like Primarina and Skarmory for free setup.

Keldeo.overview: Keldeo's Hydro Pump is one of the most dangerous attacks in all of SS UU; any team not capable of stomaching it borders on unviable, and most teams will need to stack multiple Water-resistant Pokemon just to ensure they're safe against it. That, combined with Secret Sword to slice open Pokemon that withstand Hydro Pump like Zarude, Chansey, and Rotom-W, makes Keldeo one of the most dangerous wallbreakers in the tier. Its STAB moves give it plenty of coverage already, but Icy Wind further OHKOes Salamence and Noivern, which could otherwise handle it, and Air Slash 2HKOes every Grass-type in the tier. Keldeo can also utilize a Calm Mind set to act as a late-game cleaner on offensive teams. Keldeo's good Speed tier also lets it outspeed and threaten an OHKO on Pokemon like Zarude, Thundurus-T, and Nihilego, helping further separate it from other wallbreakers in the tier. This is further augmented by its resistance to common priority moves like Scizor's Bullet Punch and Mamoswine's Ice Shard. Keldeo does have some large issues, like generally struggling to break through Primarina, Slowking, Amoonguss, and Tangrowth without support—the latter three further exploit its Choice Specs to scout its attack through Regenerator—but its upside still makes it a top choice for a wallbreaker. Keldeo is also quite prediction reliant and can end up as setup fodder for the likes of Gyarados and Salamence if it's not careful. Finally, Keldeo's Speed tier, while good, can leave it easily revenge killed by the likes of Noivern, Crobat, Azelf, and Raikou.
Keldeo.comments:
Other Options

Keldeo can run a pivot set with Leftovers and a moveset consisting of Scald, Secret Sword, Toxic, and Flip Turn. This makes it much better at wearing down Pokemon like Salamence, Slowking, Primarina, and Tangrowth, and it lets Keldeo pivot out on the likes of Amoonguss. Its damage output is mediocre, though, and Keldeo's Speed tier isn't amazingly suited to being a team's fast Pokemon that keeps other fast Pokemon in check, so it must be paired with a teammate like Noivern or Choice Scarf Diggersby. Substitute can be used over a coverage move on Keldeo's Calm Mind set to set up on threats like Amoonguss, but the presence of Assault Vest Tangrowth as well as the additional value Air Slash provides makes it not worth it most of the time. Choice Scarf sets with Flip Turn are a fine option if the ability to outspeed extremely fast Pokemon like boosted Salamence and Choice Scarf Zarude is absolutely necessary for a team to function, but Keldeo's unboosted damage output is somewhat disappointing and Flip Turn hits like a wet noodle off Keldeo's meager Attack stat, leaving it generally outclassed by other fast pivots like Noivern and Choice Scarf Hydreigon.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Water-types, specifically those resistant to Secret Sword like Slowking and RestTalk Primarina, can switch into Keldeo all game long, as long as they keep themselves healthy. Tentacruel and Azumarill can switch into Keldeo once or twice and chip it or outright KO it, making it easier for teammates to handle. Starmie and Gyarados can offensively check Keldeo but must be careful about switching in, as it does a huge chunk of damage to them despite their resistances.

Grass-types: Tangrowth and Amoonguss can scout any move Keldeo goes for. Even if they are weakened, Regenerator allows them to pivot out to an appropriate teammate to handle the scouted attack. Dhelmise and Tapu Bulu are niche answers that can switch into Keldeo somewhat well, though they despise being burnt by Scald.

Dragon-types: Salamence and Noivern can switch into Keldeo very well, though Salamence needs some bulk investment to avoid a 2HKO from Hydro Pump, and Noivern must be cautious of Keldeo staying in as it heals itself with Roost, as Secret Sword can do massive damage when Roost sheds the Flying type . Hydreigon and Zygarde-10% can also offensively threaten Keldeo depending on what move it's locked into. All Dragon-types must be careful of Icy Wind, though.

Faster threats: Common threats like Raikou, Azelf, and Crobat all outspeed and threaten to KO Keldeo.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Hydro Pump rinses the likes of Scizor, Hippowdon, Nihilego, and Thundurus-T. Even frailer resistant Pokemon such as Zarude and opposing Keldeo can't handle it more than once. Secret Sword smashes Chansey, Hydreigon, and Celesteela while chunking Tentacruel and offensive Primarina. Scald is useful against frailer offensive teams, where the extra power from Hydro Pump is unnecessary, letting Keldeo cleave through them without risk of missing. Scald also lets it fish for burns on checks like Amoonguss, Tangrowth, and Slowking, making them worse checks to Keldeo in the long run. Icy Wind destroys Salamence and Noivern, two Pokemon that could otherwise switch into Keldeo decently. It also hits Amoonguss and non-Assault Vest Tangrowth quite hard. Air Slash can KO Amoonguss from higher ranges than Icy Wind and 2HKOes Assault Vest Tangrowth with Stealth Rock up, but otherwise provides worse coverage.

Keldeo's amazing wallbreaking good defensive utility let it fit on all kinds of offensive and balanced teams. Scizor is a phenomenal teammate that can switch into Grass-types that bother Keldeo like Amoonguss, Tangrowth, and Zarude. It can bring Keldeo in safely on the likes of Skarmory and Rotom-H to launch a free Hydro Pump. If running Swords Dance, Scizor can also sweep late-game after Keldeo has successfully broken down the opponent's team. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Nihilego, Hippowdon, Nidoqueen, and Excadrill makes it much more difficult for Pokemon like Slowking and Tangrowth to repeatedly switch into Keldeo. The former two can also check Salamence and Noivern for Keldeo, while the latter three can serve as decent checks to Raikou. Nidoqueen can also pressure Tangrowth and Primarina quite well. Fast pivots such as Noivern and Crobat can outspeed and threaten Pokemon that scare Keldeo out such as Azelf, Raikou, and Zygarde-10%, which is much appreciated. Both can also bring Keldeo in on targets that it freely preys upon, with Noivern baiting in Hippowdon and Nihilego and Crobat baiting in Scizor and Skarmory. Electric-types like Raikou, Rotom-W, and Thundurus-T form good cores with Keldeo, as they can break down the likes of Slowking and Primarina for it. They can also check Togekiss, which can punish Keldeo locked into Secret Sword quite hard. Answers to Slowking, and thus the combination of Future Sight + Teleport, are mandatory when using Keldeo. Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Zarude can switch into Slowking safely and prevent it from using Teleport for free, breaking the FuturePort chain. Grass-types like Amoonguss, Tangrowth, and Zarude can aid in Keldeo's eternal fight against bulky Water-types while also being able to check the likes of Gyarados and Primarina.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Calm Mind turns Keldeo into a scary late-game cleaner that hits Thundurus-T and Amoonguss harder and becomes difficult to revenge kill with the likes of Noivern and Choice Scarf Hydreigon. Scald threatens switch-ins like Tangrowth, Amoonguss, and Slowking with a burn while providing strong neutral damage against Skarmory and Scizor. Secret Sword breaks through Chansey, Zarude, Rotom-W, and Hydreigon. Air Slash hits Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth hard and allows Keldeo to possibly flinch down checks like Salamence and Slowking. Icy Wind can be used over Air Slash to OHKO on Salamence and still hit the aforementioned Grass-types hard after a Calm Mind boost, but it is weak otherwise and keeps Keldeo from meaningfully damaging Slowking. Leftovers gives Keldeo passive recovery to have more setup chances against the likes of Scizor and Mandibuzz and is also useful for offsetting Stealth Rock and sand damage. Life Orb is an option for increased wallbreaking power, able to OHKO Chansey with Secret Sword and Amoonguss with Air Slash after Stealth Rock with a boost, but causes Keldeo to get worn down quickly. Life Orb is solely used on hyper offense teams, as longevity is less needed.

Calm Mind Keldeo best fits on bulky offense and balance teams as a strong late-game sweeper and is also valued on hyper offense teams for its good matchup against opposing offense. Entry hazard support is essential in softening up bulky Grass-types for Keldeo; Hippowdon, Skarmory, and Nidoqueen make excellent teammates as a result. Hippowdon also can bait Tangrowth and Slowking into taking Toxic and wear them down with sand damage. Meanwhile, Nidoqueen directly pressures Primarina for Keldeo. Pivots like Thundurus-T and Choice Scarf Diggersby pressure Slowking and Primarina throughout a game to keep them from switching into Keldeo without any care. They also wear down Amoonguss and Tangrowth with their repeated pivoting moves. Teammates such as Crobat, Noivern, and the aforementioned Diggersby can keep faster threats to Keldeo like Azelf and Starmie in line. Swords Dance Scizor, particularly Safety Goggles variants, takes advantage of Amoonguss and Tangrowth incredibly well, and can lure in and remove Salamence's item with Knock Off, allowing Keldeo to overwhelm it more easily with Air Slash. On hyper offense teams, Autotomize Celesteela and Nasty Plot Azelf take on Tangrowth and Amoonguss and overwhelm Primarina and Slowking for Keldeo, as they will often be the opposing team's main line of defense against these threats.

Diggersby.overview: Huge Power makes Diggersby a decent wallbreaker and cleaner that can pressure many Pokemon in the tier. A Swords Dance boost allows Diggersby to KO defensive walls like Chansey and Celesteela; even the latter is KOed by Mega Kick after chip damage despite being the only Pokemon in the tier that resists or is immune to both STAB moves. Quick Attack also provides a strong STAB priority attack that allows Diggersby to perform late-game sweeps, while a Choice Scarf set can outspeed and KO some of its usual offensive checks like Cobalion and Lycanroc-D; however, other common Choice Scarf users like Krookodile and Zarude outspeed Diggersby and have more defensive utility, with the former having Intimidate and the latter having decent natural bulk. Without Choice Scarf, Diggersby is slow and will rarely outspeed its foes, forcing it to usually rely on Quick Attack for a late-game sweep and making it easy fodder for faster revenge killers like Keldeo if they are healthy enough to survive a boosted Quick Attack. Other offensive Pokemon that can boost their Speed, such as Dragon Dance Salamence and Gyarados, can better position themselves to sweep. With Diggersby's low defenses and lack of any meaningful defensive utility outside of switching in on a predicted Electric-type attack with its Choice Scarf set, it needs to typically OHKO its foes to prevent taking heavy damage in return. Additionally, it is weak to common priority users such as Aqua Jet Azumarill and Mach Punch Conkeldurr.
Diggersby.comments:
Other Options

Choice Band gives Diggersby more immediate wallbreaking potential, as it can deal severe damage to anything that switches in on it. Body Slam can KO Rotom-H and Rotom-W on the switch with minimal chip damage, and Fire Punch deals substantial damage to typically defensive foes like Celesteela and Tangrowth. Unfortunately, this set is very prediction reliant. Additionally, Diggersby's poor Speed makes it easy for many foes like Zarude and Lycanroc-D to revenge kill it.

Checks and Counters

Faster Offensive Pokemon: Diggersby's main drawback is its below average Speed without Choice Scarf, allowing many offensive threats in the tier like Zarude and Lycanroc-D to OHKO it. While +2 Quick Attack can OHKO certain frail Pokemon like Thundurus and Azelf, it will fail to KO Pokemon with good or average bulk such as Mamoswine.

Priority Users: Azumarill, Crawdaunt, and Conkeldurr OHKO Diggersby with super effective priority attacks in Aqua Jet and Mach Punch. While Diggersby can threaten to OHKO Crawdaunt with +2 Quick Attack, it cannot do the same to Azumarill and Conkeldurr.

Physically Defensive Pokemon: Defensive Pokemon like Skarmory, Tangrowth, and Celesteela effectively check Choice Scarf Diggersby, as Diggersby fails to inflict enough damage and all of these can threaten it offensively. However, Swords Dance Diggersby can break through all these Pokemon after chip damage.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
The combination of Swords Dance and Quick Attack makes this set particularly lethal, as +2 Quick Attack can KO Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Thundurus-T after minimal chip damage. A Swords Dance-boosted Fire Punch OHKOs Celesteela, Skarmory after Stealth Rock, and has a chance to OHKO physically defensive Tangrowth after Stealth Rock. Mega Kick KOes Pokemon like Rotom-W and Rotom-H on the switch after minimal damage. It is a powerful STAB move capable of letting Diggersby still muscle past Tangrowth and Celesteela; however, it will have a much harder time getting past Skarmory. Body Slam can be used over Mega Kick as a more reliable option that will still deal enough damage to KO defensive Pokemon like Amoonguss after one Swords Dance boost. Life Orb provides Diggersby with the extra power needed to break through Tangrowth with Fire Punch, while boosting the power of its Quick Attack to pick off a weakened foe. Silk Scarf should primarily be considered if opting for Mega Kick over Fire Punch to retain the extra power to break through defensive cores and ability to clean late-game with +2 Quick Attack without the drawbacks of recoil.

Diggersby best fits on offense teams, particularly ones that can offer entry hazard support. A Sticky Web setter like Ribombee helps Diggersby outspeed most of its common checks like Cobalion and Lycanroc-D. Jirachi can provide Stealth Rock support, Healing Wish to give Diggersby another chance to clean, and can lure in and remove Skarmory with Thunder while also weakening Celesteela for it. Other teammates like Rotom-H and Thundurus-T can help threaten Celesteela and Skarmory too. Additionally, these partners offer pivot support and can safely bring in Diggersby against their common switch-ins like Chansey. Nihilego can help check problematic Pokemon like Rotom-H and defensive Salamence for Diggersby, and in return, Diggersby assists Nihilego by threatening Chansey. Togekiss is a good partner that can ease Diggersby's Speed issues with Thunder Wave and paralyze foes such as Tentacruel and Jirachi. Heal Bell also allows Diggersby to be more aggressive against foes like Moltres. Additionally, Pokemon that threaten Togekiss, like Celesteela, can be worn down by Diggersby over time. Amoonguss and Tangrowth help check common revenge killers to Diggersby such as Zarude and Keldeo and also offer sleep support to allow Diggersby to enter play more easily.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
A Choice Scarf set allows Diggersby to outspeed offensive threats like Nihilego and Lycanroc-D and OHKO them with Earthquake. U-turn allows Diggersby to maintain momentum. Fire Punch allows Diggersby to break past Celesteela and Tangrowth with good prediction and cleanly OHKO Scizor. Alternatively, Knock Off is an option to remove Rocky Helmet from Skarmory and Amoonguss, keeping Diggersby from getting worn down by attacking, as well as cripple otherwise great answers in Mandibuzz, Celesteela, and Salamence. Diggersby can alternatively choose to set up Spikes thanks to its ability to force switches, helping wear down threats like Hippowdon and Tangrowth, but being locked into Spikes creates opportunities for dangerous sweepers like Swords Dance Cobalion and Scizor. A Jolly nature lets Diggersby outspeed +1 Gyarados; however, it requires some chip damage to revenge kill it with Body Slam.

Choice Scarf Diggersby fits best on offense teams that require a strong wallbreaker that can overcome any Speed deficiencies within the team. Since Diggersby is able to use U-turn on its primary switch-ins like Skarmory, Celesteela, and Salamence, it appreciates a teammate like Primarina or Nihilego that can be brought in to pressure these foes. Diggersby can also form a strong VoltTurn core with Pokemon like Thundurus-T and Rotom-H, as both can pivot against common switch-ins like Chansey and bring Diggersby in on a favorable matchup. A Stealth Rock setter like Nihilego or Cobalion helps stack entry hazards and significantly improves Diggersby's ability to clean through chipped foes. Being Choice-locked into Body Slam or Earthquake puts Diggersby in a disadvantageous position against a common Normal- or Ground-immune Pokemon like Aegislash, Galarian Moltres, and Gyarados. Since these Pokemon can use Diggersby as a free entry point, with the latter two being able to set up for a sweep, Diggersby will need teammates that can immediately pressure these foes, like Lycanroc-D. A more defensive teammate like Chansey can also be used to switch in and pivot out with Teleport to gain momentum for another wallbreaker.

Noivern.overview: Noivern is notable for outspeeding the entire UU metagame, making it a naturally fast teammate without the use of a Choice Scarf. Its great STAB combination also makes Noivern a solid revenge killer. Furthermore, its defensive typing, access to reliable recovery, and decent bulk allow Noivern to reliably check threats like Keldeo and Zarude. Unfortunately, Noivern finds itself competing for a spot on teams with the tier's other Dragon / Flying type, Salamence. Salamence is much stronger and bulkier, which makes it a better wallbreaker and allows it to fulfill Noivern's defensive niche much more effectively than Noivern itself. However, Noivern's higher Speed, which is especially useful when dealing with massive threats like Keldeo, still makes it a solid option and a worthwhile pick over Salamence.
Noivern.comments:
Other Options

Super Fang can be used to weaken bulky walls like Chansey and Celesteela and make it easier for its teammates to revenge kill them while also pairing nicely with Taunt, but it's not very useful otherwise. Boomburst is another option for an attacking move, having an incredibly high Base Power without the drawbacks of Draco Meteor or Hurricane, but it is weaker and does not hit anything super effectively. Defog is a solid option, as Noivern is the fastest Defogger in the metagame and also checks common entry hazard setters like Jirachi and Kommo-o. However, Noivern struggles to fit Defog into its moveset, and if you want to run a Dragon / Flying Defogger, Salamence is a better option. Choice Specs is an option to make Noivern hit harder, but the lack of Heavy-Duty Boots makes Noivern incredibly susceptible to Stealth Rock, and thus it remains a very fringe option.

Checks and Counters

Special Walls: Chansey brushes off all of Noivern's moves and forces it to switch out, though it does have to worry about Taunt. Rhyperior can also easily sponge Noivern's attacks except for Draco Meteor. Finally, Celesteela is only 4HKOed by Noivern's Flamethrower, allowing it to serve as an occasional check.

Priority Users: Pokémon like Mamoswine and Lycanroc-D can use their super effective priority moves to bypass Noivern's blistering Speed and easily take it out.

Knock Off Users: Krookodile, Tangrowth, Conkeldurr, and other common Knock Off users can remove Noivern's Heavy-Duty Boots, which severely hampers its longevity and makes it unable to perform its role as a pivot as well as it could.

Fairy-types: Hatterene, Primarina, and Azumarill can take at least one hit and hit Noivern hard with their super effective STAB moves. However, these Pokemon generally don't like having to take more than one Hurricane.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Hurricane hits a wider amount of range than Draco Meteor, such as Amoonguss, Tangrowth, and Conkeldurr, and allows Noivern to pressure Fairy types, like Togekiss and Azumarill. However, Draco Meteor is more reliable and spammable than Hurricane, allows Noivern to OHKO Salamence and potentially OHKO Kommo-o, and is useful for chipping Pokemon that would otherwise check Noivern, like Rhyperior, Rotom-H, and Rotom-W. Flamethrower prevents Noivern from being completely walled by Steel-types, such as Aegislash, Jirachi, and Celesteela. U-turn is an option over either STAB move that allows Noivern to pivot out of would-be checks and bring in teammates more safely. Noivern does prefer to run both STAB moves, however. Roost is necessary for longevity. Infiltrator is used to bypass Substitute, which is crucial for allowing Noivern to take out Pokemon that rely on it, like Keldeo and Aegislash.

Noivern is best used on teams that otherwise lack naturally fast Pokemon or Choice Scarf users. Electric-types like Raikou and Rotom-W are particularly good partners for Noivern, forming a fast VoltTurn core. Raikou can lure in Rhyperior and weaken it with Toxic or Scald, as well as pressure Pokemon like Primarina and Azumarill for Noivern. Rotom-W can check Mamoswine and deals with Ground-types like Krookodile and Rhyperior better than Noivern can. Grass-types, such as Tangrowth and Amoonguss, are able to come in on Pokemon like Thundurus-T and Lycanroc-D that threaten Noivern. Wallbreakers such as Lycanroc-D, Mamoswine, and Crawdaunt help make up for Noivern's lackluster offensive presence. These Pokemon can also remove special walls that Noivern otherwise struggles with, such as Chansey, Primarina, and Milotic. Nihilego and Krookodile can set up entry hazards, which allow Noivern to more easily KO foes.

Zygarde-10%.overview: Zygarde-10% is a solid offensive Pokemon in UU thanks to its nearly unmatched Speed, outspeeding most offensive threats in the tier like Nihilego, Thundurus-T, and Cobalion. Thousand Arrows separates Zygarde-10% from other offensive Ground-types like Excadrill and Mamoswine because it can hit Flying-types like Skarmory, Celesteela, and Moltres while ignoring Tapu Bulu's Grassy Terrain. Extreme Speed is useful for picking off weakened setup sweepers and other faster threats like Gyarados and Choice Scarf Diggersby, letting Zygarde-10% be a potent revenge killer and a powerful cleaner. Sadly, Zygarde-10% has awful bulk, making pivots necessary, as even neutral attacks wear it down easily. Its mediocre Attack also means that it relies on chip damage to wear down foes such as Primarina, Slowking, Tangrowth, and Hippowdon. Its reliance on Choice Band means the aformentioned threats can switch into it and scout what move Zygarde-10% is locked into, letting them switch into a teammate that can handle whatever move Zygarde-10% goes for. Being locked into Extreme Speed is also risky, since it makes Zygarde-10% setup fodder for its checks like Swords Dance Scizor.
Zygarde-10%.comments:
Other Options

Zygarde-10% can run a Dragon Dance + Life Orb set to sweep weakened teams without locking itself into moves, but Gyarados and Salamence can fulfill that role better with their superior bulk. Scale Shot gives it a secondary Dragon-type STAB move without having to lock into Outrage, but it’s inconsistency makes it not worth it most of the time. Iron Tail can hit Tapu Bulu and Hatterene super effectively, but it has poor accuracy and coverage compared to its other moves. A set with Coil and Thousand Waves can heavily punish teams that rely on Tangrowth and Hippowdon lacking Whirlwind to check it, but this set can struggle against teams without them.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Physically defensive Tangrowth can consistently tank all of Zygarde-10%'s attacks, though it doesn't like Toxic. Zarude can consistently switch into Thousand Arrows and outspeed if it carries a Choice Scarf, but it has to watch out for Superpower and Skitter Smack. Tapu Bulu and Dhelmise resists Thousand Arrows and threatens Zygarde-10% with Horn Leech and Power Whip, respectively.

Fairy-types: Azumarill and Primarina switch into Zygarde-10% can punish Zygarde-10% locked into Outrage while easily OHKOing it with Play Rough and Moonblast. Hatterene is able to trade with Zygarde-10% and restore its health with Draining Kiss.

Faster Threats and Priority: Choice Scarf users like Diggersby and Hydreigon outspeed and KO Zygarde-10% easily. Mamoswine OHKOes it with Ice Shard, while Conkeldurr can do big damage with Mach Punch, though they have to be wary of Extreme Speed due to its higher priority. Scizor resists Outrage and Extreme Speed and can KO Zygarde-10% with Bullet Punch. Noivern naturally outspeeds Zygarde-10% and OHKOes it with Draco Meteor, while Crobat can pick off Zygarde-10% if it has chip damage.

Bulky Foes: Chansey, Slowking, Hippowdon, and Mandibuzz can tank Thousand Arrows and heal it off reliably, with the latter two hitting Zygarde-10% hard in return. Swampert and bulky Salamence can switch in as well, but they must watch out for Outrage.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Thousand Arrows is incredibly spammable and lets Zygarde-10% crush Rotom-W, Excadrill, and Cobalion. Extreme Speed lets it pick off some setup sweepers like Salamence and Azelf without having to rely on a Speed tie. Outrage lets Zygarde-10% sweep late-game against weakened teams by getting OHKOs and 2HKOs Thousand Arrows cannot, punishing threats like Chansey, Salamence, and even Tangrowth and Hippowdon with some prior chip damage. However, being locked into Outrage is risky if the opponent has a Fairy- or Steel-type on their team. Superpower hits Chansey, Cobalion, and Zarude while providing good coverage overall. Alternatively, Toxic punishes bulky foes like Tangrowth, Hippowdon, and Mandibuzz. Skitter Smack can guarantee an OHKO on Zarude and take out a weakened Tangrowth

Zygarde-10% best fits on balance and bulky offense as a potent revenge killer. Teammates like Chansey, Slowking, and Mandibuzz can deal with checks to Zygarde-10% like Primarina, Conkeldurr, and Zarude, and get it in safely with slow pivots. Zarude breaks though bulky Water-types like Swampert and Slowking, also bringing in Zygarde-10% on Skarmory and Cobalion to force them out. Moltres is an additional pivot that can deal with Tangrowth and Tapu Bulu, as well as bringing Zygarde-10% in against Tentacruel and Rotom-W. It also punishes Steel-types like Scizor coming in when Zygarde-10% is locked into Outrage or Extreme Speed. Nihilego and Skarmory handle Grass-types and sets up Stealth Rock and Spikes to wear down teams so Zygarde-10% can sweep with Thousand Arrows or Outrage. Skarmory also can shut down Hippowdon for Zygarde-10%. Rotom-W covers Mamoswine well while appreciating Thousand Arrows wearing down Amoonguss. Other wallbreakers like Keldeo and Hydreigon appreciate Zygarde-10% wearing down foes like Slowking and Celesteela for them to overwhelm.

Primarina.overview: Few Pokemon resist Primarina's STAB combination of Water and Fairy, making it a massive threat capable of threatening defensive Pokemon such as Jirachi, Celesteela, and Kommo-o. Its typing also shines defensively, allowing it to face Pokemon such as Keldeo and Kommo-o. Psychic covers the only answers to its STAB combination in Amoonguss and Tentacruel, and Calm Mind allows it to more easily get past common checks such as Tangrowth and Amoonguss. Unfortunately, Primarina has very low Speed, often forcing it to take a hit from Pokemon it's supposed to answer, such as Keldeo, before KOing them back. Its similarly low Defense stat makes it 2HKOed by even resisted hits such as Choice Specs Keldeo's Secret Sword after Stealth Rock damage and Crawdaunt's Crabhammer, so it can't check them well despite having the type advantage. Primarina faces some competition from Azumarill as a Water- and Fairy-type wallbreaker, as Azumarill acts a physical wallbreaker, can pressure walls with Knock Off, and has priority in Aqua Jet to make up for the lack of Speed, letting it check Pokemon like Nihilego and Lycanroc-D a lot more comfortably.
Primarina.comments:
Other Options

A spread of 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpA gives Primarina more bulk to deal with physical attackers like Lycanroc-D, but it is generally worse because Primarina doesn't have a usable Defense stat to begin with. Even with maximum Defense investment, Primarina is still 2HKOed by Pokemon like Mamoswine and Azumarill. Sparkling Aria is stronger than Scald and bypasses Substitute, but Scald's burn chance is a big help against checks like Amoonguss and Tentacruel. A Calm Mind + 3 attacks set can be used to boost Primarina's special attack to bypass answers like Tangrowth and Amoonguss.

Checks and Counters

Chansey: Primarina's best counter is Chansey, as it can stomach even a Choice Specs-boosted Hydro Pump with ease. Chansey also easily beats Substitute Primarina, as it can break the Substitute with Seismic Toss and scare Primarina away with Toxic. Primarina gives Chansey free turns to set up Stealth Rock, heal itself with Soft-Boiled, and bring in teammates with Teleport. It does have to be wary of Torrent-boosted Hydro Pump, though, as it 2HKOes after Stealth Rock damage.

Grass-types: Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth can cripple Primarina with Giga Drain, Sludge Bomb, and the former with Spore. Both can take on Primarina's STAB moves, but they have to scout for Choice Specs sets, as Psychic 2HKOes Amoonguss, while Moonblast 2HKOes Assault Vest Tangrowth after Stealth Rock damage. Tangrowth can, however, opt for Power Whip in place of Giga Drain to bypass Primarina's Special Defense boosts. Tapu Bulu outspeeds Primarina and can OHKO it with Horn Leech, but it doesn't like switching directly into Moonblast or risking Scald burns.

Water-types: Rotom-W can pivot into Primarina's Water-type moves and threaten it with Volt Switch in order to bring in a teammate like Tangrowth, but it is scared of Moonblast. Tentacruel eats any hit Primarina throws at it except Psychic. It also outspeeds Primarina and can pressure it with Sludge Bomb and Knock Off. Volcanion is only bothered by Psychic and can 2HKO Primarina with Sludge Bomb.

Faster Pokemon and Physical Attackers: Faster physical attackers such as Mamoswine, Lycanroc-D, and Zarude threaten Primarina with their powerful STAB moves. Other faster Pokemon such as Nihilego, Thundurus-T, and Venusaur threaten Primarina with their strong STAB attacks despite its good Special Defense.

Electric-types: Thundurus-T, Rotom-W, and Raikou outspeed Primarina, 2HKO or OHKO it with their attacks, and generate momentum with Volt Switch.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Psychic does copious amounts of damage to would-be checks in Amoonguss and Tentacruel. After Stealth Rock, Amoonguss risks being OHKOed. Scald is used as a reliable Water-type move when risking Hydro Pump is unnecessary. It also has a 30% chance to burn switch-ins, making it so Primarina can take physical attacks a bit better and wear down Amoonguss, Tangrowth, and Tentacruel. A Modest nature lets Primarina 2HKO Pokemon like Celesteela with Hydro Pump.

This set aims to punch holes through the raw power of Primarina's Choice Specs-boosted moves. Pivots such as Jirachi and Zarude can bring in Primarina safely with U-turn in front of Pokemon like Entei and Kommo-o, making up for its low Speed. Chandelure beats Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth, and some variants pressure Chansey for Primarina. Ground-types such as Rhyperior and Seismitoad handle Electric-types like Thundurus-T and set Stealth Rock up to help Primarina wallbreak. Chansey walls Primarina effortlessly, so Fighting-types such as Mienshao and Kommo-o can be used to threaten it. Primarina can be easily worn down by entry hazards, so a Wish passer like Jirachi can help it stay in the match for longer. In the same vein, entry hazard removers like Salamence and Rotom-H extend Primarina's longevity.

sets.name: RestTalk
sets.description:
Thanks to its bulk, Primarina continuously checks threats such as Keldeo and Salamence by healing itself with Rest while taking advantage of its excellent STAB combination with Sleep Talk. Rest allows it to not be ruined by status such as Toxic from Aegislash and Krookodile. Moonblast is great neutral coverage while also proving super effective damage on Kommo-o and Galarian Moltres. Scald allows Primarina to get a burn on switch-ins like Amoonguss, Celesteela, and Tentacruel, negating the recovery from their items. 124 Special Defense EVs and Leftovers allow Primarina to avoid the 2HKO from Choice Specs Chandelure's Shadow Ball and 3HKO from Salamence's Hurricane from full HP without Stealth Rock, with the rest put into Defense to take on Dragon Dance Salamence and Keldeo's Secret Sword better. Leftovers is great, as it synergizes well with Rest + Sleep Talk, but Heavy-Duty Boots is an option to negate damage from entry hazards if the team has unreliable or no hazard removal.

RestTalk Primarina is mainly used on bulky teams that appreciate a status sponge and value the defensive qualities its typing provides. Necrozma is an excellent partner, as it can threaten Amoonguss and Tentacruel, that would otherwise counter Primarina. Zarude checks Rotom-W and Chansey while appreciating Primarina checking Keldeo and Kommo-o. Fire-types such as Rotom-H and Moltres can help check Grass-types such as Zarude and Assault Vest Tangrowth, and provide momentum with Volt Switch and U-turn. Hazard control is important for Primarina to not be chipped down easily and forced to use Rest if it is running Leftovers. Salamence removes entry hazards with Defog and checks Zarude well. Kommo-o, Rhyperior, and Assault Vest Tangrowth can all form solid defensive cores with Primarina, as they are able to check Pokemon such as Volcanion, Thundurus, and Rotom-W nicely, while Primarina checks Salamence, Keldeo, and Moltres in return.

sets.name: Substitute + Calm Mind
sets.description:
Substitute lets Primarina avoid sleep and poison, which would otherwise cripple it and prevent it from sweeping with Calm Mind. Common checks like Amoonguss can't deal with Primarina if it uses Substitute as they come in, as Primarina is faster and can set up with Calm Mind. Substitute also eases prediction when forcing switches from Pokemon like Salamence and Kommo-o. Draining Kiss aids Primarina in recovering HP, allowing it to take more hits and use Substitute if needed. However, Draining Kiss is a very weak move and will only pose a threat if Primarina has accumulated enough boosts. Moonblast, on the other hand, is powerful from the start and lets Primarina not rely too much on Calm Mind boosts to threaten Water-resistant Pokemon like Tangrowth and Rotom-W. Scald is a reliable Water-type move, capable of burning Pokemon trying to check it, like Tentacruel, Assault Vest Tangrowth, and Amoonguss. Leftovers compensates the 25% loss in HP from Substitute. With the given EV spread Primarina is able to beat Amoonguss one-on-one, as it ensures Amoonguss can't break Primarina's Substitute after a Calm Mind.

Substitute + Calm Mind Primarina fits best on bulky offense and balance teams, as its ability to come in on moves like Draco Meteor from Salamence is greatly appreciated by other teammates. By switching on these moves, Primarina can either get a Substitute up or set up with Calm Mind if its checks have been eliminated or weakened. Strong wallbreakers like Mamoswine, Nidoking, and Aegislash can get past bulky Grass-types such as Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth. Electric-types such as Raikou and Thundurus-T force Primarina out of the field if it doesn't have a Substitute up, so Pokemon like Rhyperior and Seismitoad take care of them. They can also set Stealth Rock to aid Primarina in its sweep. Amoonguss and Tangrowth can take on strong physical attackers such as Diggersby and Mamoswine for Primarina. Chansey is extremely annoying, as it can take boosted hits with ease and threaten Primarina back with Toxic and Seismic Toss. Conkeldurr, Lycanroc-D, and Swords Dance Diggersby are powerful wallbreakers that can muscle through Chansey and remove it for Primarina.

Ribombee.overview: Ribombee is an effective Sticky Web setter thanks to its blistering Speed, decent offensive potential, and ability to threaten common Defoggers like Mandibuzz, Salamence and Rotom-W in addition to other leads like Cobalion. It's also immune to secondary effects thanks to Shield Dust; this makes it impossible for Pokemon like Choice Scarf Jirachi to antilead it, and its access to Skill Swap means that not even Hatterene can prevent it from getting its entry hazard up. As a result, Ribombee is a cornerstone on Sticky Web teams as the best available setter. It can struggle with certain hazard removers that resist Moonblast, though; examples include Excadrill, Moltres, and Tentacruel. It can also give free turns to the likes of Amoonguss, Scizor, and Autotomize Celesteela, though the latter dislikes being hit by Stun Spore.
Ribombee.comments:
Other Options

A Heavy-Duty Boots pivot set using Moonblast, Bug Buzz, Psychic, and U-turn can act as a passable threat that keeps Pokemon like Zygarde-10% and Keldeo in check, but it's too weak and frail to be worth it most of the time. Quiver Dance is an option, but Ribombee's inability to touch common Steel-types like Scizor and Celesteela makes it a hugely unreliable sweeper.

Checks and Counters

Steel-types: Scizor, Celesteela, and Jirachi wall Ribombee permanently and can KO it with their STAB attacks or use it as setup fodder, though they all hate Stun Spore barring Safety Goggles Scizor, particularly Choice Scarf variants of Jirachi. Excadrill is the most troublesome due to its ability to remove Sticky Web with Rapid Spin.

Poison-types: Nidoking, Amoonguss, and Tentacruel all take little damage from Moonblast and can slam Ribombee hard with their STAB moves. Tentacruel can also use Rapid Spin in Ribombee's face before KOing it with Sludge Bomb, making it impossible for Ribombee to get its entry hazard up.

Fire-types: Rotom-H, Moltres, and Entei take very little damage and can threaten Ribombee easily in return. The former two can clear its Sticky Web with Defog, while Entei poses a general threat to Sticky Web teams thanks to its powerful Extreme Speed.

sets.name: Lead
sets.description:
Moonblast is a powerful STAB attack that hits common entry hazard control options like Salamence, Mandibuzz, and Rotom-W quite hard. It also nails threats like Conkeldurr, Hydreigon, and Zarude. Stun Spore prevents Ribombee from being dead weight against Steel-types like Jirachi and Celesteela. It also cripples setup sweepers like Gyarados and Galarian Slowbro that try to take advantage of Ribombee while also paralyzing wallbreakers like Nihilego and Nidoking. U-turn can work well with Stun Spore to pivot out against threats who switch into Stun Spore like Excadrill, allowing Ribombee to bring in a teammate to pave the way for it to safely set up Sticky Web again. Skill Swap is primarily used to bypass Hatterene's Magic Bounce, but it can have bonus effects like removing Beast Boost from Nihilego or Sheer Force from Nidoking, opening up Ribombee's teammates a bit. Focus Sash is used to prevent Pokemon like Scizor, Lycanroc-D, and Choice Scarf Jirachi from OHKOing Ribombee immediately.

Thundurus-T is an exemplary Pokemon that takes full advantage of Sticky Web support—it's brutally powerful and very difficult to revenge kill outside of Lycanroc-D. Krookodile can provide an excellent Stealth Rock user to pair with Ribombee's Sticky Web, acting as a great check to the likes of Lycanroc-D and Nihilego when their Speed has been dropped. Necrozma is also a good option for a Stealth Rock setter that can pressure common Defoggers with its strong Meteor Beam and Photon Geyser, OHKOing the likes of Moltres and Tentacruel. Celesteela is an essential teammate that punishes threats to Sticky Web teams like Excadrill, Zarude, and Scizor. Keldeo becomes even scarier than usual when backed up by Sticky Web support, and its good defensive typing and generally solid bulk allow it to act as a soft check to Pokemon that typically annoy these teams like Nihilego and Mamoswine. Other generally good Pokemon that take advantage of Sticky Web include Gyarados, Azelf, and Nidoking, all of which can put huge pressure on the Steel-types that try to take advantage of Ribombee.

Lycanroc-Dusk.overview: Lycanroc-D is a solid revenge killer due to its strong Tough Claws-boosted priority move in Accelerock, which enables it to revenge kill weakened Dragon Dance Salamence and Gyarados, and high Speed, which lets it outspeed Thundurus-T and Nihilego. Access to strong coverage moves, such as Close Combat to break past Excadrill, Psychic Fangs to break past Amoonguss, and Crunch to deal with Slowking makes Lycanroc-D very unpredictable to defensively answer. However, Lycanroc-D struggles to break through teams that run physically bulky threats such as Tangrowth, Hippowdon, Swampert, and Skarmory. Its poor bulk also means it cannot come in on almost anything, so it requires pivot support to come in safely as well as occasional aggressive prediction on expected switches. Lycanroc-D is also very prone to wearing itself down between entry hazards and Life Orb recoil, limiting its staying presence on the field. The presence of priority attackers like Scizor and Azumarill can easily pick off Lycanroc-D. Zygarde-10% gives Lycanroc-D fierce competition as a fast physical wallbreaker due to a Stealth Rock resistance, higher Speed, and less prediction reliance.
Lycanroc-Dusk.comments:
Other Options

Sucker Punch can be used to deal more damage than Accelerock against neutral targets; however, it is only really useful for a better matchup against Choice Scarf Jirachi. Swords Dance is an option that allows Lycanroc-D to OHKO foes like Amoonguss and Tangrowth at +2; however, it can struggle to find many opportunities to set up safely. A Focus Sash lead Lycanroc-D is able to use Endeavor while setting up Stealth Rock, but this is generally not worth it in comparison to its other, much more dynamic sets.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Amoonguss and Tapu Bulu do not switch into Stone Edge well, but they resist Close Combat and threaten Lycanroc-D after switching in; the former also runs Rocky Helmet often, which punishes Lycanroc-D. Tangrowth is the biggest offender, since unboosted Close Combat damage is restored nearly completely by Regenerator, it commonly uses Rocky Helmet, and it can freely threaten Lycanroc-D's team in multiple ways after it comes in. Choice Scarf Zarude takes Accelrock well and can OHKO it with Power Whip.

Steel-types: Skarmory's excellent physical bulk and reliable recovery lets it effortlessly wall Lycanroc-D unless significantly chipped, though it does have to be way of switching into Choice Band Close Combat. It also can wear Lycanroc-D down with Rocky Helmet. Choice Scarf Jirachi resists Lycanroc-D's Accelrock and can revenge kill it with Iron Head. Scizor can revege kill Lycanroc-D easily with Bullet Punch.

Water-types: Foes like Slowking, Primarina, and Swampert that don't fall to one hit and are capable of firing back with super effective attacks pose problems for Lycanroc-D, which has to be kept in reserve while its teammates wear them down. Starmie naturally outspeeds and can threaten Lycanroc-D, though it must be wary of its health to avoid being taken out by Accelrock. Azumarill and Crawdaunt can take an Accelrock from Lycanroc-D unless they are severely weakened and revenge kill it with Aqua Jet in return.

Revenge Killers: Choice Scarf Hydreigon and Diggersby outspeed and OHKO Lycanroc-D; Diggersby resists Accelrock as well. Conkeldurr can OHKO Lycanroc-D with Mach Punch while Mamoswine can pick off a chipped Lycanroc-D with Ice Shard. Azelf, Zygarde-10%, and Raikou naturally outspeed and KO Lycanroc-D.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description:
Stone Edge is a very spammable STAB move that can OHKO Rotom-H and Salamence while dealing heavy damage to neutral targets like Primarina. Close Combat is a powerful coverage option that nails many Rock resistant Pokemon such as Keldeo, Cobalion, and Excadrill. It is also Lycanroc-D's best move for Hippowdon and Celesteela. Psychic Fangs inflicts heavy damage on the likes of Amoonguss, Tentacruel, and Keldeo. Crunch hits Slowking, Jirachi, and Galarian Slowbro harder, but these targets get musceled through by Stone Edge or Close Combat. Accelerock is useful against offense teams, specifically keeping threats such as Dragon Dance Salamence and Gyarados in check. It also makes Lycanroc-D more difficult to revenge kill with faster threats such as Starmie, Azelf, and Noivern which all need to watch their health against it. A Life Orb is used to guarantee feats such as 2HKOing defensive Celesteela with Close Combat and Amoonguss with Stone Edge on the switch with Stealth Rock up. Alternatively, Choice Band lets Lycanroc-D avoid the recoil associated with Life Orb while still boosting its power at the cost of being more predicition reliant. With Stealth Rock and Spikes up, Lycanroc-D can even break past Skarmory and Hippowdon. Maximum Speed investment with a Jolly nature is needed to make Lycanroc-D outspeed and threaten as many foes as it can, particularly Keldeo.

Lycanroc-D fits best on offensive teams, namely VoltTurn and Spikes stacking, that appreciate its ability to revenge kill common offensive threats such as Salamence without sacrificing its teammates' wallbreaking capabilities. As Lycanroc-D is unable to switch in on mostly anything, pivots are appreciated to give it opportunities to punch holes as often as possible and gain momentum; Moltres and Rotom-H are efficient at this and help pressure Skarmory and bulky Grass-types, which usually give Lycanroc-D grief. Rotom-W takes on Skarmory and Celesteela for Lycanroc-D and can bring it in against Chansey and Hydreigon. Entry hazard setters like Skarmory, Hippowdon, and Nihilego are important to wear down defensive walls like Tangrowth and opposing Hippowdon in range of Lycanroc-D's attacks. Skarmory, mainly Iron Defense variants, also counters Scizor and Azumarill for Lycanroc-D. Hippowdon can cripple Tangrowth and Slowking with Toxic, while Nihilego pressures Skarmory. Special attackers such as Hydreigon and Primarina appreciate Lycanroc-D's ability to break through Chansey, and in return they can help wear down common physically defensive threats such as Skarmory for it, paving the way for a late-game cleanup. The Grass-types of the tier like Tangrowth and Zarude are excellent partners to handle threats such as Azumarill. Additionally, they also check faster Pokemon Lycanroc-D cannot threaten as much with its priority, such as Zygarde-10%.

Salazzle.overview: Salazzle's good Speed tier, ability in Corrosion, and solid offensive utility make it a decent support Pokemon in UU. It can outspeed many offensive threats such as Zarude and Azelf, and it takes advantage of defensive staples like Amoonguss and Skarmory. The combination of Knock Off and Toxic lets it outlast Pokemon that would otherwise counter it, such as Tentacruel and Nihilego, and open up counters like Hippowdon for teammates. However, due to its weakness to Stealth Rock, Salazzle is forced to run Heavy-Duty Boots as opposed to a power-boosting item, which makes it heavily reliant on chip damage to make an impact. Its poor bulk also leaves it unable to contribute defensively in most games, and its typing makes it susceptible to priority users like Azumarill and Lycanroc-D. Salazzle's frailty also makes it reliant on pivots to safely enter the battlefield. This frailty also deters it from switching directly into most Pokemon it would otherwise check, especially Scizor and Tangrowth, who both carry Knock Off and can remove its Heavy-Duty Boots. Therefore, it would rather be preserved as a secondary check to the aforementioned Pokemon. It is also extremely difficult for Salazzle to make progress against bulkier Pokemon like Slowking and Hippowdon, but its Toxic support and chip damage can help mid-game wallbreakers and offensive pivots like Mamoswine and Azelf, respectively, break through or pressure them.
Salazzle.comments:
Other Options

Dragon Pulse can OHKO Zygarde-10% but should only be used if your team is weak to it. Nasty Plot over Toxic can make Salazzle a threatening wallbreaker or cleaner, but due to its frailty, it struggles to set up because even resisted attacks sting. Substitute + Toxic Salazzle can be annoying, but Salazzle struggles to make an impact when lacking one of its STAB moves, leaving it to pick and choose its good matchups and lose out on valuable utility. Substitute + Toxic also requires very solid entry hazard control, if running Black Sludge, and is still vulnerable to sand chip damage. A Choice Specs set has powerful wallbreaking potential, OHKOing threats like Conkeldurr and Thundurus-T from full health, but Salazzle can't follow up with Toxic and becomes weak to Stealth Rock, cutting into its longevity. It is also extremely prediction reliant, heavily limiting its wallbreaking potential against common defensive staples like Slowking and Hippowdon.

Checks and Counters

Faster Threats and Priority: Pokemon that commonly run Choice Scarf, such as Hydreigon and Diggersby, take advantage of Salazzle's extreme frailty and revenge kill it with ease. Priority users like Lycanroc-D and Zygarde-10% revenge kill Salazzle as well. Crobat and Noivern naturally outspeed and nail Salazzle for heavy damage.

Special Walls: Chansey can switch into Salazzle thanks to its reliable recovery and Natural Cure, proceeding to force Salazzle out. However, it hates taking Knock Off. Mandibuzz, specially defensive Hippowdon, and Nihilego are all able to switch in comfortably; however, they all hate Knock Off and Toxic.

Water-types: Water-types such as Slowking, Tentacruel, and Swampert can all switch into Salazzle multiple times but despise taking Toxic. Azumarill can KO Salazzle with Aqua Jet.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Salazzle's solid STAB combination lets it threaten common UU Pokemon including Amoonguss, Celesteela, Scizor, and Primarina. Knock Off makes Salazzle more difficult to pivot around with common checks such as Chansey, Mandibuzz, and Swampert. Toxic alongside Corrosion lets Salazzle cripple switch-ins like Nihilego, Tentacruel, Hippowdon, and Slowking, allowing itself or a teammate to overwhelm them and enhancing its offensive potential. Maximum Speed investment is needed to outspeed offensive threats like Azelf, Zarude, and Cobalion. Heavy-Duty Boots alleviates Salazzle's crippling Stealth Rock weakness and helps with its longevity, giving it more opportunities to enter the field safely.

Salazzle fits best on bulky offense teams that appreciate it heavily chipping the opposing team, paving the way for teammates to break holes with ease. Mamoswine is an excellent partner for Salazzle, beating checks like Chansey and Mandibuzz and wearing down their shared answers in Swampert and Slowking. Chip damage from Stealth Rock setters, such as Nihilego, Cobalion, and Swampert, is valuable to make switching into Salazzle even more of a pain. Knock Off absorbers, such as the aforementioned Cobalion, Amoonguss, and Tangrowth, are all appreciated due to how punishing it is for Salazzle to lose Heavy-Duty Boots. Cobalion in particular can draw in Grass-types to give Salazzle entry points to fire off an attack. Meanwhile, Amoonguss and Tangrowth check Swampert and Azumarill. Thundurus-T and Zarude are great partners, as both offensively pressure Slowking and Swampert while pivoting on Amoonguss and Tangrowth, giving Salazzle safe entry points despite its frailty. Celesteela and Slowking both reliably check Nihilego and Zygarde-10% for Salazzle. Slowking is able to pivot out on Grass-types with Teleport to let Salazzle in. Checks to defensive Scizor like Celesteela, Cobalion, and Salamence all pair well with Salazzle, as it cannot function as the sole Scizor check on most teams. Salamence also appreciates Salazzle wearing down Hippowdon and Slowking through Knock Off + Toxic, as this makes it extremely difficult for them to switch into repeated Hurricanes.

Dhelmise.overview: Dhelmise has a unique niche as a reliable spinblocker against Excadrill while providing entry hazard removal for its team with Rapid Spin of its own. Its Grass typing allows it to absorb Thousand Arrows from Zygarde-10%, which otherwise heavily threatens the Spikes stacking teams Dhelmise finds itself on. Dhelmise possesses semi-reliable recovery via Synthesis, letting it keep itself healthy to spinblock and better check common threats like Keldeo, Primarina, and Thundurus-T throughout a game. Dhelmise has respectable offensive presence while spinblocking thanks to its naturally high Attack stat and good STAB combination. However, Dhelmise is very slow and can be worn down quickly, forcing it to recover with Synthesis often, thus providing the opposing team with many free turns. Dhelmise is additionally threatened by common Pokemon like Hydreigon and Salamence, limiting its switch-in opportunities. Synthesis recovery is also hindered by the presence of sand from the extremely splashable Hippowdon, reducing Dhelmise's longevity. Dhelmise faces stiff competition from Amoonguss and Tangrowth as a defensive Grass-type; these two have greater physical bulk, are able to keep themselves healthy with Regenerator, and possess additional utility in the form of Spore from Amoonguss and coverage options like Sludge Bomb and Focus Blast from Tangrowth. Amoonguss's Poison typing also lets it check threats like Primarina and Zarude better than Dhelmise.
Dhelmise.comments:
Other Options

Knock Off punishes switch-ins that resist Dhelmise's STAB moves, like Mandibuzz, Zarude, and Hydreigon. Since Poltergeist cannot be used against Pokemon that have had their item removed, it may be prudent to run Knock Off instead of Poltergeist rather than alongside it. However, this reduces Dhelmise's overall damage output. Body Press can hit Dark-types like Zarude and Hydreigon for super effective damage, but is generally not worth running over its STAB moves. Rest is an option to alleviate status from foes like Hippowdon, letting Dhelmise fear nothing from them, but Rest is more exploitable compared to Synthesis. A trapping set of Anchor Shot, Swords Dance, Rapid Spin, and Rest with Leftovers or Chesto Berry can be used to lure walls like Skarmory and Tangrowth and use them as setup fodder, but this set falls flat into Scizor and generally has poor coverage.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types and Dark-type Coverage: While a Colbur Berry can help to absorb one Dark-type attack in a pinch, Dark-types like Zarude, Hydreigon, and Mandibuzz resist both of Dhelmise's STAB attacks and threaten super effective damage with their own STAB attacks. Umbreon does not resist Power Whip, but has access to Wish and enough bulk to take repeated hits, along with Toxic and Foul Play to threaten Dhelmise. Knock Off from Pokemon like Scizor, Azumarill, and Conkeldurr also threatens Dhelmise, especially if it is not holding a Colbur Berry, since it reduces Dhelmise's effectiveness as an entry hazard remover and spinblocker.

Flying-types: Flying-types like Crobat, Moltres, Salamence, and Togekiss threaten heavy damage or OHKOs on Dhelmise with their Flying-type STAB attacks. Celesteela threatens Dhelmise with Flamethrower on defensive sets and Air Slash and Fire Blast on offensive sets and has the bulk to repeatedly take Poltergeist from Dhelmise.

Fire-types and Fire-type Coverage: Moltres, Chandelure, and Rotom-H all threaten massive damage on Dhelmise with their STAB attacks. Several Pokemon like Nidoqueen, Azelf, and Diggersby commonly run Fire-type coverage, which prevents Dhelmise from reliably checking them.

Status: Scald burns from Pokemon like Slowking, Primarina, and Tentacruel as well as Will-O-Wisp from Rotom-W reduce Dhelmise's damage output and force it to use Synthesis more often, reducing its effectiveness as a spinblocker and providing free turns for switching or set up when Dhelmise is forced to recover. Toxic from Pokemon like Hippowdon, Chansey, and Swampert forces it to recover even more frequently than burns do.

Residual Damage: Rocky Helmet users like Amoonguss, Cobalion, and Skarmory punish Dhelmise for using Rapid Spin and have high enough Defense to take Poltergeist and Power Whip from Dhelmise many times if needed. Skarmory and Synthesis Amoonguss may also be able to PP stall Poltergeist due to its low PP, despite it not making contact, leaving Dhelmise unable to meaningfully damage them. Hippowdon's Sand Stream hampers Dhelmise's longevity by reducing the healing of Synthesis. Hippowdon fears Power Whip from Dhelmise, but is bulky enough to take one if needed, and can recover HP back throughout a game with Slack Off, plaguing Dhelmise.

sets.name: Spinblocker
sets.description:
Power Whip threatens Excadrill and Rotom-W, two common entry hazard removers, as well as common entry hazard setters like Hippowdon and Swampert. Poltergeist provides strong neutral coverage on many Pokemon that resist Power Whip, such as Salamence, Scizor, Moltres, and Crobat. Synthesis provides reliable recovery to keep Dhelmise healthy and check Thundurus-T, Keldeo, and Primarina long-term. The given bulk avoids the 2HKO from maximum Special Attack Primarina's Moonblast and the 3HKO from Thundurus-T's Psychic, while the Speed investment outspeeds defensive Celesteela. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Dhelmise to avoid chip damage from the entry hazards it is tasked with removing. Alternatively, Colbur Berry can be used to allow Dhelmise to absorb Knock Off from Pokemon like Mandibuzz, Scizor, and Krookodile and take one Dark-type attack to remove entry hazards in an emergency, such as Dark Pulse from Hydreigon or Darkest Lariat from Zarude. Dhelmise can make use of a more physically defensive EV spread to better facilitate this scenario.

Dhelmise is most commonly found on Spikes stacking teams, pairing well with Spikes setters and their beneficiaries. Skarmory excels as a teammate, as it is an excellent Spikes setter that can also absorb Knock Off aimed at Dhelmise. It also takes on dangerous offensive threats that Dhelmise cannot handle, such as Mamoswine, Zarude, and Scizor. Stealth Rock setters like Nihilego and Chansey help to further accentuate entry hazard damage and appreciate Dhelmise taking on Excadrill. Nihilego also provides Knock Off to force more Pokemon to take damage from entry hazards and can take on Flying-types like Moltres, Togekiss, and Salamence for Dhelmise. Meanwhile, Chansey takes on dangerous special attackers like Hydreigon, Chandelure, and Nidoqueen. Togekiss and the aforementioned Chansey can provide cleric support through Heal Bell and Aromatherapy, respectively, to rid Dhelmise of status and improve its longevity. Togekiss is notable for also being able to switch into and pressure Dark-types like Zarude and Hydreigon. Fast Electric-types like Raikou and Thundurus-T take advantage of Spikes well thanks to Volt Switch maintaining momentum and forcing Spikes damage on switch-ins, naturally pressuring Flying-types like Togekiss and Celesteela for Dhelmise. Other offensive partners like Zygarde-10%, Lycanroc-D, Mamoswine, and Azelf also pair well with Dhelmise, since it is able to maintain the Spikes that make these wallbreakers even harder to switch into. They can wipe out threats like Amoonguss, Salamence, and Skarmory for Dhelmise in return. Slowking can switch into Fire-type attacks from Pokemon like Moltres, Nidoqueen, and Celesteela. Primarina can comfortably sponge any attack from Hydreigon, which Spikes teams often have difficulty switching into if they lack Chansey. Rotom-W can take on offensive variants of Celesteela and helps exert damage through Volt Switch. Dhelmise's teammates should be mindful of their Knock Off use, as Dhelmise will be unable to use Poltergeist against Pokemon that have had their items removed.

Tapu Bulu.overview: Tapu Bulu is a decent wallbreaker that provides defensive utility to its team with passive recovery through its Grassy Surge. Tapu Bulu has a great movepool with coverage options like Close Combat, Zen Headbutt, and Stone Edge, which break through potential checks such as Celesteela, Amoonguss, and Moltres. Furthermore, its decent defensive typing, speed, and ability in Grassy Terrain allows it to distinguish itself from other bulky Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth by being a more reliable check to Keldeo and Azumarill as well as enable threats like SubToxic Aegislash, though it does have to be wary of the former crippling it with a Scald burn and hitting it with Choice Specs-boosted Air Slash or Icy Wind. While Tapu Bulu's typing has many useful resistances, it comes at the cost of having a lot of weaknesses to common attacking types like Fire, Ice, and Poison, meaning it struggles against staples like Entei, Mamoswine, Nidoking, and even Kommo-o due to its tendency to run Poison Jab. The tier has an abundance of defensive checks to Tapu Bulu, such as Salamence, Amoonguss, and Aegislash, which makes it difficult for Tapu Bulu to make much progress as a wallbreaker, especially when multiple of these checks are naturally found on the same team. Despite its positive traits compared to Amoonguss and Tangrowth, they still outclass it as a defensive Grass-type due to their access to Regenerator and less vulnerable typing. Furthermore, Tapu Bulu's Grassy Terrain also heals up the opponent's Pokemon as well, sometimes making it a hindrance to teams it is on.
Tapu Bulu.comments:
Other Options

Choice Band is an option that gives Tapu Bulu even more power; however, it requires a lot more prediction to break through its checks like Amoonguss, and Wood Hammer recoil can wear it down quickly. A Choice Scarf set can be used to revenge kill foes like Thundurus and Noivern; however, it primarily relies on surprise factor to do so. A specially defensive Tapu Bulu set with Horn Leech / Darkest Lariat / Synthesis and either Bulk Up or Swords Dance can be used as a better switch-in to foes like Keldeo and Thundurus-T. However, this set is a huge momentum drain against foes like Amoonguss, Kommo-o, and Celesteela. An Assault Vest set improves its matchup against the aforementioned foes while retaining an offensive presence; however, it can be easily overwhelmed by special attackers such as Primarina.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: Chandelure is a relatively safe switch-in to Tapu Bulu's most spammable moves and threatens to OHKO it. Rotom-H has to be wary of taking Close Combat; however, it can threaten to OHKO with Overheat and use Tapu Bulu as a free Volt Switch or Defog opportunity. Moltres has to be wary of Stone Edge but otherwise freely switches into Tapu Bulu and threatens to burn it with Flame Body or KO it with a STAB move.

Steel-types: Many of UU's more common Steel-types like Celesteela and Jirachi only take neutral damage from Close Combat and threaten to KO Tapu Bulu. Aegislash can comfortably stomach any hit in Shield forme and OHKO it in return.

Poison-types: Nihilego and Nidoking outspeed and OHKO Tapu Bulu with their Poison-type STAB. Without Darkest Lariat, Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro sets up on it with ease. Amoonguss threatens to OHKO Tapu Bulu with Sludge Bomb, though it has to be wary of +2 Zen Headbutt.

Physical Walls: Physically defensive Tangrowth stomachs any attack barring a +2 Megahorm and OHKOes Tapu Bulu with Sludge Bomb. Salamence is a huge issue for Tapu Bulu, as it resists the coverage it commonly carries and pressures it with Flying-type attacks, though it has to be wary of Stone Edge. Intimidate makes it much easier for Salamence to stomach any hit from Tapu Bulu. Defensive Buzzwole can stomach any attack and KO Tapu Bulu with Poison Jab.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Horn Leech is the preferred STAB option thanks to its recovery and respectable damage. Stone Edge is crucial coverage to break past Pokemon like Chandelure, Moltres, and Salamence. Close Combat lets Tapu Bulu break through Cobalion and hit other Steel-types like Jirachi and Celesteela harder; however, dropping Stone Edge leaves it unable to punish the common Flying-types, particularly Moltres, which can fish for a burn with Flame Body. Zen Headbutt breaks through Amoonguss, Kommo-o, and Buzzwole. Megahorn can help against Tangrowth; however, its coverage isn't very useful otherwise. Darkest Lariat can be used to hit Pokemon like Jirachi, Aegislash, and Chandelure harder. Life Orb with an Adamant nature gives +2 Tapu Bulu the extra power needed to KO foes like Tangrowth and Celesteela. A Jolly nature can be used to outspeed Buzzwole and Timid Volcanion, though Adamant's power is generally valued more.

Tapu Bulu fits best on offense and balance teams that appreciate its combination of utility and wallbreaking potential. Rotom-W can lure in foes like Seismitoad, giving Tapu Bulu free opportunities to use Swords Dance. Rotom-W can also remove foes like Moltres and wear down Kommo-o and Amoonguss into KO range of Tapu Bulu's attacks. Other wallbreakers like Conkeldurr and Nidoking can help break through defensive cores that Tapu Bulu struggles with. Keldeo appreciates Tapu Bulu being able to lure in and remove bulky Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth. Tentacruel is appreciated as another Water-resistant Pokemon, as Tapu Bulu doesn't want to risk a burn from Keldeo's Scald, for example. Although Tapu Bulu is a Fairy-type, it struggles to consistently check a majority of Dragon-types, such as Salamence and Kommo-o, due to its lack of a good Fairy-type attack and its weakness to their common coverage. For this reason, partners like Celesteela and Aegislash are imperative.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Horn Leech allows Tapu Bulu to gain recovery while still having a strong move to hit Primarina, Crawdaunt, and Lycanroc-D. Dazzling Gleam is able to sometimes OHKO Kommo-o and deals good damage to Zarude and Buzzwole. Toxic punishes switch-ins such as Rotom-H and Salamence. Synthesis is reliable recovery, but it should only be used sparingly due to its low PP. Heavy-Duty Boots is the preferred item, but Rocky Helmet can be used to punish contact moves from Zarude, Krookodile, and Gyarados. The EV spread is to outspeed Choice Specs Primarina while maximizing physical bulk to better check Buzzwole and Lycanroc-D.

Defensive Tapu Bulu is mainly found on stall and balance teams, as they appreciate it bringing Grassy Terrain for extra recovery. Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro and SubToxic Aegislash are great partners, as they can deal with Amoonguss and Togekiss, respectively. In return, Tapu Bulu is able to handle Krookodile, Rhyperior, Zarude, and Crawdaunt for these Pokemon. Chansey is able to check non-Dragon Dance Salamence and other special attackers such as Nidoking and Nihilego; Tapu Bulu beats Keldeo, one of the few special attackers that can break through Chansey. Umbreon provides Wish support so that Tapu Bulu does not have to use Synthesis often while also checking Salamence and Aegislash. Fire-types such as Entei and Moltres help deal with Jirachi, Amoonguss, and Aegislash, which wall it.

Nihilego.overview: Nihilego stands out as a great utility Pokémon that also boasts high offensive stats. Its good STAB combination hits key Pokemon such as Thundurus-T, Salamence, Tangrowth, and Primarina super effectively. It has important resistances like Flying, Fairy, and Fire; its Flying resistance and high Special Defense in particular are appreciated by teams that struggle with Flying-types like Moltres and Togekiss. Nihilego is an amazing Stealth Rock setter, as its resistances give very good matchups against Defoggers such as Salamence, Moltres, and Mandibuzz. Its Knock Off is useful for common switch-ins like Chansey, Scizor, Excadrill, and Celesteela. It can use Meteor Beam as well to boost its Special Attack and become a fierce sweeper. Its unique Speed tier puts it ahead of Salamence, Thundurus-T, and Moltres, and after a Speed boost from Beast Boost, it only falls behind Choice Scarf Zarude. However, its weaknesses and horrid Defense stat leave it vulnerable to Pokemon such as Hippowdon, Cobalion, and Keldeo, and priority from the likes of Conkeldurr, Azumarill, and Scizor easily shuts it down.
