It lacks room for coverage for Pokemon like Nidoking, and it just cannot get past checks like Jirachi and Excadrill.
Nihilego.comments:
Other Options

Protect scouts Choice-locked foes like Zygarde-10%, letting Nihilego switch to the appropriate teammate, but is hard to fit over the very valuable Knock Off. Toxic Spikes is a secondary entry hazard option that weakens defensive staples like Swampert and cripples Substitute users such as Primarina. However, Poison-types remove it and a large portion of the metagame is immune to it, like Salamence, Celesteela, and Scizor. A Choice Scarf set with Power Gem / Sludge Bomb / Thunderbolt / Grass Knot lets Nihilego clean through teams and revenge kill Pokemon like Crobat and other Choice Scarf users like Hydreigon, but Choice-locked Nihilego is vulnerable to Pokemon like Scizor and Azumarill. Pain Split can be considered as a form of recovery on the utility set, but it is very unreliable due to Nihilego's high HP and can only be used against special attackers that can't hurt it much.

Checks and Counters

Chansey: Chansey is Nihilego's best answer, capable of wearing it down with Seismic Toss and healing itself with Soft-Boiled. As long as Chansey doesn't let it accumulate several boosts, it can always beat Nihilego. Chansey hates having its Eviolite removed, though.

Ground-types: Hippowdon, Nidoqueen, and Swampert don't care about Nihilego's STAB moves and can force it out of the field with their STAB Ground-type moves, but the latter two dislike getting hit with Knock Off. Zygarde-10% and Choice Scarf Diggersby outspeeds and OHKOes Nihilego.

Steel-types: Excadrill and Jirachi wall Nihilego easily and can scare it out with their STAB attacks. The former is troublesome, since it can easily come in and remove Nihilego's Stealth Rock. Cobalion can pivot into Nihilego's attacks and exploit its weak physical defense. Celesteela is capable of taking +1 Thunderbolt and OHKOing Nihilego back with Heavy Slam. Scizor can revenge kill Nihilego with Bullet Punch, though it needs Special Defense investment to reliably switch into it.

Faster Pokemon and Priority Users: Faster threats like Lycanroc-D, Zarude, and Azelf all outspeed and threaten to OHKO Nihilego. However, these Pokemon must be wary of Nihilego getting a speed boost after getting a KO on its Meteor Beam set. Priority users like Azumarill, Conkeldurr, and Crawdaunt can OHKO Nihilego with their priority moves.

sets.name: Stealth Rock Utility
sets.description:
Nihilego's typing allows it to switch into a majority of the tier's Defoggers, including Salamence, Mandibuzz, and Moltres, and set Stealth Rock. Power Gem threatens many Defoggers and hits neutral targets Sludge Bomb can't, like Galarian Slowbro, Scizor, Skarmory, and Celesteela. Sludge Bomb threatens Pokemon such as Tangrowth and Primarina. Sludge Bomb poisons are helpful for crippling checks like Swampert. Grass Knot nails Hippowdon and Swampert attempting to switch in, though they need a fair bit of chip damage on them. Knock Off cripples checks to Nihilego like Chansey and Celesteela. It's also great for removing Heavy-Duty Boots from Defoggers. Black Sludge mitigates entry hazards and chip damage. The given EV spread and a Timid nature make Speed Nihilego's highest stat for Beast Boost, letting it outspeed revenge killers like Keldeo, Zarude, and Azelf.

This set fits on every playstyle except hyper offense. Nihilego's team appreciates its good defensive typing and Knock Off, and its offensive capabilities are valuable for removing threats like Primarina and Salamence. Stall in particular appreciates Nihilego's good matchup against Nasty Plot Togekiss and Thundurus-T. Skarmory is an amazing partner for Nihilego, forming an entry hazard stacking core with it and checking major threats like Excadrill, Hippowdon, and Zarude. In return, Nihilego beats threats to Skarmory like Moltres and Thundurus-T. Wallbreakers like Thundurus-T, Mamoswine, and Conkeldurr love Nihilego setting up Stealth Rock and weakening their checks like Assault Vest Tangrowth, Celesteela, and Amoonguss. Chansey completely walls this set even after having its Eviolite removed, so these wallbreakers can also take care of it. Pivots like Slowking, Azelf, and Zarude can bring in Nihilego to set Stealth Rock and wallbreak. Salamence and Rotom-H deal with Steel-types that threaten Nihilego, like Scizor and Cobalion.

sets.name: Meteor Beam Sweeper
sets.description:
Meteor Beam is Nihilego's most important move, boosting Special Attack and muscling past checks like Celesteela once they're chipped. Sludge Wave hits tier staples like Primarina, Tangrowth, and Hydreigon. Thunderbolt allows Nihilego to hit Steel-types like Jirachi and Cobalion neutrally and other checks like Celesteela and Slowking super effectively. Power Gem can be used in place of Thunderbolt for a more reliable hit on Pokemon like Mandibuzz, Salamence, and Thundurus-T. Grass Knot deals with Ground-types like Hippowdon, Swampert, and Quagsire. Pain Split can be used to give Nihilego some recovery, though the lack of coverage creates more issues. Power Herb is required for Meteor Beam. The given EV spread and a Timid nature make Speed Nihilego's highest stat for Beast Boost, letting it outspeed revenge killers like Keldeo and Azelf.

This set fits on hyper offense teams, where Nihilego can KO weakened checks like Celesteela with Meteor Beam to boost both its Speed and Special Attack. Entry hazard setters like Krookodile, Scolipede, and Excadrill help Nihilego by weakening some of its checks, like Nidoking and Celesteela. Keldeo and Belly Drum Azumarill are extremely strong wallbreakers that can punch holes for Nihilego to sweep late-game, destroying Chansey, Celesteela, and Excadrill. Secondary sweepers like Gyarados and Scizor can break past or dent Nidoqueen and Steel-types like Jirachi, Aegislash, and Celesteela. In return, Nihilego can remove Thundurus-T.

Celesteela.overview: Celesteela's typing and defensive stats are both fantastic in UU, allowing it to check a considerable portion of UU's top threats, including Salamence, Scizor, Diggersby, Hippowdon, Nihilego, and Excadrill. Thanks to its decent offensive stats, powerful STAB Heavy Slam, and access to Flamethrower to smack foes like Amoonguss and Zarude, Celesteela can prevent itself from being too passive. Leech Seed is also an excellent tool, sustaining Celesteela's longevity and allowing it to significantly wear down its switch-ins, such as Rotom-H and Thundurus-T, potentially forcing them out, while Toxic lures and cripples otherwise safe switch-ins like Rotom-W, Slowking, and Moltres. Celesteela can also operate with an Autotomize set, tapping into its strong special coverage and the sweeping potential Beast Boost lends it to clean through many unprepared teams. Despite its defensive potency, however, Celesteela suffers a bit from its lack of access to reliable recovery, which can prevent it from tanking strong neutral hits as consistently as it would like to and cause it to be overreliant on Leftovers. This can allow a few common Pokemon, such as Hydreigon and Mamoswine, to muscle past Celesteela after relatively minimal chip damage. Celesteela also struggles to bypass popular Fire- and Electric-types such as Moltres and Thundurus-T on its own, as well as various defensive picks like Tentacruel and Slowking; Tentacruel can utilize Liquid Ooze to take advantage of Leech Seed, while Slowking doesn't take meaningful damage from any of Celesteela's attacks, can absorb Leech Seed and Teleport out, and can threaten to chip Celesteela down with burns from Scald.
Celesteela.comments:
Other Options

Flash Cannon is an option over Air Slash for Celesteela's Meteor Beam set, dealing super effective damage to common answers like Nihilego. Meanwhile, Giga Drain lets it bypass Rotom-W and Slowking easier. However, these moves are much harder to fit compared to Air Slash's ability to flinch down slower checks like Moltres. Celesteela can utilize a mixed Assault Vest set to better answer Primarina and Salamence, with its colorful movepool letting it surprise typical checks such as Slowking with Megahorn and Moltres with Stone Edge and potentially break large holes in the opposing team. Due to its selection of potent physical moves such as Earthquake and Stone Edge, Celesteela can also run a physically based Autotomize set, effectively luring checks like Tentacruel and Rotom-H. However, this generally isn't as effective due to Celesteela's middling immediate power and hardships breaking various Pokemon, such as Tangrowth and Skarmory.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: Fire-types like Moltres, Rotom-H, and Chandelure can pivot in on both Heavy Slam and Flamethrower and hit Celesteela hard with super effective STAB moves. Moltres is particularly annoying, often being able to restore any chip damage it sustains from Leech Seed with Roost. However, they must run from Meteor Beam on Celesteela's Autotomize set.

Electric-types: Electric-types like Thundurus-T, Rotom-W, and Raikou can tank hits from either of Celesteela's sets and proceed to break past it with super effective STAB attacks, though they all take fair damage from Meteor Beam.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Chansey doesn't take major damage from Celesteela's attacks and can whittle it down with Seismic Toss or bring in a teammate with Teleport. Tentacruel's Liquid Ooze punishes Leech Seed attempts and it doesn't take major damage from any attack Celesteela commonly runs. Slowking can pivot into Celesteela and Teleport out to stop Leech Seed or chip it with Scald. However, it hates taking a Toxic.

Knock Off: Celesteela's defensive set becomes far easier to wear down if Leftovers, its most reliable means of passive recovery, has been removed. Knock Off users like Mamoswine, Azelf, and Scizor can wear it down immensely as it tries potentially pivoting in on them. The Autotomize set is also often reliant on Power Herb to pose a significant offensive threat, which can prevent Celesteela from setting up on foes like Scizor and Tangrowth as safely as it would like to at times.

Strong Wallbreakers: Celesteela's lack of reliable recovery allows particularly powerful wallbreakers, including Conkeldurr, Primarina, Mamoswine, and Keldeo, to quickly overwhelm it.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Flamethrower keeps Steel-types like Scizor and Excadrill in line and forces them out. It also hits Grass-types such as Amoonguss and Zarude, which are immune to Leech Seed. Leech Seed is important to wear down common switch-ins, including Moltres, Rotom-W, and Thundurus-T. It also prevents Pokemon like Gyarados and Dragon Dance Salamence from reliably setting up on Celesteela, chipping them down. Toxic cripples switch-ins like Slowking, Rotom-W, and Assault Vest Tangrowth, allowing Celesteela to overcome them in the long-term. Meanwhile, Protect works well alongside Leech Seed, offering Celesteela a guaranteed opportunity to restore health with both Leftovers and Leech Seed. It can also help to scout moves from Choice-locked Pokemon, like Zygarde-10% and Keldeo.

Celesteela is a solid fit on bulky offense and balance teams thanks to its ability to check several prominent threats like Scizor and Zarude, allowing offensive teammates to fall back on it upon losing momentum to foes like Salamence. Bulky Water-types often share strong synergy with Celesteela, checking the Fire-types that power through it, while Celesteela can handle Pokemon like Zarude and Tapu Bulu in return. Swampert and Slowking check both Rotom-H and Moltres, two of Celesteela's more effective answers, while also being helpful against Mamoswine. Slowking can also bring Celesteela in safely with Teleport against foes such as Tapu Bulu and Hydreigon. Nihilego is another good teammate, pivoting in on Pokemon like Moltres and Thundurus-T for Celesteela while appreciating its ability to deal with Ground-types such as Excadrill and Nidoking. Defensive Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss can also make solid teammates, as they can pivot into threats to Celesteela like Keldeo and Azumarill. They both can absorb Knock Off for Celesteela, and the former can use Knock Off itself to cripple switch-ins to Celesteela like Moltres. Zarude is another phenomonal partner capable of offensively pressuring Slowking better and revenge killing Thundurus-T. Entry hazard removal from the likes of Tentacruel keep Celesteela from being worn down by Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Autotomize
sets.description:
Autotomize allows Celesteela to outspeed the entire metagame barring Choice Scarf Hydreigon and more easily snowball, setting up on common threats like Hippowdon, Zarude, and Diggersby thanks to its typing. Air Slash lets Celesteela threaten foes like Keldeo, Hydreigon, and Tangrowth with ease. It can also flinch down defensive checks like Moltres and Slowking. Fire Blast provides important coverage against Steel-types like Scizor, Excadrill, and opposing Celesteela. Flamethrower is an option over Fire Blast for its greater accuracy. However, Celesteela wants all the power it can get due to this set's nature as a sweeper. Meteor Beam grants Celesteela an opportunity to bypass Fire-types like Rotom-H, Moltres, and Chandelure. It also deals massive damage to foes like Rotom-W, Thundurus-T, and Salamence, and the Special Attack boost it supplies is often extremely useful in boosting Celesteela's sweeping capabilities. Due to taking two turns, however, it must be used with Power Herb, and Celesteela must watch out for the opponent predicting the attack and bringing in a foe that resists it due to often being restricted to a one-time use. Beast Boost lets Celesteela boost its Special Attack upon netting KOs, giving it great sweeping potential.

This set fits on offensive builds, acting as a late-game sweeper that cleans weakened teams. On hyper offense teams, leads like Excadrill and Scolipede can provide entry hazards to wear down checks like Rotom-W and Slowking. Powerful wallbreakers like Azumarill and Keldeo make strong teammates capable of removing foes such as Slowking and Chansey for Celesteela to sweep through late-game. Gyarados alongisde the aformentioned Water-types can pressure Rock- and Fire-types like Nihilego, Rhyperior, and Moltres for Celesteela. Secondary sweepers like Thundurus-T and Nihilego often fit well with offensive Celesteela, helping pressure and overwhelm the likes of Chansey and Slowking.

Necrozma.overview: Necrozma is a solid sweeper in UU thanks to its offensive versatility, allowing it to bypass traditional answers like Chansey and Celesteela with its unpredictability. Its Dragon Dance set is a strong sweeper, powering through metagame staples like Slowking and Amoonguss. On the other hand, its Meteor Beam set is equally as potent, allowing it to lure in and slam answers to the Dragon Dance set like Celesteela and Mandibuzz. Its Calm Mind set can utilize its high bulk to act as a sweeper while also blanket checking threats like Scizor. Necrozma's high natural bulk and Prism Armor allow it to set up on many Pokemon like Nihilego and take super effective hits from threats like Cobalion and Scizor. Necrozma also has a solid matchup against common entry hazard removers like Salamence and Tentacruel, letting it act as an offensive Stealth Rock setter capable of supporting its team. However, Necrozma heavily dislikes status from threats like Chansey and Hippowdon, which limits its chance to sweep. Necrozma is also limited by the number of Dark-types in the tier like Zarude, Mandibuzz, and Hydreigon, which can all hinder at least one of its sets. Overreliance on Power Herb on Necrozma's Meteor Beam set makes it hard to pull off a sweep at times with Pokemon like Hydreigon and Slowking being common, while the Dragon Dance set can be worn down it accumulates multiple boosts.
Necrozma.comments:
Other Options

Necrozma can run Expanding Force over Photon Geyser on its Meteor Beam set on Psychic Terrain teams for more devastating damage, but the limited viability of the playstyle and reliance on Terrain being active make Photon Geyser the preferred option. A final option is a Stored Power set with Cosmic Power or Calm Mind to boost Necrozma's stats, but it lacks the dangerous immediate sweeping potential of Necrozma's other sets and can be inconsistent at times.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Choice Scarf Hydreigon and Zarude can easily revenge kill Necrozma, even at +1 Speed from Dragon Dance. However, if Necrozma uses Autotomize, it can threaten them before they attack. Still, Hydreigon forces Necrozma to conserve its Power Herb as it can take advantage of Meteor Beam requring two turns. Umbreon can tank hits from all sets and cripple it with Toxic. Although it must watch out for Meteor Beam, Mandibuzz can take on Necrozma well.

Special Walls: Special walls like Chansey and Slowking take on the Meteor Beam set with ease. However, they must watch out for the Dragon Dance set. Celesteela walls the Dragon Dance set and can take a boosted Heat Wave while wearing down Necrozma with Leech Seed, but it can get overwhelmed easily. Hippowdon can take boosted hits, cripple Necrozma with Toxic, and outlast it by healing with Slack Off.

Status: Status is detrimental to Necrozma's attempts to sweep, so moves like Thunder Wave from Togekiss, Scald from Slowking, and Toxic from Hippowdon, Excadrill, and Chansey greatly hinder it.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
Dragon Dance boosts Necrozma's Attack to incredible levels, letting it power through Pokemon like Hippowdon, Primarina, and Chansey. X-Scissor OHKOes Zarude and deals great damage to Hydreigon, Slowking, and Tangrowth. Heat Wave prevents Steel-types like Celesteela, Scizor, and Skarmory from walling Necrozma. With a Lum Berry, Necrozma can set up on Pokemon like Amoonguss, Rotom-W, and Slowking, which would normally stay in to cripple it with status. Alternatively, since Prism Armor lets Necrozma take weak super effective hits like Knock Off from Nihilego with ease, Necrozma can employ a Weakness Policy to get a huge boost to its Attack. Naughty is the preferred nature, since Necrozma outspeeds the entire unboosted metagame barring Choice Scarf users like Hydreigon after a Dragon Dance and prefers to not lower its Special Attack to boost the power of Heat Wave.

Necrozma best fits on offense teams as a late-game cleaner once its answers have been removed. Celesteela is problematic for this particular set, so powerful wallbreakers like Thundurus-T can remove it. Thundurus-T also beats Mandibuzz and helps wear down walls like Hippowdon and Primarina for Necrozma to bypass them more easily. Sticky Web support from Ribombee help offset Necrozma's average Speed tier, allowing it to outspeed Choice Scarf users like Zarude after a Dragon Dance. Stealth Rock support from Pokemon like Excadrill and Cobalion wears down Pokemon like Celesteela and Hatterene. Dark-type checks like the aformentioned Cobalion, Primarina, and Azumarill make great partners for Necrozma, beating threats like Umbreon and Hydreigon.

sets.name: Meteor Beam
sets.description:
In conjunction with Power Herb, Meteor Beam is a powerful attack capable of wiping out Pokemon like Salamence, Mandibuzz, and Thundurus-T while simultaneously giving Necrozma a boost to its Special Attack in one turn. Since Power Herb is single use, it should be saved until special walls like Chansey and Slowking are gone. Photon Geyser is Necrozma's primary move to power through many Pokemon like Keldeo and Amoonguss. It is also able to ignore abilities like Quagsire's Unaware. Heat Wave melts Steel-types like Scizor and Jirachi as well as Grass-types like Zarude and Tangrowth. It is also Necrozma's most reliable option for damaging Hatterene. Autotomize lets Necrozma boost its Speed to outpace threats like Zarude and Choice Scarf Diggersby. Alternatively, Necrozma can utilize Stealth Rock to act as an entry hazard setter for its team thanks to its good matchup against common entry hazard removers like Salamence and Rotom-H. Modest is the preferred nature to maximize damage output, since after an Autotomize, Necrozma outspeeds the fastest Choice Scarf users. Even if Stealth Rock is chosen, Modest is still preferred, since Necrozma doesn't miss out on many important Speed tiers.

This set also fits on offense teams as a powerful late-game sweeper. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Excadrill wears down Pokemon like Celesteela and Hatterene for Necrozma to break through them more easily and allows Necrozma to drop Stealth Rock for Autotomize. Excadrill can also beat special walls like Assault Vest Galarian Slowbro and cripple Slowking and Mandibuzz with Toxic. Early-game wallbreakers like Belly Drum Azumarill, Swords Dance Scizor, and Nasty Plot Thundurus-T can muscle through special walls like Chansey and Slowking for Necrozma. Cobalion can bring in Necrozma on Pokemon it can set up on like Amoonguss while also threatening Umbreon, Hydreigon, and Chansey for Necrozma. Sticky Web support from Ribombee help offset Necrozma's average Speed tier, allowing it to forego Autotomize for Stealth Rock if the team needs to as well as outspeed and remove threats like Keldeo and Raikou.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Necrozma can set up with Calm Mind against Pokemon that cannot OHKO it like Thundurus-T and Nihilego, making it harder to bypass with by special attacking threats such as Primarina and Salamence as well as become more threatening to Hippowdon. Heat Wave provides crucial coverage against Steel-types like Celesteela and Scizor. It is also Necrozma's best option to damage Dark-types like Zarude and Mandibuzz. Moonlight allows Necrozma to sustain itself throughout a match, although its limited PP means it should be used conservatively. Colbur Berry allows Necrozma to take Dark-type attacks from Pokemon like Scizor and Zarude and retaliate with a powerful attack. Leftovers is an alternative option that lets Necrozma preserve more longevity as it tries setting up. Even if Necrozma's Colbur Berry gets used up, the given HP and Defense EVs allow it to avoid the 2HKO from Zarude's Darkest Lariat as well as other attacks like Choice Band Zygarde-10%'s Thousdand Arrows. 28 Speed EVs let Necrozma outspeed Skarmory, with the rest put into Special Attack to boost its damage output.

This set best fits on bulky offense and balance teams that appreciate Necrozma acting as a late-game sweeper. Dark-types like Hydreigon and Mandibuzz are problematic for this set, so wallbreakers like Cobalion and Azumarill can remove them. They both also threaten Chansey and overwhelm Slowking. Togekiss also counters these Dark-types and can rid Necrozma of status with Heal Bell. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Nihilego and the aforementioned Cobalion wears down threats like Hydreigon and Primarina. Similarly, entry hazard removers like Salamence, Rotom-W, and Tentacruel are great for keeping Necrozma from getting worn down, allowing it to conserve Moonlight PP when absolutely needed. Tentacruel can remove items from threats like Chansey with Knock Off and check Celesteela, while Salamence handles Zarude. Pivots like the previously mentioned Rotom-W and Zarude can bring Necrozma in against Pokemon it can set up on like Amoonguss, Tangrowth, and Scizor. They both also can shut down Hippowdon. Choice Scarf Hydreigon can revenge kill faster threats to Necrozma like Zarude as well as check Slowking. Assault Vest Tangrowth can serve as a great defensive pivot for Necrozma, switching in on powerful wallbreakers like Keldeo and Primarina.

Toxtricity.overview: Toxtricity carries a unique niche in UU as a fearsome Electric-type wallbreaker that isn't shut down by the tier's Grass- and Ground-types. Thanks to Punk Rock and Boomburst, Toxtricity is able to deal heavy damage to walls like Amoonguss, Tangrowth, and Celesteela and maintain pressure on Pokemon that resist its STAB combination, such as Hippowdon and Swampert. In addition, Toxtricity has a relatively decent defensive typing, allowing it to come in on Iron Head from Jirachi and Close Combat from Cobalion and threaten to 2HKO them. It can also pivot into various passive Pokemon such as Togekiss and Amoonguss. However, Toxtricity is incredibly frail, leaving it with limited opportunities to fire off attacks and enter the field safely, relying on additional pivots to get in. Although Toxtricity's base 75 Speed is enough to outspeed the bulkier threats it is able to deal with, its bulk leaves it prey to revenge killers such as Thundurus-T, Excadrill, Azelf, and Hydreigon. Toxtricity faces stiff competition as an offensive Poison- or Electric-type with Nihilego and Thundurus-T, which offer better coverage and Speed.
Toxtricity.comments:
Other Options

Shift Gear sets with Drain Punch turn Toxtricity into a potent late-game sweeper that can set up on common threats like Cobalion and Chansey. However, Toxtricity is very frail and doesn't set up often, leaving outclassed by other sweepers like Meteor Beam Nihilego. Choice Scarf turns Toxtricity into a revenge killer that is able to outpace threats such as Keldeo and Azelf while still having a Special Attack-boosting nature. Throat Spray is an option on Shift Gear sets, as long as Sludge Bomb or Sludge Wave is used over Drain Punch.

Checks and Counters

Chansey: Chansey can take Toxtricity’s strongest offensive moves with ease. It can heal itself with Soft-Boiled as Toxtricty switches out, keep momentum with Teleport, and spread status with Toxic or Thunder Wave.

Psychic-types: Assault Vest Galarian Slowbro can directly counter Toxtricity, comfortably switching into Boomburst and forcing Toxtricity to switch out. Furthermore, Regenerator allows it to heal off most of Boomburst’s damage and consistently switch into Toxtricity. Azelf and Necrozma are faster than Toxtricity and threaten to OHKO it.

Ground-types: Hippowdon, Excadrill, and Nidoqueen are immune to Overdrive and threaten to KO Toxtricity with their STAB attacks. However, they can all get 2HKOed by Boomburst.

Faster Pokemon: Toxtricity's low Speed and poor natural bulk leave it prey to Pokemon that outspeed it naturally, such as Hydreigon, Keldeo, Salamence, and Thundurus-T.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Boomburst is the most powerful move on this set, heavily damaging Ground-types such as Hippowdon, Swampert, and Nidoqueen and wearing down switch-ins without recovery like Excadrill. Volt Switch is Toxtricity’s way of generating momentum against threats that Toxtricity cannot break through, like Chansey. Since Overdrive + Boomburst covers the entire UU metagame, Shift Gear can be used to boost Toxtricity's Speed and outrun revenge killers like Azelf. Sleep Talk is another option to absorb Spore from Amoonguss and still function as a wallbreaker. Sludge Wave can be used for immediate KOes on Fairy- and Grass-types such as Tapu Bulu, Hatterene, and Tangrowth, though they all hate taking Boomburst. Sludge Bomb is a viable alternative over Sludge Wave to poison and wear down switch-ins like Hippowdon and Swampert. Silk Scarf amplifies the power of Toxtricity's Boomburst, increasing its spammability and giving it good odds to 2HKO Normal-resistant foes like Skarmory and Cobalion. Air Baloon is an option to take advantage of Hippowdon since Toxtricity is immune to Toxic. Heavy-Duty Boots prevent Toxtricity from being worn down by entry hazards. A Modest nature is preferred to maximize Toxtricity's power against foes like Hippowdon and Cobalion, but a Timid nature can be used to outpace Adamant Gyarados and Mamoswine if needed.

Toxtricity fits on offensive teams as an early-game wallbreaker that can break down common defensive cores of Pokemon like Hippowdon, Tangrowth, and Salamence and open up its teammates. Toxtricity appreciates entry hazard support from setters such as Excadrill and Hippowdon to punish and accumulate chip damage on vulnerable checks such as Nihilego. Toxtricity can compliment these entry hazard setters by threatening to 2HKO entry hazard removers like Salamence and Rotom-W. Additionally, Toxtricity appreciates Pokemon that can threaten to KO and force out specially defensive walls. Keldeo is a prime example of a wallbreaker that excels at dealing with Ground-types like Hippowdon and forcing out Chansey thanks to Secret Sword. Pokemon that take on Excadrill and Zygarde-10%, such as Tangrowth, Salamence, and Zarude, make great partners. Zarude’s U-turn, combined with Toxtricity's ability to break its checks like Skarmory and Cobalion, yields another VoltTurn core that Toxtricity benefits from. Slowking can pivot into revenge killers like Azelf, Keldeo, and Noivern and bring Toxtricity in safely with Teleport to freely wallbreak. Late-game cleaners like Azelf and Scizor enjoy Toxtricity removing threats like Mandibuzz and Salamence so they can finish off the enemy team. They also form momentum cores with it and pressure offensive checks like Keldeo and Mamoswine.

Hatterene.overview: Hatterene is an imposing Calm Mind user for defensive teams to deal with because its ability Magic Bounce deflects status moves such as Toxic and Thunder Wave, as well as phazing attempts. Hatterene's STAB moves complement each other brilliantly and, alongside Mystical Fire, give it good matchups against entry hazard setters such as Swampert and Skarmory to block their hazards with Magic Bounce and keep pressure off of its teammates. Hatterene's solid bulk lets it take on threatens that can even hit it super effectively like Scizor. Hatterene's typing, while offensively potent, makes it a Fairy-type that's hit neutrally by Dark-type moves and a Psychic-type weak to Poison. This greatly impedes Hatterene's ability to consistently handle Pokemon such as Hydreigon and makes it unreliable at pressuring Tentacruel and Nihilego. It also struggles to beat Steel-types such as Jirachi and Celesteela if it does not catch them with Mystical Fire on the switch. Without a Calm Mind boost, Hatterene noticeably lacks offensive presence, which can be taken advantage of by wallbreakers such as Diggersby and Choice Specs Primarina. While it does have some good matchups against some hazard setters, it also has poor ones, such as against Hippowdon and Nidoqueen, so it can require prediction to make the most out of Magic Bounce. Excadrill is a hazard setter that not only forces out Hatterene but can completely ignore Magic Bounce thanks to Mold Breaker. Hatterene's dismal Speed tier greatly limits what it can accomplish against offensive teams.
Hatterene.comments:
Other Options

On Trick Room teams, Hatterene is an effective suicide lead with Focus Sash and Misty Explosion. Magic Bounce denies entry hazards from everything bar Excadrill, and using Misty Explosion right after Trick Room gives a safe entry point for teammates such as Crawdaunt with three turns of Trick Room still remaining. Hatterene can also be an offensive threat in Trick Room with Life Orb, but this sacrifices a lot of consistency in defensive utility because of its need for Special Attack investment and Life Orb recoil. Assault Vest alongside Nuzzle is an option to make Hatterene more bulky without a boost while still crippling the likes of Jirachi, but it faces stiff competition from Reuniclus, which has more consistent healing with Regenerator and better bulk to handle threats such as Keldeo.

Checks and Counters

Powerful Wallbreakers: Hatterene's poor Speed, lack of consistent recovery, and reliance on a Calm Mind boost to be a consistent threat makes it easy for Pokemon such as Mamoswine, Diggersby, and Crawdaunt to revenge kill it.

Steel-types: Jirachi takes little damage from Hatterene's STAB moves and threatens it back with Iron Head, though it dislikes Mystical Fire. Excadrill and Cobalion similarly take Mystical Fire well and can KO it with Iron Head. Scizor can deal heavy damage to Hatterene with Bullet Punch, though Hatterene does need to be fairly chipped for it to KO. Celesteela does not take too much damage from Mystical Fire due to its massive special bulk, and it 2HKOes with Heavy Slam.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Hatterene has plenty of opportunities to gain a Calm Mind boost against various Pokemon such as Mandibuzz and Salamence. Calm Mind notably helps Hatterene stomach hits from strong attackers such as Choice Specs Keldeo better and retaliate with Draining Kiss. Draining Kiss is mandatory as a powerful recovery tool and is instrumental against Chansey; after three boosts, Draining Kiss + Leftovers will outheal Seismic Toss's damage. Psyshock is useful against opposing Calm Mind users, most notably Primarina, as well as a more immediate weapon against Chansey. Psychic is an alternative option because it OHKOes Amoonguss after one Calm Mind boost instead of two. It also helps Hatterene pressure Quagsire better with Special Defense drops. Mystical Fire is vital to deter Steel-types looking to come in on a Calm Mind or STAB move like Celesteela, Jirachi, and Scizor. Leftovers augments the recovery from Draining Kiss and makes Hatterene harder for Pokemon such as Suicune to wear down. Hatterene needs 12 EVs in Speed to outrun Amoonguss and 56 EVs to outspeed Quagsire and help against stall, though Psychic is required for the latter Pokemon.

Hatterene fits well on balance and bulky offense teams that appreciate its Magic Bounce relieving entry hazard pressure from Skarmory. Pokemon that handle hazard setters Hatterene cannot switch into well like Nidoqueen, Jirachi, and Nihilego are appreciated. Chansey and Celesteela are able to check them. Celesteela can also pivot into Excadrill. Hazard support from teammates such as Krookodile and Chansey wears down Hatterene checks such as Scizor and Celesteela. Fire-types can blow through Steel-types that Hatterene has issues with; Rotom-H and Moltres are notably able to check Scizor and take advantage of Celesteela. Amoonguss and Skarmory can act as secondary pivots into Conkeldurr as repeatedly taking hits from them and losing its Leftovers greatly diminishes Hatterene's ability to clean with Calm Mind.

Obstagoon.overview: While STAB Facade and Knock Off along with Guts make Obstagoon seem like an appealing choice, it holds no real niche. It is completely outclassed as a Guts user by Conkeldurr, which has much higher Attack, ability to cover nearly the entire metagame in four moveslots, STAB Fighting-type attacks to nail Cobalion — which Obstagoon can't touch — and priority in Mach Punch. Moreover, its middling Speed leaves it outsped by many common foes like Keldeo, Azelf, and Zarude. Even with Rest, Obstagoon is worn down way too quickly from entry hazards, sand damage, its weakness to U-turn, and its own Flame Orb to make use of its increased longevity.

sets.name: RestTalk
sets.description: Facade lets Obstagoon 2HKO many slower defensive Pokemon like Amoonguss and Hippowdon after Stealth Rock damage. Knock Off slams Normal-resistant foes like Celesteela and Scizor. Rest gives Obstagoon some longevity against defensive teams that try to wear it down with residual damage and Sleep Talk lets it call moves when it's asleep while still being boosted by Guts. Unfortunately, the inconsistency when calling moves can make it tough to use when asleep. Due to Obstagoon's lack of coverage, it gives free set up opportunities to Cobalion, making it very difficult for it to force progress against most teams. Obstagoon can run a set with Close Combat and Switcheroo or Obstruct over RestTalk to remedy its coverage issues and cripple defensive Salamence, but this leaves it far more vulnerable to chip damage than it already was. Conkeldurr's better bulk and coverage make it a much more straightforward Pokemon to use. Obstagoon's higher Speed doesn't justify its far lower damage output as well, killing any viability it has.

Zarude.overview: Zarude's great Speed alongside U-turn allows it to be an excellent pivot and revenge killer. Its high Speed enables it to outspeed common Pokemon such as Nihilego, Thundurus-T, and Excadrill, and its good bulk and defensive typing lets it check many dangerous threats such as Rotom-W, Slowking, and Hippowdon, while also discouraging Zygarde-10% from spamming Thousand Arrows. The ability to heal status conditions and HP with Jungle Healing can allow Zarude to consistently pivot around defensive Pokemon such as Swampert and Hippowdon. Zarude's ability to synergize with other common pivots like Thundurus-T, Slowking, and Moltres has made it one of the defining components of offensive teams. However, it often struggles to break defensive Pokemon, such as Skarmory, Tangrowth, and Salamence, due to them resisting Power Whip and taking minimal damage from Darkest Lariat. Many teams naturally fit multiple Grass-type resistant Pokemon such as Mandibuzz, Cobalion, and Moltres, leaving Zarude with limited opportunities to use its strongest STAB attack. If it is running Choice Scarf, Zarude can risk being locked into an undesirable move, losing momentum. Flame Body from Moltres and Rocky Helmet from Amoonguss and Cobalion can punish U-turn, forcing momentum to be sacrificed to use Jungle Healing. Zarude's inability to answer threats like Keldeo and Primarina as a Grass-type can strain building at times, limiting its flexibility compared to Tangrowth and Amoonguss.
Zarude.comments:
Other Options

Rock Slide allows Zarude to OHKO Moltres while also dealing good damage to Salamence. Choice Band allows Zarude to function as a powerful wallbreaker, suprising usual switch-ins like Crobat and Amoonguss with a 2HKO. However, the increased prediction-reliance is problematic, and it still struggles to break through Skarmory and Mandibuzz. A Bulk Up set with Jungle Healing, Acrobatics, and Darkest Lariat allows Zarude to deal heavy damage and potentially tank super effective hits. Taunt is an option that can completely shut down Chansey's recovery and prevent Roost from Salamence, but Zarude would have to give up Jungle Healing or valuable coverage.

Checks and Counters

Faster threats and Priority: Faster Pokemon such as Keldeo, Azelf, Lycanroc-D, and Choice Scarf Diggersby are able to put Zarude in a tough spot, outspeeding and dealing heavy damage to it. However, they must watch out to see if Zarude is running a Choice Scarf set. Priority from Mamoswine and Conkeldurr can pick off a chipped Zarude.

Grass-types: Grass-types such as Amoonguss and Tangrowth take little damage from Zarude's STAB attacks, while Tapu Bulu resists both. Amoonguss and Tangrowth can threaten Zarude out with Sludge Bomb, with Tapu Bulu threatening it out with Close Combat, or set up on it with Swords Dance.

Flying-types: Salamence, Mandibuzz, and Togekiss can switch into Zarude's attacks easily. Salamence can weaken Zarude's hits with Intimidate, while Mandibuzz and Togekiss resist both STAB attacks. Moltres has to watch its health around Zarude but it can threaten a burn with Flame Body and KO Zarude. Crobat and Noivern outspeed and heavily threaten Zarude.

Steel-types: Cobalion, Skarmory, and Celesteela all take minimal damage from Zarude's STAB attacks, with the former two being able to chip Zarude with Rocky Helmet. Bulky variants of Swords Dance Scizor can set up on Zarude and threaten it with Bullet Punch.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description:
Zarude's STAB combination allows it to threaten many tier staples like Primarina, Excadrill, and Slowking. U-turn grabs momentum on usual switch-ins such as Celesteela and Salamence. Jungle Healing allows Zarude to remove status conditions from moves such as Toxic from Hippowdon and Will-O-Wisp from Rotom-W, while restoring 25% of its health. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Zarude to not worry about entry hazards, letting it constantly pivot throughout the game. Jolly is the required nature on the set so that Zarude can outspeed Nihilego and Thundurus-T.

Zarude is commonly seen on balance and bulky offense due to the easy pivoting provided by Heavy-Duty Boots and its ability to act as a status sponge against Toxic from Hippowdon and Will-O-Wisp from Rotom-W. Secondary pivots like Moltres, Thundurus-T, and Swampert all form potent pivoting cores with Zarude. Moltres appreciates Zarude luring in Grass- and Steel-types like Amoonguss, Scizor, and Skarmory, while Thundurus-T heavily pressures Celesteela and Moltres. Swampert can pivot into attacks from Celesteela and set entry hazards for Zarude to soften up Pokemon like Amoonguss with Stealth Rock. Other entry hazard setters like Cobalion and Excadrill also set Stealth Rock and appreciate Zarude dealing with Water-types such as Slowking and Swampert, while Zarude appreciates them dealing with Scizor and Rotom-H. Slowking and Celesteela provide a strong defensive backbone to support Zarude, checking threats like Azelf, Salamence, and Cobalion that hinder it. Zygarde-10%, Mamoswine, and Azelf are wallbreakers that appreciate Zarude bringing them in on Salamence, Tangrowth, and Amoonguss, as they often have trouble switching in safely due to their frailty.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Zarude's high Speed allows it to be a great user of Choice Scarf that can revenge kill Pokemon such as Keldeo and Azelf in addition to boosted sweepers such as Gyarados and Dragon Dance Necrozma. Power Whip OHKOes Lycanroc-D and Keldeo. Darkest Lariat is Zarude's strongest Dark-type STAB move and can hit Jirachi and Azelf for huge damage. U-turn allows Zarude to pivot out on potential switch-ins such as Tangrowth and Salamence, allowing it to gain momentum. Close Combat is able to hit Cobalion, an otherwise easy switch-in, for heavy damage. Jungle Healing can get rid of status conditions such as a burn from Moltres's Flame Body and Slowking's Scald while regaining HP so that Zarude can be used in the long run in a battle but it is not ideal to lock into. It also allows Zarude to act as a reliable status sponge if it takes a Knock Off when Choice Scarf is not needed.

Choice Scarf Zarude is a solid pivot and revenge killer on bulky offense teams. It appreciates additional pivots such as Moltres, Slowking, and Thundurus-T that can form momentum cores and pivot out of unfavorable matchups. For example, Moltres can bring Zarude in on Water-types such as Slowking and Swampert. Entry hazard control from the likes of Salamence, Excadrill, and Mandibuzz allows Zarude to consistently pivot without worrying about hazard damage. They can also check threats like Scizor and Tapu Bulu. Thundurus-T, Keldeo, and Nidoking are wallbreakers that appreciate Zarude's pivot support and its ability to check Pokemon such as Swampert, with the wallbreakers KOing Pokemon such as Amoonguss and Skarmory in return. Swampert is an entry hazard setter that appreciates Zarude dealing with Keldeo, Gyarados, and Hydreigon for it, while Swampert can set Stealth Rock in return and also help deal with Pokemon like Salamence. Primarina and Azumarill can help deal with some of Zarude's checks such as Salamence.
